45# The axes module contains all the wrappers to plotting functions. 

46# All the other methods should go in the _AxesBase class. 

47 

48 

49def _make_axes_method(func): 

50 """ 

51 Patch the qualname for functions that are directly added to Axes. 

52 

53 Some Axes functionality is defined in functions in other submodules. 

54 These are simply added as attributes to Axes. As a result, their 

55 ``__qualname__`` is e.g. only "table" and not "Axes.table". This 

56 function fixes that. 

57 

58 Note that the function itself is patched, so that 

59 ``matplotlib.table.table.__qualname__` will also show "Axes.table". 

60 However, since these functions are not intended to be standalone, 

61 this is bearable. 

62 """ 

63 func.__qualname__ = f"Axes.{func.__name__}" 

64 return func 

65 

66 

67@_docstring.interpd 

68class Axes(_AxesBase): 

69 """ 

70 An Axes object encapsulates all the elements of an individual (sub-)plot in 

71 a figure. 

72 

73 It contains most of the (sub-)plot elements: `~.axis.Axis`, 

74 `~.axis.Tick`, `~.lines.Line2D`, `~.text.Text`, `~.patches.Polygon`, etc., 

75 and sets the coordinate system. 

76 

77 Like all visible elements in a figure, Axes is an `.Artist` subclass. 

78 

79 The `Axes` instance supports callbacks through a callbacks attribute which 

80 is a `~.cbook.CallbackRegistry` instance. The events you can connect to 

81 are 'xlim_changed' and 'ylim_changed' and the callback will be called with 

82 func(*ax*) where *ax* is the `Axes` instance. 

83 

84 .. note:: 

85 

86 As a user, you do not instantiate Axes directly, but use Axes creation 

87 methods instead; e.g. from `.pyplot` or `.Figure`: 

88 `~.pyplot.subplots`, `~.pyplot.subplot_mosaic` or `.Figure.add_axes`. 

89 

90 """ 

91 ### Labelling, legend and texts 

92 

93 def get_title(self, loc="center"): 

94 """ 

95 Get an Axes title. 

96 

97 Get one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles 

98 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left 

99 edge, and flush with the right edge. 

100 

101 Parameters 

102 ---------- 

103 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, str, default: 'center' 

104 Which title to return. 

105 

106 Returns 

107 ------- 

108 str 

109 The title text string. 

110 

111 """ 

112 titles = {'left': self._left_title, 

113 'center': self.title, 

114 'right': self._right_title} 

115 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower()) 

116 return title.get_text() 

117 

118 def set_title(self, label, fontdict=None, loc=None, pad=None, *, y=None, 

119 **kwargs): 

120 """ 

121 Set a title for the Axes. 

122 

123 Set one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles 

124 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left 

125 edge, and flush with the right edge. 

126 

127 Parameters 

128 ---------- 

129 label : str 

130 Text to use for the title 

131 

132 fontdict : dict 

133 

134 .. admonition:: Discouraged 

135 

136 The use of *fontdict* is discouraged. Parameters should be passed as 

137 individual keyword arguments or using dictionary-unpacking 

138 ``set_title(..., **fontdict)``. 

139 

140 A dictionary controlling the appearance of the title text, 

141 the default *fontdict* is:: 

142 

143 {'fontsize': rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

144 'fontweight': rcParams['axes.titleweight'], 

145 'color': rcParams['axes.titlecolor'], 

146 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

147 'horizontalalignment': loc} 

148 

149 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, default: :rc:`axes.titlelocation` 

150 Which title to set. 

151 

152 y : float, default: :rc:`axes.titley` 

153 Vertical Axes location for the title (1.0 is the top). If 

154 None (the default) and :rc:`axes.titley` is also None, y is 

155 determined automatically to avoid decorators on the Axes. 

156 

157 pad : float, default: :rc:`axes.titlepad` 

158 The offset of the title from the top of the Axes, in points. 

159 

160 Returns 

161 ------- 

162 `.Text` 

163 The matplotlib text instance representing the title 

164 

165 Other Parameters 

166 ---------------- 

167 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties 

168 Other keyword arguments are text properties, see `.Text` for a list 

169 of valid text properties. 

170 """ 

171 if loc is None: 

172 loc = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlelocation'] 

173 

174 if y is None: 

175 y = mpl.rcParams['axes.titley'] 

176 if y is None: 

177 y = 1.0 

178 else: 

179 self._autotitlepos = False 

180 kwargs['y'] = y 

181 

182 titles = {'left': self._left_title, 

183 'center': self.title, 

184 'right': self._right_title} 

185 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower()) 

186 default = { 

187 'fontsize': mpl.rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

188 'fontweight': mpl.rcParams['axes.titleweight'], 

189 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

190 'horizontalalignment': loc.lower()} 

191 titlecolor = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlecolor'] 

192 if not cbook._str_lower_equal(titlecolor, 'auto'): 

193 default["color"] = titlecolor 

194 if pad is None: 

195 pad = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

196 self._set_title_offset_trans(float(pad)) 

197 title.set_text(label) 

198 title.update(default) 

199 if fontdict is not None: 

200 title.update(fontdict) 

201 title._internal_update(kwargs) 

202 return title 

203 

204 def get_legend_handles_labels(self, legend_handler_map=None): 

205 """ 

206 Return handles and labels for legend 

207 

208 ``ax.legend()`` is equivalent to :: 

209 

210 h, l = ax.get_legend_handles_labels() 

211 ax.legend(h, l) 

212 """ 

213 # pass through to legend. 

214 handles, labels = mlegend._get_legend_handles_labels( 

215 [self], legend_handler_map) 

216 return handles, labels 

217 

218 @_docstring.interpd 

219 def legend(self, *args, **kwargs): 

220 """ 

221 Place a legend on the Axes. 

222 

223 Call signatures:: 

224 

225 legend() 

226 legend(handles, labels) 

227 legend(handles=handles) 

228 legend(labels) 

229 

230 The call signatures correspond to the following different ways to use 

231 this method: 

232 

233 **1. Automatic detection of elements to be shown in the legend** 

234 

235 The elements to be added to the legend are automatically determined, 

236 when you do not pass in any extra arguments. 

237 

238 In this case, the labels are taken from the artist. You can specify 

239 them either at artist creation or by calling the 

240 :meth:`~.Artist.set_label` method on the artist:: 

241 

242 ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='Inline label') 

243 ax.legend() 

244 

245 or:: 

246 

247 line, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3]) 

248 line.set_label('Label via method') 

249 ax.legend() 

250 

251 .. note:: 

252 Specific artists can be excluded from the automatic legend element 

253 selection by using a label starting with an underscore, "_". 

254 A string starting with an underscore is the default label for all 

255 artists, so calling `.Axes.legend` without any arguments and 

256 without setting the labels manually will result in a ``UserWarning`` 

257 and an empty legend being drawn. 

258 

259 

260 **2. Explicitly listing the artists and labels in the legend** 

261 

262 For full control of which artists have a legend entry, it is possible 

263 to pass an iterable of legend artists followed by an iterable of 

264 legend labels respectively:: 

265 

266 ax.legend([line1, line2, line3], ['label1', 'label2', 'label3']) 

267 

268 

269 **3. Explicitly listing the artists in the legend** 

270 

271 This is similar to 2, but the labels are taken from the artists' 

272 label properties. Example:: 

273 

274 line1, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label1') 

275 line2, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label2') 

276 ax.legend(handles=[line1, line2]) 

277 

278 

279 **4. Labeling existing plot elements** 

280 

281 .. admonition:: Discouraged 

282 

283 This call signature is discouraged, because the relation between 

284 plot elements and labels is only implicit by their order and can 

285 easily be mixed up. 

286 

287 To make a legend for all artists on an Axes, call this function with 

288 an iterable of strings, one for each legend item. For example:: 

289 

290 ax.plot([1, 2, 3]) 

291 ax.plot([5, 6, 7]) 

292 ax.legend(['First line', 'Second line']) 

293 

294 

295 Parameters 

296 ---------- 

297 handles : list of (`.Artist` or tuple of `.Artist`), optional 

298 A list of Artists (lines, patches) to be added to the legend. 

299 Use this together with *labels*, if you need full control on what 

300 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above 

301 is not sufficient. 

302 

303 The length of handles and labels should be the same in this 

304 case. If they are not, they are truncated to the smaller length. 

305 

306 If an entry contains a tuple, then the legend handler for all Artists in the 

307 tuple will be placed alongside a single label. 

308 

309 labels : list of str, optional 

310 A list of labels to show next to the artists. 

311 Use this together with *handles*, if you need full control on what 

312 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above 

313 is not sufficient. 

314 

315 Returns 

316 ------- 

317 `~matplotlib.legend.Legend` 

318 

319 Other Parameters 

320 ---------------- 

321 %(_legend_kw_axes)s 

322 

323 See Also 

324 -------- 

325 .Figure.legend 

326 

327 Notes 

328 ----- 

329 Some artists are not supported by this function. See 

330 :ref:`legend_guide` for details. 

331 

332 Examples 

333 -------- 

334 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend.py 

335 """ 

336 handles, labels, kwargs = mlegend._parse_legend_args([self], *args, **kwargs) 

337 self.legend_ = mlegend.Legend(self, handles, labels, **kwargs) 

338 self.legend_._remove_method = self._remove_legend 

339 return self.legend_ 

340 

341 def _remove_legend(self, legend): 

342 self.legend_ = None 

343 

344 def inset_axes(self, bounds, *, transform=None, zorder=5, **kwargs): 

345 """ 

346 Add a child inset Axes to this existing Axes. 

347 

348 

349 Parameters 

350 ---------- 

351 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height] 

352 Lower-left corner of inset Axes, and its width and height. 

353 

354 transform : `.Transform` 

355 Defaults to `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in 

356 Axes-relative coordinates. 

357 

358 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \ 

359'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional 

360 The projection type of the inset `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name 

361 of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default 

362 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection. 

363 

364 polar : bool, default: False 

365 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'. 

366 

367 axes_class : subclass type of `~.axes.Axes`, optional 

368 The `.axes.Axes` subclass that is instantiated. This parameter 

369 is incompatible with *projection* and *polar*. See 

370 :ref:`axisartist_users-guide-index` for examples. 

371 

372 zorder : number 

373 Defaults to 5 (same as `.Axes.legend`). Adjust higher or lower 

374 to change whether it is above or below data plotted on the 

375 parent Axes. 

376 

377 **kwargs 

378 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the inset Axes class. 

379 

380 Returns 

381 ------- 

382 ax 

383 The created `~.axes.Axes` instance. 

384 

385 Examples 

386 -------- 

387 This example makes two inset Axes, the first is in Axes-relative 

388 coordinates, and the second in data-coordinates:: 

389 

390 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

391 ax.plot(range(10)) 

392 axin1 = ax.inset_axes([0.8, 0.1, 0.15, 0.15]) 

393 axin2 = ax.inset_axes( 

394 [5, 7, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData) 

395 

396 """ 

397 if transform is None: 

398 transform = self.transAxes 

399 kwargs.setdefault('label', 'inset_axes') 

400 

401 # This puts the rectangle into figure-relative coordinates. 

402 inset_locator = _TransformedBoundsLocator(bounds, transform) 

403 bounds = inset_locator(self, None).bounds 

404 fig = self.get_figure(root=False) 

405 projection_class, pkw = fig._process_projection_requirements(**kwargs) 

406 inset_ax = projection_class(fig, bounds, zorder=zorder, **pkw) 

407 

408 # this locator lets the axes move if in data coordinates. 

409 # it gets called in `ax.apply_aspect() (of all places) 

410 inset_ax.set_axes_locator(inset_locator) 

411 

412 self.add_child_axes(inset_ax) 

413 

414 return inset_ax 

415 

416 @_docstring.interpd 

417 def indicate_inset(self, bounds=None, inset_ax=None, *, transform=None, 

418 facecolor='none', edgecolor='0.5', alpha=0.5, 

419 zorder=None, **kwargs): 

420 """ 

421 Add an inset indicator to the Axes. This is a rectangle on the plot 

422 at the position indicated by *bounds* that optionally has lines that 

423 connect the rectangle to an inset Axes (`.Axes.inset_axes`). 

424 

425 Warnings 

426 -------- 

427 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change. 

428 

429 Parameters 

430 ---------- 

431 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height], optional 

432 Lower-left corner of rectangle to be marked, and its width 

433 and height. If not set, the bounds will be calculated from the 

434 data limits of *inset_ax*, which must be supplied. 

435 

436 inset_ax : `.Axes`, optional 

437 An optional inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are 

438 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners 

439 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box. 

440 

441 transform : `.Transform` 

442 Transform for the rectangle coordinates. Defaults to 

443 ``ax.transAxes``, i.e. the units of *rect* are in Axes-relative 

444 coordinates. 

445 

446 facecolor : :mpltype:`color`, default: 'none' 

447 Facecolor of the rectangle. 

448 

449 edgecolor : :mpltype:`color`, default: '0.5' 

450 Color of the rectangle and color of the connecting lines. 

451 

452 alpha : float or None, default: 0.5 

453 Transparency of the rectangle and connector lines. If not 

454 ``None``, this overrides any alpha value included in the 

455 *facecolor* and *edgecolor* parameters. 

456 

457 zorder : float, default: 4.99 

458 Drawing order of the rectangle and connector lines. The default, 

459 4.99, is just below the default level of inset Axes. 

460 

461 **kwargs 

462 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the `.Rectangle` patch: 

463 

464 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

465 

466 Returns 

467 ------- 

468 inset_indicator : `.inset.InsetIndicator` 

469 An artist which contains 

470 

471 inset_indicator.rectangle : `.Rectangle` 

472 The indicator frame. 

473 

474 inset_indicator.connectors : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch` 

475 The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left, 

476 lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are 

477 set with visibility to *False*, but the user can set the 

478 visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct. 

479 

480 .. versionchanged:: 3.10 

481 Previously the rectangle and connectors tuple were returned. 

482 """ 

483 # to make the Axes connectors work, we need to apply the aspect to 

484 # the parent Axes. 

485 self.apply_aspect() 

486 

487 if transform is None: 

488 transform = self.transData 

489 kwargs.setdefault('label', '_indicate_inset') 

490 

491 indicator_patch = minset.InsetIndicator( 

492 bounds, inset_ax=inset_ax, 

493 facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha, 

494 zorder=zorder, transform=transform, **kwargs) 

495 self.add_artist(indicator_patch) 

496 

497 return indicator_patch 

498 

499 def indicate_inset_zoom(self, inset_ax, **kwargs): 

500 """ 

501 Add an inset indicator rectangle to the Axes based on the axis 

502 limits for an *inset_ax* and draw connectors between *inset_ax* 

503 and the rectangle. 

504 

505 Warnings 

506 -------- 

507 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change. 

508 

509 Parameters 

510 ---------- 

511 inset_ax : `.Axes` 

512 Inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are 

513 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners 

514 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box. 

515 

516 **kwargs 

517 Other keyword arguments are passed on to `.Axes.indicate_inset` 

518 

519 Returns 

520 ------- 

521 inset_indicator : `.inset.InsetIndicator` 

522 An artist which contains 

523 

524 inset_indicator.rectangle : `.Rectangle` 

525 The indicator frame. 

526 

527 inset_indicator.connectors : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch` 

528 The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left, 

529 lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are 

530 set with visibility to *False*, but the user can set the 

531 visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct. 

532 

533 .. versionchanged:: 3.10 

534 Previously the rectangle and connectors tuple were returned. 

535 """ 

536 

537 return self.indicate_inset(None, inset_ax, **kwargs) 

538 

539 @_docstring.interpd 

540 def secondary_xaxis(self, location, functions=None, *, transform=None, **kwargs): 

541 """ 

542 Add a second x-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`. 

543 

544 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on 

545 the xaxis. 

546 

547 %(_secax_docstring)s 

548 

549 Examples 

550 -------- 

551 The main axis shows frequency, and the secondary axis shows period. 

552 

553 .. plot:: 

554 

555 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

556 ax.loglog(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5)) 

557 ax.set_xlabel('frequency [Hz]') 

558 

559 def invert(x): 

560 # 1/x with special treatment of x == 0 

561 x = np.array(x).astype(float) 

562 near_zero = np.isclose(x, 0) 

563 x[near_zero] = np.inf 

564 x[~near_zero] = 1 / x[~near_zero] 

565 return x 

566 

567 # the inverse of 1/x is itself 

568 secax = ax.secondary_xaxis('top', functions=(invert, invert)) 

569 secax.set_xlabel('Period [s]') 

570 plt.show() 

571 

572 To add a secondary axis relative to your data, you can pass a transform 

573 to the new axis. 

574 

575 .. plot:: 

576 

577 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

578 ax.plot(range(0, 5), range(-1, 4)) 

579 

580 # Pass 'ax.transData' as a transform to place the axis 

581 # relative to your data at y=0 

582 secax = ax.secondary_xaxis(0, transform=ax.transData) 

583 """ 

584 if not (location in ['top', 'bottom'] or isinstance(location, Real)): 

585 raise ValueError('secondary_xaxis location must be either ' 

586 'a float or "top"/"bottom"') 

587 

588 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'x', location, functions, 

589 transform, **kwargs) 

590 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax) 

591 return secondary_ax 

592 

593 @_docstring.interpd 

594 def secondary_yaxis(self, location, functions=None, *, transform=None, **kwargs): 

595 """ 

596 Add a second y-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`. 

597 

598 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on 

599 the yaxis. 

600 

601 %(_secax_docstring)s 

602 

603 Examples 

604 -------- 

605 Add a secondary Axes that converts from radians to degrees 

606 

607 .. plot:: 

608 

609 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

610 ax.plot(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5)) 

611 ax.set_ylabel('degrees') 

612 secax = ax.secondary_yaxis('right', functions=(np.deg2rad, 

613 np.rad2deg)) 

614 secax.set_ylabel('radians') 

615 

616 To add a secondary axis relative to your data, you can pass a transform 

617 to the new axis. 

618 

619 .. plot:: 

620 

621 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

622 ax.plot(range(0, 5), range(-1, 4)) 

623 

624 # Pass 'ax.transData' as a transform to place the axis 

625 # relative to your data at x=3 

626 secax = ax.secondary_yaxis(3, transform=ax.transData) 

627 """ 

628 if not (location in ['left', 'right'] or isinstance(location, Real)): 

629 raise ValueError('secondary_yaxis location must be either ' 

630 'a float or "left"/"right"') 

631 

632 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'y', location, functions, 

633 transform, **kwargs) 

634 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax) 

635 return secondary_ax 

636 

637 @_docstring.interpd 

638 def text(self, x, y, s, fontdict=None, **kwargs): 

639 """ 

640 Add text to the Axes. 

641 

642 Add the text *s* to the Axes at location *x*, *y* in data coordinates, 

643 with a default ``horizontalalignment`` on the ``left`` and 

644 ``verticalalignment`` at the ``baseline``. See 

645 :doc:`/gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/text_alignment`. 

646 

647 Parameters 

648 ---------- 

649 x, y : float 

650 The position to place the text. By default, this is in data 

651 coordinates. The coordinate system can be changed using the 

652 *transform* parameter. 

653 

654 s : str 

655 The text. 

656 

657 fontdict : dict, default: None 

658 

659 .. admonition:: Discouraged 

660 

661 The use of *fontdict* is discouraged. Parameters should be passed as 

662 individual keyword arguments or using dictionary-unpacking 

663 ``text(..., **fontdict)``. 

664 

665 A dictionary to override the default text properties. If fontdict 

666 is None, the defaults are determined by `.rcParams`. 

667 

668 Returns 

669 ------- 

670 `.Text` 

671 The created `.Text` instance. 

672 

673 Other Parameters 

674 ---------------- 

675 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties. 

676 Other miscellaneous text parameters. 

677 

678 %(Text:kwdoc)s 

679 

680 Examples 

681 -------- 

682 Individual keyword arguments can be used to override any given 

683 parameter:: 

684 

685 >>> text(x, y, s, fontsize=12) 

686 

687 The default transform specifies that text is in data coords, 

688 alternatively, you can specify text in axis coords ((0, 0) is 

689 lower-left and (1, 1) is upper-right). The example below places 

690 text in the center of the Axes:: 

691 

692 >>> text(0.5, 0.5, 'matplotlib', horizontalalignment='center', 

693 ... verticalalignment='center', transform=ax.transAxes) 

694 

695 You can put a rectangular box around the text instance (e.g., to 

696 set a background color) by using the keyword *bbox*. *bbox* is 

697 a dictionary of `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` 

698 properties. For example:: 

699 

700 >>> text(x, y, s, bbox=dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5)) 

701 """ 

702 effective_kwargs = { 

703 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

704 'horizontalalignment': 'left', 

705 'transform': self.transData, 

706 'clip_on': False, 

707 **(fontdict if fontdict is not None else {}), 

708 **kwargs, 

709 } 

710 t = mtext.Text(x, y, text=s, **effective_kwargs) 

711 if t.get_clip_path() is None: 

712 t.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

713 self._add_text(t) 

714 return t 

715 

716 @_docstring.interpd 

717 def annotate(self, text, xy, xytext=None, xycoords='data', textcoords=None, 

718 arrowprops=None, annotation_clip=None, **kwargs): 

719 # Signature must match Annotation. This is verified in 

720 # test_annotate_signature(). 

721 a = mtext.Annotation(text, xy, xytext=xytext, xycoords=xycoords, 

722 textcoords=textcoords, arrowprops=arrowprops, 

723 annotation_clip=annotation_clip, **kwargs) 

724 a.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform()) 

725 if kwargs.get('clip_on', False) and a.get_clip_path() is None: 

726 a.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

727 self._add_text(a) 

728 return a 

729 annotate.__doc__ = mtext.Annotation.__init__.__doc__ 

730 #### Lines and spans 

731 

732 @_docstring.interpd 

733 def axhline(self, y=0, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs): 

734 """ 

735 Add a horizontal line spanning the whole or fraction of the Axes. 

736 

737 Note: If you want to set x-limits in data coordinates, use 

738 `~.Axes.hlines` instead. 

739 

740 Parameters 

741 ---------- 

742 y : float, default: 0 

743 y position in :ref:`data coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

744 

745 xmin : float, default: 0 

746 The start x-position in :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

747 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 

748 1 the far right of the plot. 

749 

750 xmax : float, default: 1 

751 The end x-position in :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

752 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 

753 1 the far right of the plot. 

754 

755 Returns 

756 ------- 

757 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

758 A `.Line2D` specified via two points ``(xmin, y)``, ``(xmax, y)``. 

759 Its transform is set such that *x* is in 

760 :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>` and *y* is in 

761 :ref:`data coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

762 

763 This is still a generic line and the horizontal character is only 

764 realized through using identical *y* values for both points. Thus, 

765 if you want to change the *y* value later, you have to provide two 

766 values ``line.set_ydata([3, 3])``. 

767 

768 Other Parameters 

769 ---------------- 

770 **kwargs 

771 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for 

772 'transform': 

773 

774 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

775 

776 See Also 

777 -------- 

778 hlines : Add horizontal lines in data coordinates. 

779 axhspan : Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the axis. 

780 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope. 

781 

782 Examples 

783 -------- 

784 * draw a thick red hline at 'y' = 0 that spans the xrange:: 

785 

786 >>> axhline(linewidth=4, color='r') 

787 

788 * draw a default hline at 'y' = 1 that spans the xrange:: 

789 

790 >>> axhline(y=1) 

791 

792 * draw a default hline at 'y' = .5 that spans the middle half of 

793 the xrange:: 

794 

795 >>> axhline(y=.5, xmin=0.25, xmax=0.75) 

796 """ 

797 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax']) 

798 if "transform" in kwargs: 

799 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword " 

800 "argument; axhline generates its own transform.") 

801 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

802 

803 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds. 

804 yy, = self._process_unit_info([("y", y)], kwargs) 

805 scaley = (yy < ymin) or (yy > ymax) 

806 

807 trans = self.get_yaxis_transform(which='grid') 

808 l = mlines.Line2D([xmin, xmax], [y, y], transform=trans, **kwargs) 

809 self.add_line(l) 

810 l.get_path()._interpolation_steps = mpl.axis.GRIDLINE_INTERPOLATION_STEPS 

811 if scaley: 

812 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

813 return l 

814 

815 @_docstring.interpd 

816 def axvline(self, x=0, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs): 

817 """ 

818 Add a vertical line spanning the whole or fraction of the Axes. 

819 

820 Note: If you want to set y-limits in data coordinates, use 

821 `~.Axes.vlines` instead. 

822 

823 Parameters 

824 ---------- 

825 x : float, default: 0 

826 x position in :ref:`data coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

827 

828 ymin : float, default: 0 

829 The start y-position in :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

830 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the 

831 top of the plot. 

832 

833 ymax : float, default: 1 

834 The end y-position in :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

835 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the 

836 top of the plot. 

837 

838 Returns 

839 ------- 

840 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

841 A `.Line2D` specified via two points ``(x, ymin)``, ``(x, ymax)``. 

842 Its transform is set such that *x* is in 

843 :ref:`data coordinates <coordinate-systems>` and *y* is in 

844 :ref:`axes coordinates <coordinate-systems>`. 

845 

846 This is still a generic line and the vertical character is only 

847 realized through using identical *x* values for both points. Thus, 

848 if you want to change the *x* value later, you have to provide two 

849 values ``line.set_xdata([3, 3])``. 

850 

851 Other Parameters 

852 ---------------- 

853 **kwargs 

854 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for 

855 'transform': 

856 

857 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

858 

859 See Also 

860 -------- 

861 vlines : Add vertical lines in data coordinates. 

862 axvspan : Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the axis. 

863 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope. 

864 

865 Examples 

866 -------- 

867 * draw a thick red vline at *x* = 0 that spans the yrange:: 

868 

869 >>> axvline(linewidth=4, color='r') 

870 

871 * draw a default vline at *x* = 1 that spans the yrange:: 

872 

873 >>> axvline(x=1) 

874 

875 * draw a default vline at *x* = .5 that spans the middle half of 

876 the yrange:: 

877 

878 >>> axvline(x=.5, ymin=0.25, ymax=0.75) 

879 """ 

880 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax']) 

881 if "transform" in kwargs: 

882 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword " 

883 "argument; axvline generates its own transform.") 

884 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

885 

886 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds. 

887 xx, = self._process_unit_info([("x", x)], kwargs) 

888 scalex = (xx < xmin) or (xx > xmax) 

889 

890 trans = self.get_xaxis_transform(which='grid') 

891 l = mlines.Line2D([x, x], [ymin, ymax], transform=trans, **kwargs) 

892 self.add_line(l) 

893 l.get_path()._interpolation_steps = mpl.axis.GRIDLINE_INTERPOLATION_STEPS 

894 if scalex: 

895 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

896 return l 

897 

898 @staticmethod 

899 def _check_no_units(vals, names): 

900 # Helper method to check that vals are not unitized 

901 for val, name in zip(vals, names): 

902 if not munits._is_natively_supported(val): 

903 raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a single scalar value, " 

904 f"but got {val}") 

905 

906 @_docstring.interpd 

907 def axline(self, xy1, xy2=None, *, slope=None, **kwargs): 

908 """ 

909 Add an infinitely long straight line. 

910 

911 The line can be defined either by two points *xy1* and *xy2*, or 

912 by one point *xy1* and a *slope*. 

913 

914 This draws a straight line "on the screen", regardless of the x and y 

915 scales, and is thus also suitable for drawing exponential decays in 

916 semilog plots, power laws in loglog plots, etc. However, *slope* 

917 should only be used with linear scales; It has no clear meaning for 

918 all other scales, and thus the behavior is undefined. Please specify 

919 the line using the points *xy1*, *xy2* for non-linear scales. 

920 

921 The *transform* keyword argument only applies to the points *xy1*, 

922 *xy2*. The *slope* (if given) is always in data coordinates. This can 

923 be used e.g. with ``ax.transAxes`` for drawing grid lines with a fixed 

924 slope. 

925 

926 Parameters 

927 ---------- 

928 xy1, xy2 : (float, float) 

929 Points for the line to pass through. 

930 Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given. 

931 slope : float, optional 

932 The slope of the line. Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given. 

933 

934 Returns 

935 ------- 

936 `.AxLine` 

937 

938 Other Parameters 

939 ---------------- 

940 **kwargs 

941 Valid kwargs are `.Line2D` properties 

942 

943 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

944 

945 See Also 

946 -------- 

947 axhline : for horizontal lines 

948 axvline : for vertical lines 

949 

950 Examples 

951 -------- 

952 Draw a thick red line passing through (0, 0) and (1, 1):: 

953 

954 >>> axline((0, 0), (1, 1), linewidth=4, color='r') 

955 """ 

956 if slope is not None and (self.get_xscale() != 'linear' or 

957 self.get_yscale() != 'linear'): 

958 raise TypeError("'slope' cannot be used with non-linear scales") 

959 

960 datalim = [xy1] if xy2 is None else [xy1, xy2] 

961 if "transform" in kwargs: 

962 # if a transform is passed (i.e. line points not in data space), 

963 # data limits should not be adjusted. 

964 datalim = [] 

965 

966 line = mlines.AxLine(xy1, xy2, slope, **kwargs) 

967 # Like add_line, but correctly handling data limits. 

968 self._set_artist_props(line) 

969 if line.get_clip_path() is None: 

970 line.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

971 if not line.get_label(): 

972 line.set_label(f"_child{len(self._children)}") 

973 self._children.append(line) 

974 line._remove_method = self._children.remove 

975 self.update_datalim(datalim) 

976 

977 self._request_autoscale_view() 

978 return line 

979 

980 @_docstring.interpd 

981 def axhspan(self, ymin, ymax, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs): 

982 """ 

983 Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the Axes. 

984 

985 The rectangle spans from *ymin* to *ymax* vertically, and, by default, 

986 the whole x-axis horizontally. The x-span can be set using *xmin* 

987 (default: 0) and *xmax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; e.g. 

988 ``xmin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the x-axis regardless of 

989 the limits set by `~.Axes.set_xlim`. 

990 

991 Parameters 

992 ---------- 

993 ymin : float 

994 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

995 ymax : float 

996 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

997 xmin : float, default: 0 

998 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units. 

999 xmax : float, default: 1 

1000 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units. 

1001 

1002 Returns 

1003 ------- 

1004 `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` 

1005 Horizontal span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax). 

1006 

1007 Other Parameters 

1008 ---------------- 

1009 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` properties 

1010 

1011 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

1012 

1013 See Also 

1014 -------- 

1015 axvspan : Add a vertical span across the Axes. 

1016 """ 

1017 # Strip units away. 

1018 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax']) 

1019 (ymin, ymax), = self._process_unit_info([("y", [ymin, ymax])], kwargs) 

1020 

1021 p = mpatches.Rectangle((xmin, ymin), xmax - xmin, ymax - ymin, **kwargs) 

1022 p.set_transform(self.get_yaxis_transform(which="grid")) 

1023 # For Rectangles and non-separable transforms, add_patch can be buggy 

1024 # and update the x limits even though it shouldn't do so for an 

1025 # yaxis_transformed patch, so undo that update. 

1026 ix = self.dataLim.intervalx.copy() 

1027 mx = self.dataLim.minposx 

1028 self.add_patch(p) 

1029 self.dataLim.intervalx = ix 

1030 self.dataLim.minposx = mx 

1031 p.get_path()._interpolation_steps = mpl.axis.GRIDLINE_INTERPOLATION_STEPS 

1032 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

1033 return p 

1034 

1035 @_docstring.interpd 

1036 def axvspan(self, xmin, xmax, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs): 

1037 """ 

1038 Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the Axes. 

1039 

1040 The rectangle spans from *xmin* to *xmax* horizontally, and, by 

1041 default, the whole y-axis vertically. The y-span can be set using 

1042 *ymin* (default: 0) and *ymax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; 

1043 e.g. ``ymin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the y-axis 

1044 regardless of the limits set by `~.Axes.set_ylim`. 

1045 

1046 Parameters 

1047 ---------- 

1048 xmin : float 

1049 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

1050 xmax : float 

1051 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

1052 ymin : float, default: 0 

1053 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1). 

1054 ymax : float, default: 1 

1055 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1). 

1056 

1057 Returns 

1058 ------- 

1059 `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` 

1060 Vertical span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax). 

1061 

1062 Other Parameters 

1063 ---------------- 

1064 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` properties 

1065 

1066 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

1067 

1068 See Also 

1069 -------- 

1070 axhspan : Add a horizontal span across the Axes. 

1071 

1072 Examples 

1073 -------- 

1074 Draw a vertical, green, translucent rectangle from x = 1.25 to 

1075 x = 1.55 that spans the yrange of the Axes. 

1076 

1077 >>> axvspan(1.25, 1.55, facecolor='g', alpha=0.5) 

1078 

1079 """ 

1080 # Strip units away. 

1081 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax']) 

1082 (xmin, xmax), = self._process_unit_info([("x", [xmin, xmax])], kwargs) 

1083 

1084 p = mpatches.Rectangle((xmin, ymin), xmax - xmin, ymax - ymin, **kwargs) 

1085 p.set_transform(self.get_xaxis_transform(which="grid")) 

1086 # For Rectangles and non-separable transforms, add_patch can be buggy 

1087 # and update the y limits even though it shouldn't do so for an 

1088 # xaxis_transformed patch, so undo that update. 

1089 iy = self.dataLim.intervaly.copy() 

1090 my = self.dataLim.minposy 

1091 self.add_patch(p) 

1092 self.dataLim.intervaly = iy 

1093 self.dataLim.minposy = my 

1094 p.get_path()._interpolation_steps = mpl.axis.GRIDLINE_INTERPOLATION_STEPS 

1095 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

1096 return p 

1097 

1098 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "label") 

1099 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["y", "xmin", "xmax", "colors"], 

1100 label_namer="y") 

1101 def hlines(self, y, xmin, xmax, colors=None, linestyles='solid', 

1102 label='', **kwargs): 

1103 """ 

1104 Plot horizontal lines at each *y* from *xmin* to *xmax*. 

1105 

1106 Parameters 

1107 ---------- 

1108 y : float or array-like 

1109 y-indexes where to plot the lines. 

1110 

1111 xmin, xmax : float or array-like 

1112 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are 

1113 provided, all lines will have the same length. 

1114 

1115 colors : :mpltype:`color` or list of color , default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1116 

1117 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, default: 'solid' 

1118 

1119 label : str, default: '' 

1120 

1121 Returns 

1122 ------- 

1123 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` 

1124 

1125 Other Parameters 

1126 ---------------- 

1127 data : indexable object, optional 

1128 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1129 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties. 

1130 

1131 See Also 

1132 -------- 

1133 vlines : vertical lines 

1134 axhline : horizontal line across the Axes 

1135 """ 

1136 

1137 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform 

1138 xmin, xmax, y = self._process_unit_info( 

1139 [("x", xmin), ("x", xmax), ("y", y)], kwargs) 

1140 

1141 if not np.iterable(y): 

1142 y = [y] 

1143 if not np.iterable(xmin): 

1144 xmin = [xmin] 

1145 if not np.iterable(xmax): 

1146 xmax = [xmax] 

1147 

1148 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input 

1149 y, xmin, xmax = cbook._combine_masks(y, xmin, xmax) 

1150 y = np.ravel(y) 

1151 xmin = np.ravel(xmin) 

1152 xmax = np.ravel(xmax) 

1153 

1154 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(y), 2, 2)) 

1155 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = xmin 

1156 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = y 

1157 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = xmax 

1158 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = y 

1159 

1160 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors, 

1161 linestyles=linestyles, label=label) 

1162 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False) 

1163 lines._internal_update(kwargs) 

1164 

1165 if len(y) > 0: 

1166 # Extreme values of xmin/xmax/y. Using masked_verts here handles 

1167 # the case of y being a masked *object* array (as can be generated 

1168 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble. 

1169 updatex = True 

1170 updatey = True 

1171 if self.name == "rectilinear": 

1172 datalim = lines.get_datalim(self.transData) 

1173 t = lines.get_transform() 

1174 updatex, updatey = t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData) 

1175 minx = np.nanmin(datalim.xmin) 

1176 maxx = np.nanmax(datalim.xmax) 

1177 miny = np.nanmin(datalim.ymin) 

1178 maxy = np.nanmax(datalim.ymax) 

1179 else: 

1180 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1181 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1182 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1183 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1184 

1185 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy) 

1186 self.update_datalim(corners, updatex, updatey) 

1187 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1188 return lines 

1189 

1190 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "label") 

1191 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "ymin", "ymax", "colors"], 

1192 label_namer="x") 

1193 def vlines(self, x, ymin, ymax, colors=None, linestyles='solid', 

1194 label='', **kwargs): 

1195 """ 

1196 Plot vertical lines at each *x* from *ymin* to *ymax*. 

1197 

1198 Parameters 

1199 ---------- 

1200 x : float or array-like 

1201 x-indexes where to plot the lines. 

1202 

1203 ymin, ymax : float or array-like 

1204 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are 

1205 provided, all lines will have the same length. 

1206 

1207 colors : :mpltype:`color` or list of color, default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1208 

1209 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, default: 'solid' 

1210 

1211 label : str, default: '' 

1212 

1213 Returns 

1214 ------- 

1215 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` 

1216 

1217 Other Parameters 

1218 ---------------- 

1219 data : indexable object, optional 

1220 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1221 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties. 

1222 

1223 See Also 

1224 -------- 

1225 hlines : horizontal lines 

1226 axvline : vertical line across the Axes 

1227 """ 

1228 

1229 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform 

1230 x, ymin, ymax = self._process_unit_info( 

1231 [("x", x), ("y", ymin), ("y", ymax)], kwargs) 

1232 

1233 if not np.iterable(x): 

1234 x = [x] 

1235 if not np.iterable(ymin): 

1236 ymin = [ymin] 

1237 if not np.iterable(ymax): 

1238 ymax = [ymax] 

1239 

1240 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input 

1241 x, ymin, ymax = cbook._combine_masks(x, ymin, ymax) 

1242 x = np.ravel(x) 

1243 ymin = np.ravel(ymin) 

1244 ymax = np.ravel(ymax) 

1245 

1246 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(x), 2, 2)) 

1247 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = x 

1248 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = ymin 

1249 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = x 

1250 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = ymax 

1251 

1252 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors, 

1253 linestyles=linestyles, label=label) 

1254 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False) 

1255 lines._internal_update(kwargs) 

1256 

1257 if len(x) > 0: 

1258 # Extreme values of x/ymin/ymax. Using masked_verts here handles 

1259 # the case of x being a masked *object* array (as can be generated 

1260 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble. 

1261 updatex = True 

1262 updatey = True 

1263 if self.name == "rectilinear": 

1264 datalim = lines.get_datalim(self.transData) 

1265 t = lines.get_transform() 

1266 updatex, updatey = t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData) 

1267 minx = np.nanmin(datalim.xmin) 

1268 maxx = np.nanmax(datalim.xmax) 

1269 miny = np.nanmin(datalim.ymin) 

1270 maxy = np.nanmax(datalim.ymax) 

1271 else: 

1272 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1273 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1274 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1275 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1276 

1277 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy) 

1278 self.update_datalim(corners, updatex, updatey) 

1279 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1280 return lines 

1281 

1282 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "orientation") 

1283 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["positions", "lineoffsets", 

1284 "linelengths", "linewidths", 

1285 "colors", "linestyles"]) 

1286 @_docstring.interpd 

1287 def eventplot(self, positions, orientation='horizontal', lineoffsets=1, 

1288 linelengths=1, linewidths=None, colors=None, alpha=None, 

1289 linestyles='solid', **kwargs): 

1290 """ 

1291 Plot identical parallel lines at the given positions. 

1292 

1293 This type of plot is commonly used in neuroscience for representing 

1294 neural events, where it is usually called a spike raster, dot raster, 

1295 or raster plot. 

1296 

1297 However, it is useful in any situation where you wish to show the 

1298 timing or position of multiple sets of discrete events, such as the 

1299 arrival times of people to a business on each day of the month or the 

1300 date of hurricanes each year of the last century. 

1301 

1302 Parameters 

1303 ---------- 

1304 positions : array-like or list of array-like 

1305 A 1D array-like defines the positions of one sequence of events. 

1306 

1307 Multiple groups of events may be passed as a list of array-likes. 

1308 Each group can be styled independently by passing lists of values 

1309 to *lineoffsets*, *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors* and 

1310 *linestyles*. 

1311 

1312 Note that *positions* can be a 2D array, but in practice different 

1313 event groups usually have different counts so that one will use a 

1314 list of different-length arrays rather than a 2D array. 

1315 

1316 orientation : {'horizontal', 'vertical'}, default: 'horizontal' 

1317 The direction of the event sequence: 

1318 

1319 - 'horizontal': the events are arranged horizontally. 

1320 The indicator lines are vertical. 

1321 - 'vertical': the events are arranged vertically. 

1322 The indicator lines are horizontal. 

1323 

1324 lineoffsets : float or array-like, default: 1 

1325 The offset of the center of the lines from the origin, in the 

1326 direction orthogonal to *orientation*. 

1327 

1328 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1329 the length of *positions*. 

1330 

1331 linelengths : float or array-like, default: 1 

1332 The total height of the lines (i.e. the lines stretches from 

1333 ``lineoffset - linelength/2`` to ``lineoffset + linelength/2``). 

1334 

1335 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1336 the length of *positions*. 

1337 

1338 linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth` 

1339 The line width(s) of the event lines, in points. 

1340 

1341 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1342 the length of *positions*. 

1343 

1344 colors : :mpltype:`color` or list of color, default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1345 The color(s) of the event lines. 

1346 

1347 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1348 the length of *positions*. 

1349 

1350 alpha : float or array-like, default: 1 

1351 The alpha blending value(s), between 0 (transparent) and 1 

1352 (opaque). 

1353 

1354 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1355 the length of *positions*. 

1356 

1357 linestyles : str or tuple or list of such values, default: 'solid' 

1358 Default is 'solid'. Valid strings are ['solid', 'dashed', 

1359 'dashdot', 'dotted', '-', '--', '-.', ':']. Dash tuples 

1360 should be of the form:: 

1361 

1362 (offset, onoffseq), 

1363 

1364 where *onoffseq* is an even length tuple of on and off ink 

1365 in points. 

1366 

1367 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1368 the length of *positions*. 

1369 

1370 data : indexable object, optional 

1371 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1372 

1373 **kwargs 

1374 Other keyword arguments are line collection properties. See 

1375 `.LineCollection` for a list of the valid properties. 

1376 

1377 Returns 

1378 ------- 

1379 list of `.EventCollection` 

1380 The `.EventCollection` that were added. 

1381 

1382 Notes 

1383 ----- 

1384 For *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors*, *alpha* and *linestyles*, if 

1385 only a single value is given, that value is applied to all lines. If an 

1386 array-like is given, it must have the same length as *positions*, and 

1387 each value will be applied to the corresponding row of the array. 

1388 

1389 Examples 

1390 -------- 

1391 .. plot:: gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/eventplot_demo.py 

1392 """ 

1393 

1394 lineoffsets, linelengths = self._process_unit_info( 

1395 [("y", lineoffsets), ("y", linelengths)], kwargs) 

1396 

1397 # fix positions, noting that it can be a list of lists: 

1398 if not np.iterable(positions): 

1399 positions = [positions] 

1400 elif any(np.iterable(position) for position in positions): 

1401 positions = [np.asanyarray(position) for position in positions] 

1402 else: 

1403 positions = [np.asanyarray(positions)] 

1404 

1405 poss = [] 

1406 for position in positions: 

1407 poss += self._process_unit_info([("x", position)], kwargs) 

1408 positions = poss 

1409 

1410 # prevent 'singular' keys from **kwargs dict from overriding the effect 

1411 # of 'plural' keyword arguments (e.g. 'color' overriding 'colors') 

1412 colors = cbook._local_over_kwdict(colors, kwargs, 'color') 

1413 linewidths = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linewidths, kwargs, 'linewidth') 

1414 linestyles = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linestyles, kwargs, 'linestyle') 

1415 

1416 if not np.iterable(lineoffsets): 

1417 lineoffsets = [lineoffsets] 

1418 if not np.iterable(linelengths): 

1419 linelengths = [linelengths] 

1420 if not np.iterable(linewidths): 

1421 linewidths = [linewidths] 

1422 if not np.iterable(colors): 

1423 colors = [colors] 

1424 if not np.iterable(alpha): 

1425 alpha = [alpha] 

1426 if hasattr(linestyles, 'lower') or not np.iterable(linestyles): 

1427 linestyles = [linestyles] 

1428 

1429 lineoffsets = np.asarray(lineoffsets) 

1430 linelengths = np.asarray(linelengths) 

1431 linewidths = np.asarray(linewidths) 

1432 

1433 if len(lineoffsets) == 0: 

1434 raise ValueError('lineoffsets cannot be empty') 

1435 if len(linelengths) == 0: 

1436 raise ValueError('linelengths cannot be empty') 

1437 if len(linestyles) == 0: 

1438 raise ValueError('linestyles cannot be empty') 

1439 if len(linewidths) == 0: 

1440 raise ValueError('linewidths cannot be empty') 

1441 if len(alpha) == 0: 

1442 raise ValueError('alpha cannot be empty') 

1443 if len(colors) == 0: 

1444 colors = [None] 

1445 try: 

1446 # Early conversion of the colors into RGBA values to take care 

1447 # of cases like colors='0.5' or colors='C1'. (Issue #8193) 

1448 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(colors) 

1449 except ValueError: 

1450 # Will fail if any element of *colors* is None. But as long 

1451 # as len(colors) == 1 or len(positions), the rest of the 

1452 # code should process *colors* properly. 

1453 pass 

1454 

1455 if len(lineoffsets) == 1 and len(positions) != 1: 

1456 lineoffsets = np.tile(lineoffsets, len(positions)) 

1457 lineoffsets[0] = 0 

1458 lineoffsets = np.cumsum(lineoffsets) 

1459 if len(linelengths) == 1: 

1460 linelengths = np.tile(linelengths, len(positions)) 

1461 if len(linewidths) == 1: 

1462 linewidths = np.tile(linewidths, len(positions)) 

1463 if len(colors) == 1: 

1464 colors = list(colors) * len(positions) 

1465 if len(alpha) == 1: 

1466 alpha = list(alpha) * len(positions) 

1467 if len(linestyles) == 1: 

1468 linestyles = [linestyles] * len(positions) 

1469 

1470 if len(lineoffsets) != len(positions): 

1471 raise ValueError('lineoffsets and positions are unequal sized ' 

1472 'sequences') 

1473 if len(linelengths) != len(positions): 

1474 raise ValueError('linelengths and positions are unequal sized ' 

1475 'sequences') 

1476 if len(linewidths) != len(positions): 

1477 raise ValueError('linewidths and positions are unequal sized ' 

1478 'sequences') 

1479 if len(colors) != len(positions): 

1480 raise ValueError('colors and positions are unequal sized ' 

1481 'sequences') 

1482 if len(alpha) != len(positions): 

1483 raise ValueError('alpha and positions are unequal sized ' 

1484 'sequences') 

1485 if len(linestyles) != len(positions): 

1486 raise ValueError('linestyles and positions are unequal sized ' 

1487 'sequences') 

1488 

1489 colls = [] 

1490 for position, lineoffset, linelength, linewidth, color, alpha_, \ 

1491 linestyle in \ 

1492 zip(positions, lineoffsets, linelengths, linewidths, 

1493 colors, alpha, linestyles): 

1494 coll = mcoll.EventCollection(position, 

1495 orientation=orientation, 

1496 lineoffset=lineoffset, 

1497 linelength=linelength, 

1498 linewidth=linewidth, 

1499 color=color, 

1500 alpha=alpha_, 

1501 linestyle=linestyle) 

1502 self.add_collection(coll, autolim=False) 

1503 coll._internal_update(kwargs) 

1504 colls.append(coll) 

1505 

1506 if len(positions) > 0: 

1507 # try to get min/max 

1508 min_max = [(np.min(_p), np.max(_p)) for _p in positions 

1509 if len(_p) > 0] 

1510 # if we have any non-empty positions, try to autoscale 

1511 if len(min_max) > 0: 

1512 mins, maxes = zip(*min_max) 

1513 minpos = np.min(mins) 

1514 maxpos = np.max(maxes) 

1515 

1516 minline = (lineoffsets - linelengths).min() 

1517 maxline = (lineoffsets + linelengths).max() 

1518 

1519 if orientation == "vertical": 

1520 corners = (minline, minpos), (maxline, maxpos) 

1521 else: # "horizontal" 

1522 corners = (minpos, minline), (maxpos, maxline) 

1523 self.update_datalim(corners) 

1524 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1525 

1526 return colls 

1527 

1528 #### Basic plotting 

1529 

1530 # Uses a custom implementation of data-kwarg handling in 

1531 # _process_plot_var_args. 

1532 @_docstring.interpd 

1533 def plot(self, *args, scalex=True, scaley=True, data=None, **kwargs): 

1534 """ 

1535 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers. 

1536 

1537 Call signatures:: 

1538 

1539 plot([x], y, [fmt], *, data=None, **kwargs) 

1540 plot([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1541 

1542 The coordinates of the points or line nodes are given by *x*, *y*. 

1543 

1544 The optional parameter *fmt* is a convenient way for defining basic 

1545 formatting like color, marker and linestyle. It's a shortcut string 

1546 notation described in the *Notes* section below. 

1547 

1548 >>> plot(x, y) # plot x and y using default line style and color 

1549 >>> plot(x, y, 'bo') # plot x and y using blue circle markers 

1550 >>> plot(y) # plot y using x as index array 0..N-1 

1551 >>> plot(y, 'r+') # ditto, but with red plusses 

1552 

1553 You can use `.Line2D` properties as keyword arguments for more 

1554 control on the appearance. Line properties and *fmt* can be mixed. 

1555 The following two calls yield identical results: 

1556 

1557 >>> plot(x, y, 'go--', linewidth=2, markersize=12) 

1558 >>> plot(x, y, color='green', marker='o', linestyle='dashed', 

1559 ... linewidth=2, markersize=12) 

1560 

1561 When conflicting with *fmt*, keyword arguments take precedence. 

1562 

1563 

1564 **Plotting labelled data** 

1565 

1566 There's a convenient way for plotting objects with labelled data (i.e. 

1567 data that can be accessed by index ``obj['y']``). Instead of giving 

1568 the data in *x* and *y*, you can provide the object in the *data* 

1569 parameter and just give the labels for *x* and *y*:: 

1570 

1571 >>> plot('xlabel', 'ylabel', data=obj) 

1572 

1573 All indexable objects are supported. This could e.g. be a `dict`, a 

1574 `pandas.DataFrame` or a structured numpy array. 

1575 

1576 

1577 **Plotting multiple sets of data** 

1578 

1579 There are various ways to plot multiple sets of data. 

1580 

1581 - The most straight forward way is just to call `plot` multiple times. 

1582 Example: 

1583 

1584 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'bo') 

1585 >>> plot(x2, y2, 'go') 

1586 

1587 - If *x* and/or *y* are 2D arrays, a separate data set will be drawn 

1588 for every column. If both *x* and *y* are 2D, they must have the 

1589 same shape. If only one of them is 2D with shape (N, m) the other 

1590 must have length N and will be used for every data set m. 

1591 

1592 Example: 

1593 

1594 >>> x = [1, 2, 3] 

1595 >>> y = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]) 

1596 >>> plot(x, y) 

1597 

1598 is equivalent to: 

1599 

1600 >>> for col in range(y.shape[1]): 

1601 ... plot(x, y[:, col]) 

1602 

1603 - The third way is to specify multiple sets of *[x]*, *y*, *[fmt]* 

1604 groups:: 

1605 

1606 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'g^', x2, y2, 'g-') 

1607 

1608 In this case, any additional keyword argument applies to all 

1609 datasets. Also, this syntax cannot be combined with the *data* 

1610 parameter. 

1611 

1612 By default, each line is assigned a different style specified by a 

1613 'style cycle'. The *fmt* and line property parameters are only 

1614 necessary if you want explicit deviations from these defaults. 

1615 Alternatively, you can also change the style cycle using 

1616 :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`. 

1617 

1618 

1619 Parameters 

1620 ---------- 

1621 x, y : array-like or float 

1622 The horizontal / vertical coordinates of the data points. 

1623 *x* values are optional and default to ``range(len(y))``. 

1624 

1625 Commonly, these parameters are 1D arrays. 

1626 

1627 They can also be scalars, or two-dimensional (in that case, the 

1628 columns represent separate data sets). 

1629 

1630 These arguments cannot be passed as keywords. 

1631 

1632 fmt : str, optional 

1633 A format string, e.g. 'ro' for red circles. See the *Notes* 

1634 section for a full description of the format strings. 

1635 

1636 Format strings are just an abbreviation for quickly setting 

1637 basic line properties. All of these and more can also be 

1638 controlled by keyword arguments. 

1639 

1640 This argument cannot be passed as keyword. 

1641 

1642 data : indexable object, optional 

1643 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to 

1644 plot in *x* and *y*. 

1645 

1646 .. note:: 

1647 Technically there's a slight ambiguity in calls where the 

1648 second label is a valid *fmt*. ``plot('n', 'o', data=obj)`` 

1649 could be ``plt(x, y)`` or ``plt(y, fmt)``. In such cases, 

1650 the former interpretation is chosen, but a warning is issued. 

1651 You may suppress the warning by adding an empty format string 

1652 ``plot('n', 'o', '', data=obj)``. 

1653 

1654 Returns 

1655 ------- 

1656 list of `.Line2D` 

1657 A list of lines representing the plotted data. 

1658 

1659 Other Parameters 

1660 ---------------- 

1661 scalex, scaley : bool, default: True 

1662 These parameters determine if the view limits are adapted to the 

1663 data limits. The values are passed on to 

1664 `~.axes.Axes.autoscale_view`. 

1665 

1666 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` properties, optional 

1667 *kwargs* are used to specify properties like a line label (for 

1668 auto legends), linewidth, antialiasing, marker face color. 

1669 Example:: 

1670 

1671 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3], 'go-', label='line 1', linewidth=2) 

1672 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9], 'rs', label='line 2') 

1673 

1674 If you specify multiple lines with one plot call, the kwargs apply 

1675 to all those lines. In case the label object is iterable, each 

1676 element is used as labels for each set of data. 

1677 

1678 Here is a list of available `.Line2D` properties: 

1679 

1680 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

1681 

1682 See Also 

1683 -------- 

1684 scatter : XY scatter plot with markers of varying size and/or color ( 

1685 sometimes also called bubble chart). 

1686 

1687 Notes 

1688 ----- 

1689 **Format Strings** 

1690 

1691 A format string consists of a part for color, marker and line:: 

1692 

1693 fmt = '[marker][line][color]' 

1694 

1695 Each of them is optional. If not provided, the value from the style 

1696 cycle is used. Exception: If ``line`` is given, but no ``marker``, 

1697 the data will be a line without markers. 

1698 

1699 Other combinations such as ``[color][marker][line]`` are also 

1700 supported, but note that their parsing may be ambiguous. 

1701 

1702 **Markers** 

1703 

1704 ============= =============================== 

1705 character description 

1706 ============= =============================== 

1707 ``'.'`` point marker 

1708 ``','`` pixel marker 

1709 ``'o'`` circle marker 

1710 ``'v'`` triangle_down marker 

1711 ``'^'`` triangle_up marker 

1712 ``'<'`` triangle_left marker 

1713 ``'>'`` triangle_right marker 

1714 ``'1'`` tri_down marker 

1715 ``'2'`` tri_up marker 

1716 ``'3'`` tri_left marker 

1717 ``'4'`` tri_right marker 

1718 ``'8'`` octagon marker 

1719 ``'s'`` square marker 

1720 ``'p'`` pentagon marker 

1721 ``'P'`` plus (filled) marker 

1722 ``'*'`` star marker 

1723 ``'h'`` hexagon1 marker 

1724 ``'H'`` hexagon2 marker 

1725 ``'+'`` plus marker 

1726 ``'x'`` x marker 

1727 ``'X'`` x (filled) marker 

1728 ``'D'`` diamond marker 

1729 ``'d'`` thin_diamond marker 

1730 ``'|'`` vline marker 

1731 ``'_'`` hline marker 

1732 ============= =============================== 

1733 

1734 **Line Styles** 

1735 

1736 ============= =============================== 

1737 character description 

1738 ============= =============================== 

1739 ``'-'`` solid line style 

1740 ``'--'`` dashed line style 

1741 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line style 

1742 ``':'`` dotted line style 

1743 ============= =============================== 

1744 

1745 Example format strings:: 

1746 

1747 'b' # blue markers with default shape 

1748 'or' # red circles 

1749 '-g' # green solid line 

1750 '--' # dashed line with default color 

1751 '^k:' # black triangle_up markers connected by a dotted line 

1752 

1753 **Colors** 

1754 

1755 The supported color abbreviations are the single letter codes 

1756 

1757 ============= =============================== 

1758 character color 

1759 ============= =============================== 

1760 ``'b'`` blue 

1761 ``'g'`` green 

1762 ``'r'`` red 

1763 ``'c'`` cyan 

1764 ``'m'`` magenta 

1765 ``'y'`` yellow 

1766 ``'k'`` black 

1767 ``'w'`` white 

1768 ============= =============================== 

1769 

1770 and the ``'CN'`` colors that index into the default property cycle. 

1771 

1772 If the color is the only part of the format string, you can 

1773 additionally use any `matplotlib.colors` spec, e.g. full names 

1774 (``'green'``) or hex strings (``'#008000'``). 

1775 """ 

1776 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D) 

1777 lines = [*self._get_lines(self, *args, data=data, **kwargs)] 

1778 for line in lines: 

1779 self.add_line(line) 

1780 if scalex: 

1781 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

1782 if scaley: 

1783 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

1784 return lines 

1785 

1786 @_api.deprecated("3.9", alternative="plot") 

1787 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

1788 @_docstring.interpd 

1789 def plot_date(self, x, y, fmt='o', tz=None, xdate=True, ydate=False, 

1790 **kwargs): 

1791 """ 

1792 Plot coercing the axis to treat floats as dates. 

1793 

1794 .. deprecated:: 3.9 

1795 

1796 This method exists for historic reasons and will be removed in version 3.11. 

1797 

1798 - ``datetime``-like data should directly be plotted using 

1799 `~.Axes.plot`. 

1800 - If you need to plot plain numeric data as :ref:`date-format` or 

1801 need to set a timezone, call ``ax.xaxis.axis_date`` / 

1802 ``ax.yaxis.axis_date`` before `~.Axes.plot`. See 

1803 `.Axis.axis_date`. 

1804 

1805 Similar to `.plot`, this plots *y* vs. *x* as lines or markers. 

1806 However, the axis labels are formatted as dates depending on *xdate* 

1807 and *ydate*. Note that `.plot` will work with `datetime` and 

1808 `numpy.datetime64` objects without resorting to this method. 

1809 

1810 Parameters 

1811 ---------- 

1812 x, y : array-like 

1813 The coordinates of the data points. If *xdate* or *ydate* is 

1814 *True*, the respective values *x* or *y* are interpreted as 

1815 :ref:`Matplotlib dates <date-format>`. 

1816 

1817 fmt : str, optional 

1818 The plot format string. For details, see the corresponding 

1819 parameter in `.plot`. 

1820 

1821 tz : timezone string or `datetime.tzinfo`, default: :rc:`timezone` 

1822 The time zone to use in labeling dates. 

1823 

1824 xdate : bool, default: True 

1825 If *True*, the *x*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates. 

1826 

1827 ydate : bool, default: False 

1828 If *True*, the *y*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates. 

1829 

1830 Returns 

1831 ------- 

1832 list of `.Line2D` 

1833 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1834 

1835 Other Parameters 

1836 ---------------- 

1837 data : indexable object, optional 

1838 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1839 **kwargs 

1840 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

1841 

1842 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

1843 

1844 See Also 

1845 -------- 

1846 matplotlib.dates : Helper functions on dates. 

1847 matplotlib.dates.date2num : Convert dates to num. 

1848 matplotlib.dates.num2date : Convert num to dates. 

1849 matplotlib.dates.drange : Create an equally spaced sequence of dates. 

1850 

1851 Notes 

1852 ----- 

1853 If you are using custom date tickers and formatters, it may be 

1854 necessary to set the formatters/locators after the call to 

1855 `.plot_date`. `.plot_date` will set the default tick locator to 

1856 `.AutoDateLocator` (if the tick locator is not already set to a 

1857 `.DateLocator` instance) and the default tick formatter to 

1858 `.AutoDateFormatter` (if the tick formatter is not already set to a 

1859 `.DateFormatter` instance). 

1860 """ 

1861 if xdate: 

1862 self.xaxis_date(tz) 

1863 if ydate: 

1864 self.yaxis_date(tz) 

1865 return self.plot(x, y, fmt, **kwargs) 

1866 

1867 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1868 @_docstring.interpd 

1869 def loglog(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1870 """ 

1871 Make a plot with log scaling on both the x- and y-axis. 

1872 

1873 Call signatures:: 

1874 

1875 loglog([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1876 loglog([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1877 

1878 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1879 both the x-axis and the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and 

1880 parameters of plot can be used here as well. 

1881 

1882 The additional parameters *base*, *subs* and *nonpositive* control the 

1883 x/y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale` and 

1884 `.Axes.set_yscale`. To use different properties on the x-axis and the 

1885 y-axis, use e.g. 

1886 ``ax.set_xscale("log", base=10); ax.set_yscale("log", base=2)``. 

1887 

1888 Parameters 

1889 ---------- 

1890 base : float, default: 10 

1891 Base of the logarithm. 

1892 

1893 subs : sequence, optional 

1894 The location of the minor ticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1895 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1896 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale`/`.Axes.set_yscale` for details. 

1897 

1898 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip' 

1899 Non-positive values can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a very 

1900 small positive number. 

1901 

1902 **kwargs 

1903 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

1904 

1905 Returns 

1906 ------- 

1907 list of `.Line2D` 

1908 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1909 """ 

1910 dx = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1911 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1912 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']} 

1913 self.set_xscale('log', **dx) 

1914 dy = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1915 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1916 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']} 

1917 self.set_yscale('log', **dy) 

1918 return self.plot( 

1919 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in {*dx, *dy}}) 

1920 

1921 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1922 @_docstring.interpd 

1923 def semilogx(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1924 """ 

1925 Make a plot with log scaling on the x-axis. 

1926 

1927 Call signatures:: 

1928 

1929 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1930 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1931 

1932 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1933 the x-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can 

1934 be used here as well. 

1935 

1936 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the 

1937 x-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale`. 

1938 

1939 Parameters 

1940 ---------- 

1941 base : float, default: 10 

1942 Base of the x logarithm. 

1943 

1944 subs : array-like, optional 

1945 The location of the minor xticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1946 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1947 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale` for details. 

1948 

1949 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip' 

1950 Non-positive values in x can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a 

1951 very small positive number. 

1952 

1953 **kwargs 

1954 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

1955 

1956 Returns 

1957 ------- 

1958 list of `.Line2D` 

1959 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1960 """ 

1961 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1962 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1963 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']} 

1964 self.set_xscale('log', **d) 

1965 return self.plot( 

1966 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d}) 

1967 

1968 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1969 @_docstring.interpd 

1970 def semilogy(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1971 """ 

1972 Make a plot with log scaling on the y-axis. 

1973 

1974 Call signatures:: 

1975 

1976 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1977 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1978 

1979 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1980 the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can 

1981 be used here as well. 

1982 

1983 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the 

1984 y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_yscale`. 

1985 

1986 Parameters 

1987 ---------- 

1988 base : float, default: 10 

1989 Base of the y logarithm. 

1990 

1991 subs : array-like, optional 

1992 The location of the minor yticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1993 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1994 plot. See `.Axes.set_yscale` for details. 

1995 

1996 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'clip' 

1997 Non-positive values in y can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a 

1998 very small positive number. 

1999 

2000 **kwargs 

2001 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

2002 

2003 Returns 

2004 ------- 

2005 list of `.Line2D` 

2006 Objects representing the plotted data. 

2007 """ 

2008 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

2009 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

2010 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']} 

2011 self.set_yscale('log', **d) 

2012 return self.plot( 

2013 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d}) 

2014 

2015 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"], label_namer="x") 

2016 def acorr(self, x, **kwargs): 

2017 """ 

2018 Plot the autocorrelation of *x*. 

2019 

2020 Parameters 

2021 ---------- 

2022 x : array-like 

2023 Not run through Matplotlib's unit conversion, so this should 

2024 be a unit-less array. 

2025 

2026 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending) 

2027 A detrending function applied to *x*. It must have the 

2028 signature :: 

2029 

2030 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray 

2031 

2032 normed : bool, default: True 

2033 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length. 

2034 

2035 usevlines : bool, default: True 

2036 Determines the plot style. 

2037 

2038 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the acorr value 

2039 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted 

2040 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`. 

2041 

2042 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the acorr values using 

2043 `.Axes.plot`. 

2044 

2045 maxlags : int, default: 10 

2046 Number of lags to show. If ``None``, will return all 

2047 ``2 * len(x) - 1`` lags. 

2048 

2049 Returns 

2050 ------- 

2051 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2052 The lag vector. 

2053 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2054 The auto correlation vector. 

2055 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D` 

2056 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation: 

2057 

2058 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True. 

2059 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False. 

2060 b : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` or None 

2061 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True 

2062 None *usevlines* is False. 

2063 

2064 Other Parameters 

2065 ---------------- 

2066 linestyle : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` property, optional 

2067 The linestyle for plotting the data points. 

2068 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2069 

2070 marker : str, default: 'o' 

2071 The marker for plotting the data points. 

2072 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2073 

2074 data : indexable object, optional 

2075 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

2076 

2077 **kwargs 

2078 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and 

2079 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are 

2080 passed to `.Axes.plot`. 

2081 

2082 Notes 

2083 ----- 

2084 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with 

2085 ``mode = "full"``. 

2086 """ 

2087 return self.xcorr(x, x, **kwargs) 

2088 

2089 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "normed") 

2090 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

2091 def xcorr(self, x, y, normed=True, detrend=mlab.detrend_none, 

2092 usevlines=True, maxlags=10, **kwargs): 

2093 r""" 

2094 Plot the cross correlation between *x* and *y*. 

2095 

2096 The correlation with lag k is defined as 

2097 :math:`\sum_n x[n+k] \cdot y^*[n]`, where :math:`y^*` is the complex 

2098 conjugate of :math:`y`. 

2099 

2100 Parameters 

2101 ---------- 

2102 x, y : array-like of length n 

2103 Neither *x* nor *y* are run through Matplotlib's unit conversion, so 

2104 these should be unit-less arrays. 

2105 

2106 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending) 

2107 A detrending function applied to *x* and *y*. It must have the 

2108 signature :: 

2109 

2110 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray 

2111 

2112 normed : bool, default: True 

2113 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length. 

2114 

2115 usevlines : bool, default: True 

2116 Determines the plot style. 

2117 

2118 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the xcorr value 

2119 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted 

2120 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`. 

2121 

2122 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the xcorr values using 

2123 `.Axes.plot`. 

2124 

2125 maxlags : int, default: 10 

2126 Number of lags to show. If None, will return all ``2 * len(x) - 1`` 

2127 lags. 

2128 

2129 Returns 

2130 ------- 

2131 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2132 The lag vector. 

2133 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2134 The auto correlation vector. 

2135 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D` 

2136 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation: 

2137 

2138 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True. 

2139 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False. 

2140 b : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` or None 

2141 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True 

2142 None *usevlines* is False. 

2143 

2144 Other Parameters 

2145 ---------------- 

2146 linestyle : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` property, optional 

2147 The linestyle for plotting the data points. 

2148 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2149 

2150 marker : str, default: 'o' 

2151 The marker for plotting the data points. 

2152 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2153 

2154 data : indexable object, optional 

2155 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

2156 

2157 **kwargs 

2158 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and 

2159 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are 

2160 passed to `.Axes.plot`. 

2161 

2162 Notes 

2163 ----- 

2164 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with 

2165 ``mode = "full"``. 

2166 """ 

2167 Nx = len(x) 

2168 if Nx != len(y): 

2169 raise ValueError('x and y must be equal length') 

2170 

2171 x = detrend(np.asarray(x)) 

2172 y = detrend(np.asarray(y)) 

2173 

2174 correls = np.correlate(x, y, mode="full") 

2175 

2176 if normed: 

2177 correls = correls / np.sqrt(np.dot(x, x) * np.dot(y, y)) 

2178 

2179 if maxlags is None: 

2180 maxlags = Nx - 1 

2181 

2182 if maxlags >= Nx or maxlags < 1: 

2183 raise ValueError('maxlags must be None or strictly ' 

2184 'positive < %d' % Nx) 

2185 

2186 lags = np.arange(-maxlags, maxlags + 1) 

2187 correls = correls[Nx - 1 - maxlags:Nx + maxlags] 

2188 

2189 if usevlines: 

2190 a = self.vlines(lags, [0], correls, **kwargs) 

2191 # Make label empty so only vertical lines get a legend entry 

2192 kwargs.pop('label', '') 

2193 b = self.axhline(**kwargs) 

2194 else: 

2195 kwargs.setdefault('marker', 'o') 

2196 kwargs.setdefault('linestyle', 'None') 

2197 a, = self.plot(lags, correls, **kwargs) 

2198 b = None 

2199 return lags, correls, a, b 

2200 

2201 #### Specialized plotting 

2202 

2203 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

2204 def step(self, x, y, *args, where='pre', data=None, **kwargs): 

2205 """ 

2206 Make a step plot. 

2207 

2208 Call signatures:: 

2209 

2210 step(x, y, [fmt], *, data=None, where='pre', **kwargs) 

2211 step(x, y, [fmt], x2, y2, [fmt2], ..., *, where='pre', **kwargs) 

2212 

2213 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which changes some 

2214 formatting options. Most of the concepts and parameters of plot can be 

2215 used here as well. 

2216 

2217 .. note:: 

2218 

2219 This method uses a standard plot with a step drawstyle: The *x* 

2220 values are the reference positions and steps extend left/right/both 

2221 directions depending on *where*. 

2222 

2223 For the common case where you know the values and edges of the 

2224 steps, use `~.Axes.stairs` instead. 

2225 

2226 Parameters 

2227 ---------- 

2228 x : array-like 

2229 1D sequence of x positions. It is assumed, but not checked, that 

2230 it is uniformly increasing. 

2231 

2232 y : array-like 

2233 1D sequence of y levels. 

2234 

2235 fmt : str, optional 

2236 A format string, e.g. 'g' for a green line. See `.plot` for a more 

2237 detailed description. 

2238 

2239 Note: While full format strings are accepted, it is recommended to 

2240 only specify the color. Line styles are currently ignored (use 

2241 the keyword argument *linestyle* instead). Markers are accepted 

2242 and plotted on the given positions, however, this is a rarely 

2243 needed feature for step plots. 

2244 

2245 where : {'pre', 'post', 'mid'}, default: 'pre' 

2246 Define where the steps should be placed: 

2247 

2248 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from 

2249 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the 

2250 value ``y[i]``. 

2251 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from 

2252 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the 

2253 value ``y[i]``. 

2254 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions. 

2255 

2256 data : indexable object, optional 

2257 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to 

2258 plot in *x* and *y*. 

2259 

2260 **kwargs 

2261 Additional parameters are the same as those for `.plot`. 

2262 

2263 Returns 

2264 ------- 

2265 list of `.Line2D` 

2266 Objects representing the plotted data. 

2267 """ 

2268 _api.check_in_list(('pre', 'post', 'mid'), where=where) 

2269 kwargs['drawstyle'] = 'steps-' + where 

2270 return self.plot(x, y, *args, data=data, **kwargs) 

2271 

2272 @staticmethod 

2273 def _convert_dx(dx, x0, xconv, convert): 

2274 """ 

2275 Small helper to do logic of width conversion flexibly. 

2276 

2277 *dx* and *x0* have units, but *xconv* has already been converted 

2278 to unitless (and is an ndarray). This allows the *dx* to have units 

2279 that are different from *x0*, but are still accepted by the 

2280 ``__add__`` operator of *x0*. 

2281 """ 

2282 

2283 # x should be an array... 

2284 assert type(xconv) is np.ndarray 

2285 

2286 if xconv.size == 0: 

2287 # xconv has already been converted, but maybe empty... 

2288 return convert(dx) 

2289 

2290 try: 

2291 # attempt to add the width to x0; this works for 

2292 # datetime+timedelta, for instance 

2293 

2294 # only use the first element of x and x0. This saves
