2295 # having to be sure addition works across the whole 

2296 # vector. This is particularly an issue if 

2297 # x0 and dx are lists so x0 + dx just concatenates the lists. 

2298 # We can't just cast x0 and dx to numpy arrays because that 

2299 # removes the units from unit packages like `pint` that 

2300 # wrap numpy arrays. 

2301 try: 

2302 x0 = cbook._safe_first_finite(x0) 

2303 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError): 

2304 pass 

2305 

2306 try: 

2307 x = cbook._safe_first_finite(xconv) 

2308 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError): 

2309 x = xconv 

2310 

2311 delist = False 

2312 if not np.iterable(dx): 

2313 dx = [dx] 

2314 delist = True 

2315 dx = [convert(x0 + ddx) - x for ddx in dx] 

2316 if delist: 

2317 dx = dx[0] 

2318 except (ValueError, TypeError, AttributeError): 

2319 # if the above fails (for any reason) just fallback to what 

2320 # we do by default and convert dx by itself. 

2321 dx = convert(dx) 

2322 return dx 

2323 

2324 def _parse_bar_color_args(self, kwargs): 

2325 """ 

2326 Helper function to process color-related arguments of `.Axes.bar`. 

2327 

2328 Argument precedence for facecolors: 

2329 

2330 - kwargs['facecolor'] 

2331 - kwargs['color'] 

2332 - 'Result of ``self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color`` 

2333 

2334 Argument precedence for edgecolors: 

2335 

2336 - kwargs['edgecolor'] 

2337 - None 

2338 

2339 Parameters 

2340 ---------- 

2341 self : Axes 

2342 

2343 kwargs : dict 

2344 Additional kwargs. If these keys exist, we pop and process them: 

2345 'facecolor', 'edgecolor', 'color' 

2346 Note: The dict is modified by this function. 

2347 

2348 

2349 Returns 

2350 ------- 

2351 facecolor 

2352 The facecolor. One or more colors as (N, 4) rgba array. 

2353 edgecolor 

2354 The edgecolor. Not normalized; may be any valid color spec or None. 

2355 """ 

2356 color = kwargs.pop('color', None) 

2357 

2358 facecolor = kwargs.pop('facecolor', color) 

2359 edgecolor = kwargs.pop('edgecolor', None) 

2360 

2361 facecolor = (facecolor if facecolor is not None 

2362 else self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color()) 

2363 

2364 try: 

2365 facecolor = mcolors.to_rgba_array(facecolor) 

2366 except ValueError as err: 

2367 raise ValueError( 

2368 "'facecolor' or 'color' argument must be a valid color or" 

2369 "sequence of colors." 

2370 ) from err 

2371 

2372 return facecolor, edgecolor 

2373 

2374 @_preprocess_data() 

2375 @_docstring.interpd 

2376 def bar(self, x, height, width=0.8, bottom=None, *, align="center", 

2377 **kwargs): 

2378 r""" 

2379 Make a bar plot. 

2380 

2381 The bars are positioned at *x* with the given *align*\ment. Their 

2382 dimensions are given by *height* and *width*. The vertical baseline 

2383 is *bottom* (default 0). 

2384 

2385 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars 

2386 or a sequence of values, one for each bar. 

2387 

2388 Parameters 

2389 ---------- 

2390 x : float or array-like 

2391 The x coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the 

2392 alignment of the bars to the coordinates. 

2393 

2394 Bars are often used for categorical data, i.e. string labels below 

2395 the bars. You can provide a list of strings directly to *x*. 

2396 ``bar(['A', 'B', 'C'], [1, 2, 3])`` is often a shorter and more 

2397 convenient notation compared to 

2398 ``bar(range(3), [1, 2, 3], tick_label=['A', 'B', 'C'])``. They are 

2399 equivalent as long as the names are unique. The explicit *tick_label* 

2400 notation draws the names in the sequence given. However, when having 

2401 duplicate values in categorical *x* data, these values map to the same 

2402 numerical x coordinate, and hence the corresponding bars are drawn on 

2403 top of each other. 

2404 

2405 height : float or array-like 

2406 The height(s) of the bars. 

2407 

2408 Note that if *bottom* has units (e.g. datetime), *height* should be in 

2409 units that are a difference from the value of *bottom* (e.g. timedelta). 

2410 

2411 width : float or array-like, default: 0.8 

2412 The width(s) of the bars. 

2413 

2414 Note that if *x* has units (e.g. datetime), then *width* should be in 

2415 units that are a difference (e.g. timedelta) around the *x* values. 

2416 

2417 bottom : float or array-like, default: 0 

2418 The y coordinate(s) of the bottom side(s) of the bars. 

2419 

2420 Note that if *bottom* has units, then the y-axis will get a Locator and 

2421 Formatter appropriate for the units (e.g. dates, or categorical). 

2422 

2423 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center' 

2424 Alignment of the bars to the *x* coordinates: 

2425 

2426 - 'center': Center the base on the *x* positions. 

2427 - 'edge': Align the left edges of the bars with the *x* positions. 

2428 

2429 To align the bars on the right edge pass a negative *width* and 

2430 ``align='edge'``. 

2431 

2432 Returns 

2433 ------- 

2434 `.BarContainer` 

2435 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars. 

2436 

2437 Other Parameters 

2438 ---------------- 

2439 color : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, optional 

2440 The colors of the bar faces. This is an alias for *facecolor*. 

2441 If both are given, *facecolor* takes precedence. 

2442 

2443 facecolor : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, optional 

2444 The colors of the bar faces. 

2445 If both *color* and *facecolor are given, *facecolor* takes precedence. 

2446 

2447 edgecolor : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, optional 

2448 The colors of the bar edges. 

2449 

2450 linewidth : float or array-like, optional 

2451 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges. 

2452 

2453 tick_label : str or list of str, optional 

2454 The tick labels of the bars. 

2455 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.) 

2456 

2457 label : str or list of str, optional 

2458 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a 

2459 label for the whole dataset. 

2460 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *x* and 

2461 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated 

2462 and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when 

2463 bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.) 

2464 

2465 xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional 

2466 If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips. 

2467 The values are +/- sizes relative to the data: 

2468 

2469 - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars 

2470 - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar 

2471 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row 

2472 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper 

2473 errors. 

2474 - *None*: No errorbar. (Default) 

2475 

2476 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on 

2477 the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*. 

2478 

2479 ecolor : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, default: 'black' 

2480 The line color of the errorbars. 

2481 

2482 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize` 

2483 The length of the error bar caps in points. 

2484 

2485 error_kw : dict, optional 

2486 Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the 

2487 `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined 

2488 here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments. 

2489 

2490 log : bool, default: False 

2491 If *True*, set the y-axis to be log scale. 

2492 

2493 data : indexable object, optional 

2494 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

2495 

2496 **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties 

2497 

2498 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

2499 

2500 See Also 

2501 -------- 

2502 barh : Plot a horizontal bar plot. 

2503 

2504 Notes 

2505 ----- 

2506 Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *bottom* values per 

2507 bar. See :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_stacked`. 

2508 """ 

2509 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mpatches.Patch) 

2510 facecolor, edgecolor = self._parse_bar_color_args(kwargs) 

2511 

2512 linewidth = kwargs.pop('linewidth', None) 

2513 hatch = kwargs.pop('hatch', None) 

2514 

2515 # Because xerr and yerr will be passed to errorbar, most dimension 

2516 # checking and processing will be left to the errorbar method. 

2517 xerr = kwargs.pop('xerr', None) 

2518 yerr = kwargs.pop('yerr', None) 

2519 error_kw = kwargs.pop('error_kw', None) 

2520 error_kw = {} if error_kw is None else error_kw.copy() 

2521 ezorder = error_kw.pop('zorder', None) 

2522 if ezorder is None: 

2523 ezorder = kwargs.get('zorder', None) 

2524 if ezorder is not None: 

2525 # If using the bar zorder, increment slightly to make sure 

2526 # errorbars are drawn on top of bars 

2527 ezorder += 0.01 

2528 error_kw.setdefault('zorder', ezorder) 

2529 ecolor = kwargs.pop('ecolor', 'k') 

2530 capsize = kwargs.pop('capsize', mpl.rcParams["errorbar.capsize"]) 

2531 error_kw.setdefault('ecolor', ecolor) 

2532 error_kw.setdefault('capsize', capsize) 

2533 

2534 # The keyword argument *orientation* is used by barh() to defer all 

2535 # logic and drawing to bar(). It is considered internal and is 

2536 # intentionally not mentioned in the docstring. 

2537 orientation = kwargs.pop('orientation', 'vertical') 

2538 _api.check_in_list(['vertical', 'horizontal'], orientation=orientation) 

2539 log = kwargs.pop('log', False) 

2540 label = kwargs.pop('label', '') 

2541 tick_labels = kwargs.pop('tick_label', None) 

2542 

2543 y = bottom # Matches barh call signature. 

2544 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2545 if y is None: 

2546 y = 0 

2547 else: # horizontal 

2548 if x is None: 

2549 x = 0 

2550 

2551 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2552 # It is possible for y (bottom) to contain unit information. 

2553 # However, it is also possible for y=0 for the default and height 

2554 # to contain unit information. This will prioritize the units of y. 

2555 self._process_unit_info( 

2556 [("x", x), ("y", y), ("y", height)], kwargs, convert=False) 

2557 if log: 

2558 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

2559 else: # horizontal 

2560 # It is possible for x (left) to contain unit information. 

2561 # However, it is also possible for x=0 for the default and width 

2562 # to contain unit information. This will prioritize the units of x. 

2563 self._process_unit_info( 

2564 [("x", x), ("x", width), ("y", y)], kwargs, convert=False) 

2565 if log: 

2566 self.set_xscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

2567 

2568 # lets do some conversions now since some types cannot be 

2569 # subtracted uniformly 

2570 if self.xaxis is not None: 

2571 x0 = x 

2572 x = np.asarray(self.convert_xunits(x)) 

2573 width = self._convert_dx(width, x0, x, self.convert_xunits) 

2574 if xerr is not None: 

2575 xerr = self._convert_dx(xerr, x0, x, self.convert_xunits) 

2576 if self.yaxis is not None: 

2577 y0 = y 

2578 y = np.asarray(self.convert_yunits(y)) 

2579 height = self._convert_dx(height, y0, y, self.convert_yunits) 

2580 if yerr is not None: 

2581 yerr = self._convert_dx(yerr, y0, y, self.convert_yunits) 

2582 

2583 x, height, width, y, linewidth, hatch = np.broadcast_arrays( 

2584 # Make args iterable too. 

2585 np.atleast_1d(x), height, width, y, linewidth, hatch) 

2586 

2587 # Now that units have been converted, set the tick locations. 

2588 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2589 tick_label_axis = self.xaxis 

2590 tick_label_position = x 

2591 else: # horizontal 

2592 tick_label_axis = self.yaxis 

2593 tick_label_position = y 

2594 

2595 if not isinstance(label, str) and np.iterable(label): 

2596 bar_container_label = '_nolegend_' 

2597 patch_labels = label 

2598 else: 

2599 bar_container_label = label 

2600 patch_labels = ['_nolegend_'] * len(x) 

2601 if len(patch_labels) != len(x): 

2602 raise ValueError(f'number of labels ({len(patch_labels)}) ' 

2603 f'does not match number of bars ({len(x)}).') 

2604 

2605 linewidth = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(linewidth)) 

2606 hatch = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(hatch)) 

2607 facecolor = itertools.chain(itertools.cycle(facecolor), 

2608 # Fallback if color == "none". 

2609 itertools.repeat('none')) 

2610 if edgecolor is None: 

2611 edgecolor = itertools.repeat(None) 

2612 else: 

2613 edgecolor = itertools.chain( 

2614 itertools.cycle(mcolors.to_rgba_array(edgecolor)), 

2615 # Fallback if edgecolor == "none". 

2616 itertools.repeat('none')) 

2617 

2618 # We will now resolve the alignment and really have 

2619 # left, bottom, width, height vectors 

2620 _api.check_in_list(['center', 'edge'], align=align) 

2621 if align == 'center': 

2622 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2623 try: 

2624 left = x - width / 2 

2625 except TypeError as e: 

2626 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters x ({x.dtype}) ' 

2627 f'and width ({width.dtype}) ' 

2628 f'are incompatible') from e 

2629 bottom = y 

2630 else: # horizontal 

2631 try: 

2632 bottom = y - height / 2 

2633 except TypeError as e: 

2634 raise TypeError(f'the dtypes of parameters y ({y.dtype}) ' 

2635 f'and height ({height.dtype}) ' 

2636 f'are incompatible') from e 

2637 left = x 

2638 else: # edge 

2639 left = x 

2640 bottom = y 

2641 

2642 patches = [] 

2643 args = zip(left, bottom, width, height, facecolor, edgecolor, linewidth, 

2644 hatch, patch_labels) 

2645 for l, b, w, h, c, e, lw, htch, lbl in args: 

2646 r = mpatches.Rectangle( 

2647 xy=(l, b), width=w, height=h, 

2648 facecolor=c, 

2649 edgecolor=e, 

2650 linewidth=lw, 

2651 label=lbl, 

2652 hatch=htch, 

2653 ) 

2654 r._internal_update(kwargs) 

2655 r.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100 

2656 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2657 r.sticky_edges.y.append(b) 

2658 else: # horizontal 

2659 r.sticky_edges.x.append(l) 

2660 self.add_patch(r) 

2661 patches.append(r) 

2662 

2663 if xerr is not None or yerr is not None: 

2664 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2665 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info 

2666 ex = [l + 0.5 * w for l, w in zip(left, width)] 

2667 ey = [b + h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)] 

2668 

2669 else: # horizontal 

2670 # using list comps rather than arrays to preserve unit info 

2671 ex = [l + w for l, w in zip(left, width)] 

2672 ey = [b + 0.5 * h for b, h in zip(bottom, height)] 

2673 

2674 error_kw.setdefault("label", '_nolegend_') 

2675 

2676 errorbar = self.errorbar(ex, ey, yerr=yerr, xerr=xerr, fmt='none', 

2677 **error_kw) 

2678 else: 

2679 errorbar = None 

2680 

2681 self._request_autoscale_view() 

2682 

2683 if orientation == 'vertical': 

2684 datavalues = height 

2685 else: # horizontal 

2686 datavalues = width 

2687 

2688 bar_container = BarContainer(patches, errorbar, datavalues=datavalues, 

2689 orientation=orientation, 

2690 label=bar_container_label) 

2691 self.add_container(bar_container) 

2692 

2693 if tick_labels is not None: 

2694 tick_labels = np.broadcast_to(tick_labels, len(patches)) 

2695 tick_label_axis.set_ticks(tick_label_position) 

2696 tick_label_axis.set_ticklabels(tick_labels) 

2697 

2698 return bar_container 

2699 

2700 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'bar' do the unpacking.. 

2701 @_docstring.interpd 

2702 def barh(self, y, width, height=0.8, left=None, *, align="center", 

2703 data=None, **kwargs): 

2704 r""" 

2705 Make a horizontal bar plot. 

2706 

2707 The bars are positioned at *y* with the given *align*\ment. Their 

2708 dimensions are given by *width* and *height*. The horizontal baseline 

2709 is *left* (default 0). 

2710 

2711 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars 

2712 or a sequence of values, one for each bar. 

2713 

2714 Parameters 

2715 ---------- 

2716 y : float or array-like 

2717 The y coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the 

2718 alignment of the bars to the coordinates. 

2719 

2720 Bars are often used for categorical data, i.e. string labels below 

2721 the bars. You can provide a list of strings directly to *y*. 

2722 ``barh(['A', 'B', 'C'], [1, 2, 3])`` is often a shorter and more 

2723 convenient notation compared to 

2724 ``barh(range(3), [1, 2, 3], tick_label=['A', 'B', 'C'])``. They are 

2725 equivalent as long as the names are unique. The explicit *tick_label* 

2726 notation draws the names in the sequence given. However, when having 

2727 duplicate values in categorical *y* data, these values map to the same 

2728 numerical y coordinate, and hence the corresponding bars are drawn on 

2729 top of each other. 

2730 

2731 width : float or array-like 

2732 The width(s) of the bars. 

2733 

2734 Note that if *left* has units (e.g. datetime), *width* should be in 

2735 units that are a difference from the value of *left* (e.g. timedelta). 

2736 

2737 height : float or array-like, default: 0.8 

2738 The heights of the bars. 

2739 

2740 Note that if *y* has units (e.g. datetime), then *height* should be in 

2741 units that are a difference (e.g. timedelta) around the *y* values. 

2742 

2743 left : float or array-like, default: 0 

2744 The x coordinates of the left side(s) of the bars. 

2745 

2746 Note that if *left* has units, then the x-axis will get a Locator and 

2747 Formatter appropriate for the units (e.g. dates, or categorical). 

2748 

2749 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center' 

2750 Alignment of the base to the *y* coordinates*: 

2751 

2752 - 'center': Center the bars on the *y* positions. 

2753 - 'edge': Align the bottom edges of the bars with the *y* 

2754 positions. 

2755 

2756 To align the bars on the top edge pass a negative *height* and 

2757 ``align='edge'``. 

2758 

2759 Returns 

2760 ------- 

2761 `.BarContainer` 

2762 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars. 

2763 

2764 Other Parameters 

2765 ---------------- 

2766 color : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, optional 

2767 The colors of the bar faces. 

2768 

2769 edgecolor : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, optional 

2770 The colors of the bar edges. 

2771 

2772 linewidth : float or array-like, optional 

2773 Width of the bar edge(s). If 0, don't draw edges. 

2774 

2775 tick_label : str or list of str, optional 

2776 The tick labels of the bars. 

2777 Default: None (Use default numeric labels.) 

2778 

2779 label : str or list of str, optional 

2780 A single label is attached to the resulting `.BarContainer` as a 

2781 label for the whole dataset. 

2782 If a list is provided, it must be the same length as *y* and 

2783 labels the individual bars. Repeated labels are not de-duplicated 

2784 and will cause repeated label entries, so this is best used when 

2785 bars also differ in style (e.g., by passing a list to *color*.) 

2786 

2787 xerr, yerr : float or array-like of shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional 

2788 If not *None*, add horizontal / vertical errorbars to the bar tips. 

2789 The values are +/- sizes relative to the data: 

2790 

2791 - scalar: symmetric +/- values for all bars 

2792 - shape(N,): symmetric +/- values for each bar 

2793 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row 

2794 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper 

2795 errors. 

2796 - *None*: No errorbar. (default) 

2797 

2798 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` for an example on 

2799 the usage of *xerr* and *yerr*. 

2800 

2801 ecolor : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, default: 'black' 

2802 The line color of the errorbars. 

2803 

2804 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize` 

2805 The length of the error bar caps in points. 

2806 

2807 error_kw : dict, optional 

2808 Dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the 

2809 `~.Axes.errorbar` method. Values of *ecolor* or *capsize* defined 

2810 here take precedence over the independent keyword arguments. 

2811 

2812 log : bool, default: False 

2813 If ``True``, set the x-axis to be log scale. 

2814 

2815 data : indexable object, optional 

2816 If given, all parameters also accept a string ``s``, which is 

2817 interpreted as ``data[s]`` if ``s`` is a key in ``data``. 

2818 

2819 **kwargs : `.Rectangle` properties 

2820 

2821 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

2822 

2823 See Also 

2824 -------- 

2825 bar : Plot a vertical bar plot. 

2826 

2827 Notes 

2828 ----- 

2829 Stacked bars can be achieved by passing individual *left* values per 

2830 bar. See 

2831 :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/horizontal_barchart_distribution`. 

2832 """ 

2833 kwargs.setdefault('orientation', 'horizontal') 

2834 patches = self.bar(x=left, height=height, width=width, bottom=y, 

2835 align=align, data=data, **kwargs) 

2836 return patches 

2837 

2838 def bar_label(self, container, labels=None, *, fmt="%g", label_type="edge", 

2839 padding=0, **kwargs): 

2840 """ 

2841 Label a bar plot. 

2842 

2843 Adds labels to bars in the given `.BarContainer`. 

2844 You may need to adjust the axis limits to fit the labels. 

2845 

2846 Parameters 

2847 ---------- 

2848 container : `.BarContainer` 

2849 Container with all the bars and optionally errorbars, likely 

2850 returned from `.bar` or `.barh`. 

2851 

2852 labels : array-like, optional 

2853 A list of label texts, that should be displayed. If not given, the 

2854 label texts will be the data values formatted with *fmt*. 

2855 

2856 fmt : str or callable, default: '%g' 

2857 An unnamed %-style or {}-style format string for the label or a 

2858 function to call with the value as the first argument. 

2859 When *fmt* is a string and can be interpreted in both formats, 

2860 %-style takes precedence over {}-style. 

2861 

2862 .. versionadded:: 3.7 

2863 Support for {}-style format string and callables. 

2864 

2865 label_type : {'edge', 'center'}, default: 'edge' 

2866 The label type. Possible values: 

2867 

2868 - 'edge': label placed at the end-point of the bar segment, and the 

2869 value displayed will be the position of that end-point. 

2870 - 'center': label placed in the center of the bar segment, and the 

2871 value displayed will be the length of that segment. 

2872 (useful for stacked bars, i.e., 

2873 :doc:`/gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/bar_label_demo`) 

2874 

2875 padding : float, default: 0 

2876 Distance of label from the end of the bar, in points. 

2877 

2878 **kwargs 

2879 Any remaining keyword arguments are passed through to 

2880 `.Axes.annotate`. The alignment parameters ( 

2881 *horizontalalignment* / *ha*, *verticalalignment* / *va*) are 

2882 not supported because the labels are automatically aligned to 

2883 the bars. 

2884 

2885 Returns 

2886 ------- 

2887 list of `.Annotation` 

2888 A list of `.Annotation` instances for the labels. 

2889 """ 

2890 for key in ['horizontalalignment', 'ha', 'verticalalignment', 'va']: 

2891 if key in kwargs: 

2892 raise ValueError( 

2893 f"Passing {key!r} to bar_label() is not supported.") 

2894 

2895 a, b = self.yaxis.get_view_interval() 

2896 y_inverted = a > b 

2897 c, d = self.xaxis.get_view_interval() 

2898 x_inverted = c > d 

2899 

2900 # want to know whether to put label on positive or negative direction 

2901 # cannot use np.sign here because it will return 0 if x == 0 

2902 def sign(x): 

2903 return 1 if x >= 0 else -1 

2904 

2905 _api.check_in_list(['edge', 'center'], label_type=label_type) 

2906 

2907 bars = container.patches 

2908 errorbar = container.errorbar 

2909 datavalues = container.datavalues 

2910 orientation = container.orientation 

2911 

2912 if errorbar: 

2913 # check "ErrorbarContainer" for the definition of these elements 

2914 lines = errorbar.lines # attribute of "ErrorbarContainer" (tuple) 

2915 barlinecols = lines[2] # 0: data_line, 1: caplines, 2: barlinecols 

2916 barlinecol = barlinecols[0] # the "LineCollection" of error bars 

2917 errs = barlinecol.get_segments() 

2918 else: 

2919 errs = [] 

2920 

2921 if labels is None: 

2922 labels = [] 

2923 

2924 annotations = [] 

2925 

2926 for bar, err, dat, lbl in itertools.zip_longest( 

2927 bars, errs, datavalues, labels 

2928 ): 

2929 (x0, y0), (x1, y1) = bar.get_bbox().get_points() 

2930 xc, yc = (x0 + x1) / 2, (y0 + y1) / 2 

2931 

2932 if orientation == "vertical": 

2933 extrema = max(y0, y1) if dat >= 0 else min(y0, y1) 

2934 length = abs(y0 - y1) 

2935 else: # horizontal 

2936 extrema = max(x0, x1) if dat >= 0 else min(x0, x1) 

2937 length = abs(x0 - x1) 

2938 

2939 if err is None or np.size(err) == 0: 

2940 endpt = extrema 

2941 elif orientation == "vertical": 

2942 endpt = err[:, 1].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 1].min() 

2943 else: # horizontal 

2944 endpt = err[:, 0].max() if dat >= 0 else err[:, 0].min() 

2945 

2946 if label_type == "center": 

2947 value = sign(dat) * length 

2948 else: # edge 

2949 value = extrema 

2950 

2951 if label_type == "center": 

2952 xy = (0.5, 0.5) 

2953 kwargs["xycoords"] = ( 

2954 lambda r, b=bar: 

2955 mtransforms.Bbox.intersection( 

2956 b.get_window_extent(r), b.get_clip_box() 

2957 ) or mtransforms.Bbox.null() 

2958 ) 

2959 else: # edge 

2960 if orientation == "vertical": 

2961 xy = xc, endpt 

2962 else: # horizontal 

2963 xy = endpt, yc 

2964 

2965 if orientation == "vertical": 

2966 y_direction = -1 if y_inverted else 1 

2967 xytext = 0, y_direction * sign(dat) * padding 

2968 else: # horizontal 

2969 x_direction = -1 if x_inverted else 1 

2970 xytext = x_direction * sign(dat) * padding, 0 

2971 

2972 if label_type == "center": 

2973 ha, va = "center", "center" 

2974 else: # edge 

2975 if orientation == "vertical": 

2976 ha = 'center' 

2977 if y_inverted: 

2978 va = 'top' if dat > 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN 

2979 else: 

2980 va = 'top' if dat < 0 else 'bottom' # also handles NaN 

2981 else: # horizontal 

2982 if x_inverted: 

2983 ha = 'right' if dat > 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN 

2984 else: 

2985 ha = 'right' if dat < 0 else 'left' # also handles NaN 

2986 va = 'center' 

2987 

2988 if np.isnan(dat): 

2989 lbl = '' 

2990 

2991 if lbl is None: 

2992 if isinstance(fmt, str): 

2993 lbl = cbook._auto_format_str(fmt, value) 

2994 elif callable(fmt): 

2995 lbl = fmt(value) 

2996 else: 

2997 raise TypeError("fmt must be a str or callable") 

2998 annotation = self.annotate(lbl, 

2999 xy, xytext, textcoords="offset points", 

3000 ha=ha, va=va, **kwargs) 

3001 annotations.append(annotation) 

3002 

3003 return annotations 

3004 

3005 @_preprocess_data() 

3006 @_docstring.interpd 

3007 def broken_barh(self, xranges, yrange, **kwargs): 

3008 """ 

3009 Plot a horizontal sequence of rectangles. 

3010 

3011 A rectangle is drawn for each element of *xranges*. All rectangles 

3012 have the same vertical position and size defined by *yrange*. 

3013 

3014 Parameters 

3015 ---------- 

3016 xranges : sequence of tuples (*xmin*, *xwidth*) 

3017 The x-positions and extents of the rectangles. For each tuple 

3018 (*xmin*, *xwidth*) a rectangle is drawn from *xmin* to *xmin* + 

3019 *xwidth*. 

3020 yrange : (*ymin*, *yheight*) 

3021 The y-position and extent for all the rectangles. 

3022 

3023 Returns 

3024 ------- 

3025 `~.collections.PolyCollection` 

3026 

3027 Other Parameters 

3028 ---------------- 

3029 data : indexable object, optional 

3030 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

3031 **kwargs : `.PolyCollection` properties 

3032 

3033 Each *kwarg* can be either a single argument applying to all 

3034 rectangles, e.g.:: 

3035 

3036 facecolors='black' 

3037 

3038 or a sequence of arguments over which is cycled, e.g.:: 

3039 

3040 facecolors=('black', 'blue') 

3041 

3042 would create interleaving black and blue rectangles. 

3043 

3044 Supported keywords: 

3045 

3046 %(PolyCollection:kwdoc)s 

3047 """ 

3048 # process the unit information 

3049 xdata = cbook._safe_first_finite(xranges) if len(xranges) else None 

3050 ydata = cbook._safe_first_finite(yrange) if len(yrange) else None 

3051 self._process_unit_info( 

3052 [("x", xdata), ("y", ydata)], kwargs, convert=False) 

3053 

3054 vertices = [] 

3055 y0, dy = yrange 

3056 y0, y1 = self.convert_yunits((y0, y0 + dy)) 

3057 for xr in xranges: # convert the absolute values, not the x and dx 

3058 try: 

3059 x0, dx = xr 

3060 except Exception: 

3061 raise ValueError( 

3062 "each range in xrange must be a sequence with two " 

3063 "elements (i.e. xrange must be an (N, 2) array)") from None 

3064 x0, x1 = self.convert_xunits((x0, x0 + dx)) 

3065 vertices.append([(x0, y0), (x0, y1), (x1, y1), (x1, y0)]) 

3066 

3067 col = mcoll.PolyCollection(np.array(vertices), **kwargs) 

3068 self.add_collection(col, autolim=True) 

3069 self._request_autoscale_view() 

3070 

3071 return col 

3072 

3073 @_preprocess_data() 

3074 def stem(self, *args, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None, bottom=0, 

3075 label=None, orientation='vertical'): 

3076 """ 

3077 Create a stem plot. 

3078 

3079 A stem plot draws lines perpendicular to a baseline at each location 

3080 *locs* from the baseline to *heads*, and places a marker there. For 

3081 vertical stem plots (the default), the *locs* are *x* positions, and 

3082 the *heads* are *y* values. For horizontal stem plots, the *locs* are 

3083 *y* positions, and the *heads* are *x* values. 

3084 

3085 Call signature:: 

3086 

3087 stem([locs,] heads, linefmt=None, markerfmt=None, basefmt=None) 

3088 

3089 The *locs*-positions are optional. *linefmt* may be provided as 

3090 positional, but all other formats must be provided as keyword 

3091 arguments. 

3092 

3093 Parameters 

3094 ---------- 

3095 locs : array-like, default: (0, 1, ..., len(heads) - 1) 

3096 For vertical stem plots, the x-positions of the stems. 

3097 For horizontal stem plots, the y-positions of the stems. 

3098 

3099 heads : array-like 

3100 For vertical stem plots, the y-values of the stem heads. 

3101 For horizontal stem plots, the x-values of the stem heads. 

3102 

3103 linefmt : str, optional 

3104 A string defining the color and/or linestyle of the vertical lines: 

3105 

3106 ========= ============= 

3107 Character Line Style 

3108 ========= ============= 

3109 ``'-'`` solid line 

3110 ``'--'`` dashed line 

3111 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line 

3112 ``':'`` dotted line 

3113 ========= ============= 

3114 

3115 Default: 'C0-', i.e. solid line with the first color of the color 

3116 cycle. 

3117 

3118 Note: Markers specified through this parameter (e.g. 'x') will be 

3119 silently ignored. Instead, markers should be specified using 

3120 *markerfmt*. 

3121 

3122 markerfmt : str, optional 

3123 A string defining the color and/or shape of the markers at the stem 

3124 heads. If the marker is not given, use the marker 'o', i.e. filled 

3125 circles. If the color is not given, use the color from *linefmt*. 

3126 

3127 basefmt : str, default: 'C3-' ('C2-' in classic mode) 

3128 A format string defining the properties of the baseline. 

3129 

3130 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

3131 The orientation of the stems. 

3132 

3133 bottom : float, default: 0 

3134 The y/x-position of the baseline (depending on *orientation*). 

3135 

3136 label : str, optional 

3137 The label to use for the stems in legends. 

3138 

3139 data : indexable object, optional 

3140 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

3141 

3142 Returns 

3143 ------- 

3144 `.StemContainer` 

3145 The container may be treated like a tuple 

3146 (*markerline*, *stemlines*, *baseline*) 

3147 

3148 Notes 

3149 ----- 

3150 .. seealso:: 

3151 The MATLAB function 

3152 `stem <https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/stem.html>`_ 

3153 which inspired this method. 

3154 """ 

3155 if not 1 <= len(args) <= 3: 

3156 raise _api.nargs_error('stem', '1-3', len(args)) 

3157 _api.check_in_list(['horizontal', 'vertical'], orientation=orientation) 

3158 

3159 if len(args) == 1: 

3160 heads, = args 

3161 locs = np.arange(len(heads)) 

3162 args = () 

3163 elif isinstance(args[1], str): 

3164 heads, *args = args 

3165 locs = np.arange(len(heads)) 

3166 else: 

3167 locs, heads, *args = args 

3168 

3169 if orientation == 'vertical': 

3170 locs, heads = self._process_unit_info([("x", locs), ("y", heads)]) 

3171 else: # horizontal 

3172 heads, locs = self._process_unit_info([("x", heads), ("y", locs)]) 

3173 

3174 # resolve line format 

3175 if linefmt is None: 

3176 linefmt = args[0] if len(args) > 0 else "C0-" 

3177 linestyle, linemarker, linecolor = _process_plot_format(linefmt) 

3178 

3179 # resolve marker format 

3180 if markerfmt is None: 

3181 # if not given as kwarg, fall back to 'o' 

3182 markerfmt = "o" 

3183 if markerfmt == '': 

3184 markerfmt = ' ' # = empty line style; '' would resolve rcParams 

3185 markerstyle, markermarker, markercolor = \ 

3186 _process_plot_format(markerfmt) 

3187 if markermarker is None: 

3188 markermarker = 'o' 

3189 if markerstyle is None: 

3190 markerstyle = 'None' 

3191 if markercolor is None: 

3192 markercolor = linecolor 

3193 

3194 # resolve baseline format 

3195 if basefmt is None: 

3196 basefmt = ("C2-" if mpl.rcParams["_internal.classic_mode"] else 

3197 "C3-") 

3198 basestyle, basemarker, basecolor = _process_plot_format(basefmt) 

3199 

3200 # New behaviour in 3.1 is to use a LineCollection for the stemlines 

3201 if linestyle is None: 

3202 linestyle = mpl.rcParams['lines.linestyle'] 

3203 xlines = self.vlines if orientation == "vertical" else self.hlines 

3204 stemlines = xlines( 

3205 locs, bottom, heads, 

3206 colors=linecolor, linestyles=linestyle, label="_nolegend_") 

3207 

3208 if orientation == 'horizontal': 

3209 marker_x = heads 

3210 marker_y = locs 

3211 baseline_x = [bottom, bottom] 

3212 baseline_y = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)] 

3213 else: 

3214 marker_x = locs 

3215 marker_y = heads 

3216 baseline_x = [np.min(locs), np.max(locs)] 

3217 baseline_y = [bottom, bottom] 

3218 

3219 markerline, = self.plot(marker_x, marker_y, 

3220 color=markercolor, linestyle=markerstyle, 

3221 marker=markermarker, label="_nolegend_") 

3222 

3223 baseline, = self.plot(baseline_x, baseline_y, 

3224 color=basecolor, linestyle=basestyle, 

3225 marker=basemarker, label="_nolegend_") 

3226 

3227 stem_container = StemContainer((markerline, stemlines, baseline), 

3228 label=label) 

3229 self.add_container(stem_container) 

3230 return stem_container 

3231 

3232 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "explode") 

3233 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "explode", "labels", "colors"]) 

3234 def pie(self, x, explode=None, labels=None, colors=None, 

3235 autopct=None, pctdistance=0.6, shadow=False, labeldistance=1.1, 

3236 startangle=0, radius=1, counterclock=True, 

3237 wedgeprops=None, textprops=None, center=(0, 0), 

3238 frame=False, rotatelabels=False, *, normalize=True, hatch=None): 

3239 """ 

3240 Plot a pie chart. 

3241 

3242 Make a pie chart of array *x*. The fractional area of each wedge is 

3243 given by ``x/sum(x)``. 

3244 

3245 The wedges are plotted counterclockwise, by default starting from the 

3246 x-axis. 

3247 

3248 Parameters 

3249 ---------- 

3250 x : 1D array-like 

3251 The wedge sizes. 

3252 

3253 explode : array-like, default: None 

3254 If not *None*, is a ``len(x)`` array which specifies the fraction 

3255 of the radius with which to offset each wedge. 

3256 

3257 labels : list, default: None 

3258 A sequence of strings providing the labels for each wedge 

3259 

3260 colors : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color`, default: None 

3261 A sequence of colors through which the pie chart will cycle. If 

3262 *None*, will use the colors in the currently active cycle. 

3263 

3264 hatch : str or list, default: None 

3265 Hatching pattern applied to all pie wedges or sequence of patterns 

3266 through which the chart will cycle. For a list of valid patterns, 

3267 see :doc:`/gallery/shapes_and_collections/hatch_style_reference`. 

3268 

3269 .. versionadded:: 3.7 

3270 

3271 autopct : None or str or callable, default: None 

3272 If not *None*, *autopct* is a string or function used to label the 

3273 wedges with their numeric value. The label will be placed inside 

3274 the wedge. If *autopct* is a format string, the label will be 

3275 ``fmt % pct``. If *autopct* is a function, then it will be called. 

3276 

3277 pctdistance : float, default: 0.6 

3278 The relative distance along the radius at which the text 

3279 generated by *autopct* is drawn. To draw the text outside the pie, 

3280 set *pctdistance* > 1. This parameter is ignored if *autopct* is 

3281 ``None``. 

3282 

3283 labeldistance : float or None, default: 1.1 

3284 The relative distance along the radius at which the labels are 

3285 drawn. To draw the labels inside the pie, set *labeldistance* < 1. 

3286 If set to ``None``, labels are not drawn but are still stored for 

3287 use in `.legend`. 

3288 

3289 shadow : bool or dict, default: False 

3290 If bool, whether to draw a shadow beneath the pie. If dict, draw a shadow 

3291 passing the properties in the dict to `.Shadow`. 

3292 

3293 .. versionadded:: 3.8 

3294 *shadow* can be a dict. 

3295 

3296 startangle : float, default: 0 degrees 

3297 The angle by which the start of the pie is rotated, 

3298 counterclockwise from the x-axis. 

3299 

3300 radius : float, default: 1 

3301 The radius of the pie. 

3302 

3303 counterclock : bool, default: True 

3304 Specify fractions direction, clockwise or counterclockwise. 

3305 

3306 wedgeprops : dict, default: None 

3307 Dict of arguments passed to each `.patches.Wedge` of the pie. 

3308 For example, ``wedgeprops = {'linewidth': 3}`` sets the width of 

3309 the wedge border lines equal to 3. By default, ``clip_on=False``. 

3310 When there is a conflict between these properties and other 

3311 keywords, properties passed to *wedgeprops* take precedence. 

3312 

3313 textprops : dict, default: None 

3314 Dict of arguments to pass to the text objects. 

3315 

3316 center : (float, float), default: (0, 0) 

3317 The coordinates of the center of the chart. 

3318 

3319 frame : bool, default: False 

3320 Plot Axes frame with the chart if true. 

3321 

3322 rotatelabels : bool, default: False 

3323 Rotate each label to the angle of the corresponding slice if true. 

3324 

3325 normalize : bool, default: True 

3326 When *True*, always make a full pie by normalizing x so that 

3327 ``sum(x) == 1``. *False* makes a partial pie if ``sum(x) <= 1`` 

3328 and raises a `ValueError` for ``sum(x) > 1``. 

3329 

3330 data : indexable object, optional 

3331 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

3332 

3333 Returns 

3334 ------- 

3335 patches : list 

3336 A sequence of `matplotlib.patches.Wedge` instances 

3337 

3338 texts : list 

3339 A list of the label `.Text` instances. 

3340 

3341 autotexts : list 

3342 A list of `.Text` instances for the numeric labels. This will only 

3343 be returned if the parameter *autopct* is not *None*. 

3344 

3345 Notes 

3346 ----- 

3347 The pie chart will probably look best if the figure and Axes are 

3348 square, or the Axes aspect is equal. 

3349 This method sets the aspect ratio of the axis to "equal". 

3350 The Axes aspect ratio can be controlled with `.Axes.set_aspect`. 

3351 """ 

3352 self.set_aspect('equal') 

3353 # The use of float32 is "historical", but can't be changed without 

3354 # regenerating the test baselines. 

3355 x = np.asarray(x, np.float32) 

3356 if x.ndim > 1: 

3357 raise ValueError("x must be 1D") 

3358 

3359 if np.any(x < 0): 

3360 raise ValueError("Wedge sizes 'x' must be non negative values") 

3361 

3362 sx = x.sum() 

3363 

3364 if normalize: 

3365 x = x / sx 

3366 elif sx > 1: 

3367 raise ValueError('Cannot plot an unnormalized pie with sum(x) > 1') 

3368 if labels is None: 

3369 labels = [''] * len(x) 

3370 if explode is None: 

3371 explode = [0] * len(x) 

3372 if len(x) != len(labels): 

3373 raise ValueError(f"'labels' must be of length 'x', not {len(labels)}") 

3374 if len(x) != len(explode): 

3375 raise ValueError(f"'explode' must be of length 'x', not {len(explode)}") 

3376 if colors is None: 

3377 get_next_color = self._get_patches_for_fill.get_next_color 

3378 else: 

3379 color_cycle = itertools.cycle(colors) 

3380 

3381 def get_next_color(): 

3382 return next(color_cycle) 

3383 

3384 hatch_cycle = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(hatch)) 

3385 

3386 _api.check_isinstance(Real, radius=radius, startangle=startangle) 

3387 if radius <= 0: 

3388 raise ValueError(f"'radius' must be a positive number, not {radius}") 

3389 

3390 # Starting theta1 is the start fraction of the circle 

3391 theta1 = startangle / 360 

3392 

3393 if wedgeprops is None: 

3394 wedgeprops = {} 

3395 if textprops is None: 

3396 textprops = {} 

3397 

3398 texts = [] 

3399 slices = [] 

3400 autotexts = [] 

3401 

3402 for frac, label, expl in zip(x, labels, explode): 

3403 x, y = center 

3404 theta2 = (theta1 + frac) if counterclock else (theta1 - frac) 

3405 thetam = 2 * np.pi * 0.5 * (theta1 + theta2) 

3406 x += expl * math.cos(thetam) 

3407 y += expl * math.sin(thetam) 

3408 

3409 w = mpatches.Wedge((x, y), radius, 360. * min(theta1, theta2), 

3410 360. * max(theta1, theta2), 

3411 facecolor=get_next_color(), 

3412 hatch=next(hatch_cycle), 

3413 clip_on=False, 

3414 label=label) 

3415 w.set(**wedgeprops) 

3416 slices.append(w) 

3417 self.add_patch(w) 

3418 

3419 if shadow: 

3420 # Make sure to add a shadow after the call to add_patch so the 

3421 # figure and transform props will be set. 

3422 shadow_dict = {'ox': -0.02, 'oy': -0.02, 'label': '_nolegend_'} 

3423 if isinstance(shadow, dict): 

3424 shadow_dict.update(shadow) 

3425 self.add_patch(mpatches.Shadow(w, **shadow_dict)) 

3426 

3427 if labeldistance is not None: 

3428 xt = x + labeldistance * radius * math.cos(thetam) 

3429 yt = y + labeldistance * radius * math.sin(thetam) 

3430 label_alignment_h = 'left' if xt > 0 else 'right' 

3431 label_alignment_v = 'center' 

3432 label_rotation = 'horizontal' 

3433 if rotatelabels: 

3434 label_alignment_v = 'bottom' if yt > 0 else 'top' 

3435 label_rotation = (np.rad2deg(thetam) 

3436 + (0 if xt > 0 else 180)) 

3437 t = self.text(xt, yt, label, 

3438 clip_on=False, 

3439 horizontalalignment=label_alignment_h, 

3440 verticalalignment=label_alignment_v, 

3441 rotation=label_rotation, 

3442 size=mpl.rcParams['xtick.labelsize']) 

3443 t.set(**textprops) 

3444 texts.append(t) 

3445 

3446 if autopct is not None: 

3447 xt = x + pctdistance * radius * math.cos(thetam) 

3448 yt = y + pctdistance * radius * math.sin(thetam) 

3449 if isinstance(autopct, str): 

3450 s = autopct % (100. * frac) 

3451 elif callable(autopct): 

3452 s = autopct(100. * frac) 

3453 else: 

3454 raise TypeError( 

3455 'autopct must be callable or a format string') 

3456 if mpl._val_or_rc(textprops.get("usetex"), "text.usetex"): 

3457 # escape % (i.e. \%) if it is not already escaped 

3458 s = re.sub(r"([^\\])%", r"\1\\%", s) 

3459 t = self.text(xt, yt, s, 

3460 clip_on=False, 

3461 horizontalalignment='center', 

3462 verticalalignment='center') 

3463 t.set(**textprops) 

3464 autotexts.append(t) 

3465 

3466 theta1 = theta2 

3467 

3468 if frame: 

3469 self._request_autoscale_view() 

3470 else: 

3471 self.set(frame_on=False, xticks=[], yticks=[], 

3472 xlim=(-1.25 + center[0], 1.25 + center[0]), 

3473 ylim=(-1.25 + center[1], 1.25 + center[1])) 

3474 

3475 if autopct is None: 

3476 return slices, texts 

3477 else: 

3478 return slices, texts, autotexts 

3479 

3480 @staticmethod 

3481 def _errorevery_to_mask(x, errorevery): 

3482 """ 

3483 Normalize `errorbar`'s *errorevery* to be a boolean mask for data *x*. 

3484 

3485 This function is split out to be usable both by 2D and 3D errorbars. 

3486 """ 

3487 if isinstance(errorevery, Integral): 

3488 errorevery = (0, errorevery) 

3489 if isinstance(errorevery, tuple): 

3490 if (len(errorevery) == 2 and 

3491 isinstance(errorevery[0], Integral) and 

3492 isinstance(errorevery[1], Integral)): 

3493 errorevery = slice(errorevery[0], None, errorevery[1]) 

3494 else: 

3495 raise ValueError( 

3496 f'{errorevery=!r} is a not a tuple of two integers') 

3497 elif isinstance(errorevery, slice): 

3498 pass 

3499 elif not isinstance(errorevery, str) and np.iterable(errorevery): 

3500 try: 

3501 x[errorevery] # fancy indexing 

3502 except (ValueError, IndexError) as err: 

3503 raise ValueError( 

3504 f"{errorevery=!r} is iterable but not a valid NumPy fancy " 

3505 "index to match 'xerr'/'yerr'") from err 

3506 else: 

3507 raise ValueError(f"{errorevery=!r} is not a recognized value") 

3508 everymask = np.zeros(len(x), bool) 

3509 everymask[errorevery] = True 

3510 return everymask 

3511 

3512 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "ecolor") 

3513 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "xerr", "yerr"], 

3514 label_namer="y") 

3515 @_docstring.interpd 

3516 def errorbar(self, x, y, yerr=None, xerr=None, 

3517 fmt='', ecolor=None, elinewidth=None, capsize=None, 

3518 barsabove=False, lolims=False, uplims=False, 

3519 xlolims=False, xuplims=False, errorevery=1, capthick=None, 

3520 **kwargs): 

3521 """ 

3522 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers with attached errorbars. 

3523 

3524 *x*, *y* define the data locations, *xerr*, *yerr* define the errorbar 

3525 sizes. By default, this draws the data markers/lines as well as the 

3526 errorbars. Use fmt='none' to draw errorbars without any data markers. 

3527 

3528 .. versionadded:: 3.7 

3529 Caps and error lines are drawn in polar coordinates on polar plots. 

3530 

3531 

3532 Parameters 

3533 ---------- 

3534 x, y : float or array-like 

3535 The data positions. 

3536 

3537 xerr, yerr : float or array-like, shape(N,) or shape(2, N), optional 

3538 The errorbar sizes: 

3539 

3540 - scalar: Symmetric +/- values for all data points. 

3541 - shape(N,): Symmetric +/-values for each data point. 

3542 - shape(2, N): Separate - and + values for each bar. First row 

3543 contains the lower errors, the second row contains the upper 

3544 errors. 

3545 - *None*: No errorbar. 

3546 

3547 All values must be >= 0. 

3548 

3549 See :doc:`/gallery/statistics/errorbar_features` 

3550 for an example on the usage of ``xerr`` and ``yerr``. 

3551 

3552 fmt : str, default: '' 

3553 The format for the data points / data lines. See `.plot` for 

3554 details. 

3555 

3556 Use 'none' (case-insensitive) to plot errorbars without any data 

3557 markers. 

3558 

3559 ecolor : :mpltype:`color`, default: None 

3560 The color of the errorbar lines. If None, use the color of the 

3561 line connecting the markers. 

3562 

3563 elinewidth : float, default: None 

3564 The linewidth of the errorbar lines. If None, the linewidth of 

3565 the current style is used. 

3566 

3567 capsize : float, default: :rc:`errorbar.capsize` 

3568 The length of the error bar caps in points. 

3569 

3570 capthick : float, default: None 

3571 An alias to the keyword argument *markeredgewidth* (a.k.a. *mew*). 

3572 This setting is a more sensible name for the property that 

3573 controls the thickness of the error bar cap in points. For 

3574 backwards compatibility, if *mew* or *markeredgewidth* are given, 

3575 then they will over-ride *capthick*. This may change in future 

3576 releases. 

3577 

3578 barsabove : bool, default: False 

3579 If True, will plot the errorbars above the plot 

3580 symbols. Default is below. 

3581 

3582 lolims, uplims, xlolims, xuplims : bool or array-like, default: False 

3583 These arguments can be used to indicate that a value gives only 

3584 upper/lower limits. In that case a caret symbol is used to 

3585 indicate this. *lims*-arguments may be scalars, or array-likes of 

3586 the same length as *xerr* and *yerr*. To use limits with inverted 

3587 axes, `~.Axes.set_xlim` or `~.Axes.set_ylim` must be called before 

3588 :meth:`errorbar`. Note the tricky parameter names: setting e.g. 

3589 *lolims* to True means that the y-value is a *lower* limit of the 

3590 True value, so, only an *upward*-pointing arrow will be drawn! 

3591 

3592 errorevery : int or (int, int), default: 1 

3593 draws error bars on a subset of the data. *errorevery* =N draws 

3594 error bars on the points (x[::N], y[::N]). 

3595 *errorevery* =(start, N) draws error bars on the points 

3596 (x[start::N], y[start::N]). e.g. errorevery=(6, 3) 

3597 adds error bars to the data at (x[6], x[9], x[12], x[15], ...). 

3598 Used to avoid overlapping error bars when two series share x-axis 

3599 values. 

3600 

3601 Returns 

3602 ------- 

3603 `.ErrorbarContainer` 

3604 The container contains: 

3605 

3606 - data_line : A `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` instance of x, y plot markers 

3607 and/or line. 

3608 - caplines : A tuple of `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` instances of the error 

3609 bar caps. 

3610 - barlinecols : A tuple of `.LineCollection` with the horizontal and 

3611 vertical error ranges. 

3612 

3613 Other Parameters 

3614 ---------------- 

3615 data : indexable object, optional 

3616 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

3617 

3618 **kwargs 

3619 All other keyword arguments are passed on to the `~.Axes.plot` call 

3620 drawing the markers. For example, this code makes big red squares 

3621 with thick green edges:: 

3622 

3623 x, y, yerr = rand(3, 10) 

3624 errorbar(x, y, yerr, marker='s', mfc='red', 

3625 mec='green', ms=20, mew=4) 

3626 

3627 where *mfc*, *mec*, *ms* and *mew* are aliases for the longer 

3628 property names, *markerfacecolor*, *markeredgecolor*, *markersize* 

3629 and *markeredgewidth*. 

3630 

3631 Valid kwargs for the marker properties are: 

3632 

3633 - *dashes* 

3634 - *dash_capstyle* 

3635 - *dash_joinstyle* 

3636 - *drawstyle* 

3637 - *fillstyle* 

3638 - *linestyle* 

3639 - *marker* 

3640 - *markeredgecolor* 

3641 - *markeredgewidth* 

3642 - *markerfacecolor* 

3643 - *markerfacecoloralt* 

3644 - *markersize* 

3645 - *markevery* 

3646 - *solid_capstyle* 

3647 - *solid_joinstyle* 

3648 

3649 Refer to the corresponding `.Line2D` property for more details: 

3650 

3651 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

3652 """ 

3653 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D) 

3654 # Drop anything that comes in as None to use the default instead. 

3655 kwargs = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if v is not None} 

3656 kwargs.setdefault('zorder', 2) 

3657 

3658 # Casting to object arrays preserves units. 

3659 if not isinstance(x, np.ndarray): 

3660 x = np.asarray(x, dtype=object) 

3661 if not isinstance(y, np.ndarray): 

3662 y = np.asarray(y, dtype=object) 

3663 

3664 def _upcast_err(err): 

3665 """ 

3666 Safely handle tuple of containers that carry units. 

3667 

3668 This function covers the case where the input to the xerr/yerr is a 

3669 length 2 tuple of equal length ndarray-subclasses that carry the 

3670 unit information in the container. 

3671 

3672 If we have a tuple of nested numpy array (subclasses), we defer 

3673 coercing the units to be consistent to the underlying unit 

3674 library (and implicitly the broadcasting). 

3675 

3676 Otherwise, fallback to casting to an object array. 

3677 """ 

3678 

3679 if ( 

3680 # make sure it is not a scalar 

3681 np.iterable(err) and 

3682 # and it is not empty 

3683 len(err) > 0 and 

3684 # and the first element is an array sub-class use 

3685 # safe_first_element because getitem is index-first not 

3686 # location first on pandas objects so err[0] almost always 

3687 # fails. 

3688 isinstance(cbook._safe_first_finite(err), np.ndarray) 

3689 ): 

3690 # Get the type of the first element 

3691 atype = type(cbook._safe_first_finite(err)) 

3692 # Promote the outer container to match the inner container 

3693 if atype is np.ndarray: 

3694 # Converts using np.asarray, because data cannot 

3695 # be directly passed to init of np.ndarray 

3696 return np.asarray(err, dtype=object) 

3697 # If atype is not np.ndarray, directly pass data to init. 

3698 # This works for types such as unyts and astropy units 

3699 return atype(err) 

3700 # Otherwise wrap it in an object array 

3701 return np.asarray(err, dtype=object) 

3702 

3703 if xerr is not None and not isinstance(xerr, np.ndarray): 

3704 xerr = _upcast_err(xerr) 

3705 if yerr is not None and not isinstance(yerr, np.ndarray): 

3706 yerr = _upcast_err(yerr) 

3707 x, y = np.atleast_1d(x, y) # Make sure all the args are iterable. 

3708 if len(x) != len(y): 

3709 raise ValueError("'x' and 'y' must have the same size") 

3710 

3711 everymask = self._errorevery_to_mask(x, errorevery) 

3712 

3713 label = kwargs.pop("label", None) 

3714 kwargs['label'] = '_nolegend_' 

3715 

3716 # Create the main line and determine overall kwargs for child artists. 

3717 # We avoid calling self.plot() directly, or self._get_lines(), because 

3718 # that would call self._process_unit_info again, and do other indirect 

3719 # data processing. 

3720 (data_line, base_style), = self._get_lines._plot_args( 

3721 self, (x, y) if fmt == '' else (x, y, fmt), kwargs, return_kwargs=True) 

3722 

3723 # Do this after creating `data_line` to avoid modifying `base_style`. 

3724 if barsabove: 

3725 data_line.set_zorder(kwargs['zorder'] - .1) 

3726 else: 

3727 data_line.set_zorder(kwargs['zorder'] + .1) 

3728 

3729 # Add line to plot, or throw it away and use it to determine kwargs. 

3730 if fmt.lower() != 'none': 

3731 self.add_line(data_line) 

3732 else: 

3733 data_line = None 

3734 # Remove alpha=0 color that _get_lines._plot_args returns for 

3735 # 'none' format, and replace it with user-specified color, if 

3736 # supplied. 

3737 base_style.pop('color') 

3738 if 'color' in kwargs: 

3739 base_style['color'] = kwargs.pop('color') 

3740 

3741 if 'color' not in base_style: 

3742 base_style['color'] = 'C0' 

3743 if ecolor is None: 

3744 ecolor = base_style['color'] 

3745 

3746 # Eject any line-specific information from format string, as it's not 

3747 # needed for bars or caps. 

3748 for key in ['marker', 'markersize', 'markerfacecolor', 

3749 'markerfacecoloralt', 

3750 'markeredgewidth', 'markeredgecolor', 'markevery', 

3751 'linestyle', 'fillstyle', 'drawstyle', 'dash_capstyle', 

3752 'dash_joinstyle', 'solid_capstyle', 'solid_joinstyle', 

3753 'dashes']: 

3754 base_style.pop(key, None) 

3755 

3756 # Make the style dict for the line collections (the bars). 

3757 eb_lines_style = {**base_style, 'color': ecolor} 

3758 

3759 if elinewidth is not None: 

3760 eb_lines_style['linewidth'] = elinewidth 

3761 elif 'linewidth' in kwargs: 

3762 eb_lines_style['linewidth'] = kwargs['linewidth'] 

3763 

3764 for key in ('transform', 'alpha', 'zorder', 'rasterized'): 

3765 if key in kwargs: 

3766 eb_lines_style[key] = kwargs[key] 

3767 

3768 # Make the style dict for caps (the "hats"). 

3769 eb_cap_style = {**base_style, 'linestyle': 'none'} 

3770 if capsize is None: 

3771 capsize = mpl.rcParams["errorbar.capsize"] 

3772 if capsize > 0: 

3773 eb_cap_style['markersize'] = 2. * capsize 

3774 if capthick is not None: 

3775 eb_cap_style['markeredgewidth'] = capthick 

3776 

3777 # For backwards-compat, allow explicit setting of 

3778 # 'markeredgewidth' to over-ride capthick. 

3779 for key in ('markeredgewidth', 'transform', 'alpha', 

3780 'zorder', 'rasterized'): 

3781 if key in kwargs: 

3782 eb_cap_style[key] = kwargs[key] 

3783 eb_cap_style['color'] = ecolor 

3784 

3785 barcols = [] 

3786 caplines = {'x': [], 'y': []} 

3787 

3788 # Vectorized fancy-indexer. 

3789 def apply_mask(arrays, mask): 

3790 return [array[mask] for array in arrays] 

3791 

3792 # dep: dependent dataset, indep: independent dataset 

3793 for (dep_axis, dep, err, lolims, uplims, indep, lines_func, 

3794 marker, lomarker, himarker) in [ 

3795 ("x", x, xerr, xlolims, xuplims, y, self.hlines, 

3796 "|", mlines.CARETRIGHTBASE, mlines.CARETLEFTBASE), 

3797 ("y", y, yerr, lolims, uplims, x, self.vlines, 

3798 "_", mlines.CARETUPBASE, mlines.CARETDOWNBASE), 

3799 ]: 

3800 if err is None: 

3801 continue 

3802 lolims = np.broadcast_to(lolims, len(dep)).astype(bool) 

3803 uplims = np.broadcast_to(uplims, len(dep)).astype(bool) 

3804 try: 

3805 np.broadcast_to(err, (2, len(dep))) 

3806 except ValueError: 

3807 raise ValueError( 

3808 f"'{dep_axis}err' (shape: {np.shape(err)}) must be a " 

3809 f"scalar or a 1D or (2, n) array-like whose shape matches " 

3810 f"'{dep_axis}' (shape: {np.shape(dep)})") from None 

3811 if err.dtype is np.dtype(object) and np.any(err == None): # noqa: E711 

3812 raise ValueError( 

3813 f"'{dep_axis}err' must not contain None. " 

3814 "Use NaN if you want to skip a value.") 

3815 

3816 res = np.zeros(err.shape, dtype=bool) # Default in case of nan 

3817 if np.any(np.less(err, -err, out=res, where=(err == err))): 

3818 # like err<0, but also works for timedelta and nan. 

3819 raise ValueError( 

3820 f"'{dep_axis}err' must not contain negative values") 

3821 # This is like 

3822 # elow, ehigh = np.broadcast_to(...) 

3823 # return dep - elow * ~lolims, dep + ehigh * ~uplims 

3824 # except that broadcast_to would strip units. 

3825 low, high = dep + np.vstack([-(1 - lolims), 1 - uplims]) * err 

3826 barcols.append(lines_func( 

3827 *apply_mask([indep, low, high], everymask), **eb_lines_style)) 

3828 if self.name == "polar" and dep_axis == "x": 

3829 for b in barcols: 

3830 for p in b.get_paths(): 

3831 p._interpolation_steps = 2 

3832 # Normal errorbars for points without upper/lower limits. 

3833 nolims = ~(lolims | uplims) 

3834 if nolims.any() and capsize > 0: 

3835 indep_masked, lo_masked, hi_masked = apply_mask( 

3836 [indep, low, high], nolims & everymask) 

3837 for lh_masked in [lo_masked, hi_masked]: 

3838 # Since this has to work for x and y as dependent data, we 

3839 # first set both x and y to the independent variable and 

3840 # overwrite the respective dependent data in a second step. 

3841 line = mlines.Line2D(indep_masked, indep_masked, 

3842 marker=marker, **eb_cap_style) 

3843 line.set(**{f"{dep_axis}data": lh_masked}) 

3844 caplines[dep_axis].append(line) 

3845 for idx, (lims, hl) in enumerate([(lolims, high), (uplims, low)]): 

3846 if not lims.any(): 

3847 continue 

3848 hlmarker = ( 

3849 himarker 

3850 if self._axis_map[dep_axis].get_inverted() ^ idx 

3851 else lomarker) 

3852 x_masked, y_masked, hl_masked = apply_mask( 

3853 [x, y, hl], lims & everymask) 

3854 # As above, we set the dependent data in a second step. 

3855 line = mlines.Line2D(x_masked, y_masked, 

3856 marker=hlmarker, **eb_cap_style) 

3857 line.set(**{f"{dep_axis}data": hl_masked}) 

3858 caplines[dep_axis].append(line) 

3859 if capsize > 0: 

3860 caplines[dep_axis].append(mlines.Line2D( 

3861 x_masked, y_masked, marker=marker, **eb_cap_style)) 

3862 if self.name == 'polar': 

3863 trans_shift = self.transShift 

3864 for axis in caplines: 

3865 for l in caplines[axis]: 

3866 # Rotate caps to be perpendicular to the error bars 

3867 for theta, r in zip(l.get_xdata(), l.get_ydata()): 

3868 rotation = _ScaledRotation(theta=theta, trans_shift=trans_shift) 

3869 if axis == 'y': 

3870 rotation += mtransforms.Affine2D().rotate(np.pi / 2) 

3871 ms = mmarkers.MarkerStyle(marker=marker, 

3872 transform=rotation) 

3873 self.add_line(mlines.Line2D([theta], [r], marker=ms, 

3874 **eb_cap_style)) 

3875 else: 

3876 for axis in caplines: 

3877 for l in caplines[axis]: 

3878 self.add_line(l) 

3879 

3880 self._request_autoscale_view() 

3881 caplines = caplines['x'] + caplines['y'] 

3882 errorbar_container = ErrorbarContainer( 

3883 (data_line, tuple(caplines), tuple(barcols)), 

3884 has_xerr=(xerr is not None), has_yerr=(yerr is not None), 

3885 label=label) 

3886 self.add_container(errorbar_container) 

3887 

3888 return errorbar_container # (l0, caplines, barcols) 

3889 

3890 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "notch") 

3891 @_preprocess_data() 

3892 @_api.rename_parameter("3.9", "labels", "tick_labels") 

3893 def boxplot(self, x, notch=None, sym=None, vert=None, 

3894 orientation='vertical', whis=None, positions=None, 

3895 widths=None, patch_artist=None, bootstrap=None, 

3896 usermedians=None, conf_intervals=None, 

3897 meanline=None, showmeans=None, showcaps=None, 

3898 showbox=None, showfliers=None, boxprops=None, 

3899 tick_labels=None, flierprops=None, medianprops=None, 

3900 meanprops=None, capprops=None, whiskerprops=None, 

3901 manage_ticks=True, autorange=False, zorder=None, 

3902 capwidths=None, label=None): 

3903 """ 

3904 Draw a box and whisker plot. 

3905 

3906 The box extends from the first quartile (Q1) to the third 

3907 quartile (Q3) of the data, with a line at the median. 

3908 The whiskers extend from the box to the farthest data point 

3909 lying within 1.5x the inter-quartile range (IQR) from the box. 

3910 Flier points are those past the end of the whiskers. 

3911 See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot for reference. 

3912 

3913 .. code-block:: none 

3914 

3915 Q1-1.5IQR Q1 median Q3 Q3+1.5IQR 

3916 |-----:-----| 

3917 o |--------| : |--------| o o 

3918 |-----:-----| 

3919 flier <-----------> fliers 

3920 IQR 

3921 

3922 

3923 Parameters 

3924 ---------- 

3925 x : Array or a sequence of vectors. 

3926 The input data. If a 2D array, a boxplot is drawn for each column 

3927 in *x*. If a sequence of 1D arrays, a boxplot is drawn for each 

3928 array in *x*. 

3929 

3930 notch : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.notch` 

3931 Whether to draw a notched boxplot (`True`), or a rectangular 

3932 boxplot (`False`). The notches represent the confidence interval 

3933 (CI) around the median. The documentation for *bootstrap* 

3934 describes how the locations of the notches are computed by 

3935 default, but their locations may also be overridden by setting the 

3936 *conf_intervals* parameter. 

3937 

3938 .. note:: 

3939 

3940 In cases where the values of the CI are less than the 

3941 lower quartile or greater than the upper quartile, the 

3942 notches will extend beyond the box, giving it a 

3943 distinctive "flipped" appearance. This is expected 

3944 behavior and consistent with other statistical 

3945 visualization packages. 

3946 

3947 sym : str, optional 

3948 The default symbol for flier points. An empty string ('') hides 

3949 the fliers. If `None`, then the fliers default to 'b+'. More 

3950 control is provided by the *flierprops* parameter. 

3951 

3952 vert : bool, optional 

3953 .. deprecated:: 3.11 

3954 Use *orientation* instead. 

3955 

3956 This is a pending deprecation for 3.10, with full deprecation 

3957 in 3.11 and removal in 3.13. 

3958 If this is given during the deprecation period, it overrides 

3959 the *orientation* parameter. 

3960 

3961 If True, plots the boxes vertically. 

3962 If False, plots the boxes horizontally. 

3963 

3964 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

3965 If 'horizontal', plots the boxes horizontally. 

3966 Otherwise, plots the boxes vertically. 

3967 

3968 .. versionadded:: 3.10 

3969 

3970 whis : float or (float, float), default: 1.5 

3971 The position of the whiskers. 

3972 

3973 If a float, the lower whisker is at the lowest datum above 

3974 ``Q1 - whis*(Q3-Q1)``, and the upper whisker at the highest datum 

3975 below ``Q3 + whis*(Q3-Q1)``, where Q1 and Q3 are the first and 

3976 third quartiles. The default value of ``whis = 1.5`` corresponds 

3977 to Tukey's original definition of boxplots. 

3978 

3979 If a pair of floats, they indicate the percentiles at which to 

3980 draw the whiskers (e.g., (5, 95)). In particular, setting this to 

3981 (0, 100) results in whiskers covering the whole range of the data. 

3982 

3983 In the edge case where ``Q1 == Q3``, *whis* is automatically set 

3984 to (0, 100) (cover the whole range of the data) if *autorange* is 

3985 True. 

3986 

3987 Beyond the whiskers, data are considered outliers and are plotted 

3988 as individual points. 

3989 

3990 bootstrap : int, optional 

3991 Specifies whether to bootstrap the confidence intervals 

3992 around the median for notched boxplots. If *bootstrap* is 

3993 None, no bootstrapping is performed, and notches are 

3994 calculated using a Gaussian-based asymptotic approximation 

3995 (see McGill, R., Tukey, J.W., and Larsen, W.A., 1978, and 

3996 Kendall and Stuart, 1967). Otherwise, bootstrap specifies 

3997 the number of times to bootstrap the median to determine its 

3998 95% confidence intervals. Values between 1000 and 10000 are 

3999 recommended. 

4000 

4001 usermedians : 1D array-like, optional 

4002 A 1D array-like of length ``len(x)``. Each entry that is not 

4003 `None` forces the value of the median for the corresponding 

4004 dataset. For entries that are `None`, the medians are computed 

4005 by Matplotlib as normal. 

4006 

4007 conf_intervals : array-like, optional 

4008 A 2D array-like of shape ``(len(x), 2)``. Each entry that is not 

4009 None forces the location of the corresponding notch (which is 

4010 only drawn if *notch* is `True`). For entries that are `None`, 

4011 the notches are computed by the method specified by the other 

4012 parameters (e.g., *bootstrap*). 

4013 

4014 positions : array-like, optional 

4015 The positions of the boxes. The ticks and limits are 

4016 automatically set to match the positions. Defaults to 

4017 ``range(1, N+1)`` where N is the number of boxes to be drawn. 

4018 

4019 widths : float or array-like 

4020 The widths of the boxes. The default is 0.5, or ``0.15*(distance 

4021 between extreme positions)``, if that is smaller. 

4022 

4023 patch_artist : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.patchartist` 

4024 If `False` produces boxes with the Line2D artist. Otherwise, 

4025 boxes are drawn with Patch artists. 

4026 

4027 tick_labels : list of str, optional 

4028 The tick labels of each boxplot. 

4029 Ticks are always placed at the box *positions*. If *tick_labels* is given, 

4030 the ticks are labelled accordingly. Otherwise, they keep their numeric 

4031 values. 

4032 

4033 .. versionchanged:: 3.9 

4034 Renamed from *labels*, which is deprecated since 3.9 

4035 and will be removed in 3.11. 

4036 

4037 manage_ticks : bool, default: True 

4038 If True, the tick locations and labels will be adjusted to match 

4039 the boxplot positions. 

4040 

4041 autorange : bool, default: False 

4042 When `True` and the data are distributed such that the 25th and 

4043 75th percentiles are equal, *whis* is set to (0, 100) such 

4044 that the whisker ends are at the minimum and maximum of the data. 

4045 

4046 meanline : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.meanline` 

4047 If `True` (and *showmeans* is `True`), will try to render the 

4048 mean as a line spanning the full width of the box according to 

4049 *meanprops* (see below). Not recommended if *shownotches* is also 

4050 True. Otherwise, means will be shown as points. 

4051 

4052 zorder : float, default: ``Line2D.zorder = 2`` 

4053 The zorder of the boxplot. 

4054 

4055 Returns 

4056 ------- 

4057 dict 

4058 A dictionary mapping each component of the boxplot to a list 

4059 of the `.Line2D` instances created. That dictionary has the 

4060 following keys (assuming vertical boxplots): 

4061 

4062 - ``boxes``: the main body of the boxplot showing the 

4063 quartiles and the median's confidence intervals if 

4064 enabled. 

4065 

4066 - ``medians``: horizontal lines at the median of each box. 

4067 

4068 - ``whiskers``: the vertical lines extending to the most 

4069 extreme, non-outlier data points. 

4070 

4071 - ``caps``: the horizontal lines at the ends of the 

4072 whiskers. 

4073 

4074 - ``fliers``: points representing data that extend beyond 

4075 the whiskers (fliers). 

4076 

4077 - ``means``: points or lines representing the means. 

4078 

4079 Other Parameters 

4080 ---------------- 

4081 showcaps : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.showcaps` 

4082 Show the caps on the ends of whiskers. 

4083 showbox : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.showbox` 

4084 Show the central box. 

4085 showfliers : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.showfliers` 

4086 Show the outliers beyond the caps. 

4087 showmeans : bool, default: :rc:`boxplot.showmeans` 

4088 Show the arithmetic means. 

4089 capprops : dict, default: None 

4090 The style of the caps. 

4091 capwidths : float or array, default: None 

4092 The widths of the caps. 

4093 boxprops : dict, default: None 

4094 The style of the box. 

4095 whiskerprops : dict, default: None 

4096 The style of the whiskers. 

4097 flierprops : dict, default: None 

4098 The style of the fliers. 

4099 medianprops : dict, default: None 

4100 The style of the median. 

4101 meanprops : dict, default: None 

4102 The style of the mean. 

4103 label : str or list of str, optional 

4104 Legend labels. Use a single string when all boxes have the same style and 

4105 you only want a single legend entry for them. Use a list of strings to 

4106 label all boxes individually. To be distinguishable, the boxes should be 

4107 styled individually, which is currently only possible by modifying the 

4108 returned artists, see e.g. :doc:`/gallery/statistics/boxplot_demo`. 

4109 

4110 In the case of a single string, the legend entry will technically be 

4111 associated with the first box only. By default, the legend will show the 

4112 median line (``result["medians"]``); if *patch_artist* is True, the legend 

4113 will show the box `.Patch` artists (``result["boxes"]``) instead. 

4114 

4115 .. versionadded:: 3.9 

4116 

4117 data : indexable object, optional 

4118 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

4119 

4120 See Also 

4121 -------- 

4122 .Axes.bxp : Draw a boxplot from pre-computed statistics. 

4123 violinplot : Draw an estimate of the probability density function. 

4124 """ 

4125 

4126 # Missing arguments default to rcParams. 

4127 if whis is None: 

4128 whis = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.whiskers'] 

4129 if bootstrap is None: 

4130 bootstrap = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.bootstrap'] 

4131 

4132 bxpstats = cbook.boxplot_stats(x, whis=whis, bootstrap=bootstrap, 

4133 labels=tick_labels, autorange=autorange) 

4134 if notch is None: 

4135 notch = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.notch'] 

4136 if patch_artist is None: 

4137 patch_artist = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.patchartist'] 

4138 if meanline is None: 

4139 meanline = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.meanline'] 

4140 if showmeans is None: 

4141 showmeans = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showmeans'] 

4142 if showcaps is None: 

4143 showcaps = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showcaps'] 

4144 if showbox is None: 

4145 showbox = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showbox'] 

4146 if showfliers is None: 

4147 showfliers = mpl.rcParams['boxplot.showfliers'] 

4148 

4149 if boxprops is None: 

4150 boxprops = {} 

4151 if whiskerprops is None: 

4152 whiskerprops = {} 

4153 if capprops is None: 

4154 capprops = {} 

4155 if medianprops is None: 

4156 medianprops = {} 

4157 if meanprops is None: 

4158 meanprops = {} 

4159 if flierprops is None: 

4160 flierprops = {} 

4161 

4162 if patch_artist: 

4163 boxprops['linestyle'] = 'solid' # Not consistent with bxp. 

4164 if 'color' in boxprops: 

4165 boxprops['edgecolor'] = boxprops.pop('color') 

4166 

4167 # if non-default sym value, put it into the flier dictionary 

4168 # the logic for providing the default symbol ('b+') now lives 

4169 # in bxp in the initial value of flierkw 

4170 # handle all of the *sym* related logic here so we only have to pass 

4171 # on the flierprops dict. 

4172 if sym is not None: 

4173 # no-flier case, which should really be done with 

4174 # 'showfliers=False' but none-the-less deal with it to keep back 

4175 # compatibility 

4176 if sym == '': 

4177 # blow away existing dict and make one for invisible markers 

4178 flierprops = dict(linestyle='none', marker='', color='none') 

4179 # turn the fliers off just to be safe 

4180 showfliers = False 

4181 # now process the symbol string 

4182 else: 

4183 # process the symbol string 

4184 # discarded linestyle 

4185 _, marker, color = _process_plot_format(sym) 

4186 # if we have a marker, use it 

4187 if marker is not None: 

4188 flierprops['marker'] = marker 

4189 # if we have a color, use it 

4190 if color is not None: 

4191 # assume that if color is passed in the user want 

4192 # filled symbol, if the users want more control use 

4193 # flierprops 

4194 flierprops['color'] = color 

4195 flierprops['markerfacecolor'] = color 

4196 flierprops['markeredgecolor'] = color 

4197 

4198 # replace medians if necessary: 

4199 if usermedians is not None: 

4200 if (len(np.ravel(usermedians)) != len(bxpstats) or 

4201 np.shape(usermedians)[0] != len(bxpstats)): 

4202 raise ValueError( 

4203 "'usermedians' and 'x' have different lengths") 

4204 else: 

4205 # reassign medians as necessary 

4206 for stats, med in zip(bxpstats, usermedians): 

4207 if med is not None: 

4208 stats['med'] = med 

4209 

4210 if conf_intervals is not None: 

4211 if len(conf_intervals) != len(bxpstats): 

4212 raise ValueError( 

4213 "'conf_intervals' and 'x' have different lengths") 

4214 else: 

4215 for stats, ci in zip(bxpstats, conf_intervals): 

4216 if ci is not None: 

4217 if len(ci) != 2: 

4218 raise ValueError('each confidence interval must ' 

4219 'have two values') 

4220 else: 

4221 if ci[0] is not None: 

4222 stats['cilo'] = ci[0] 

4223 if ci[1] is not None: 

4224 stats['cihi'] = ci[1] 

4225 

4226 artists = self.bxp(bxpstats, positions=positions, widths=widths, 

4227 vert=vert, patch_artist=patch_artist, 

4228 shownotches=notch, showmeans=showmeans, 

4229 showcaps=showcaps, showbox=showbox, 

4230 boxprops=boxprops, flierprops=flierprops, 

4231 medianprops=medianprops, meanprops=meanprops, 

4232 meanline=meanline, showfliers=showfliers, 

4233 capprops=capprops, whiskerprops=whiskerprops, 

4234 manage_ticks=manage_ticks, zorder=zorder, 

4235 capwidths=capwidths, label=label, 

4236 orientation=orientation) 

4237 return artists 

4238 

4239 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "widths") 

4240 def bxp(self, bxpstats, positions=None, widths=None, vert=None, 

4241 orientation='vertical', patch_artist=False, shownotches=False, 

4242 showmeans=False, showcaps=True, showbox=True, showfliers=True, 

4243 boxprops=None, whiskerprops=None, flierprops=None, 

4244 medianprops=None, capprops=None, meanprops=None, 

4245 meanline=False, manage_ticks=True, zorder=None, 

4246 capwidths=None, label=None): 

4247 """ 

4248 Draw a box and whisker plot from pre-computed statistics. 

4249 

4250 The box extends from the first quartile *q1* to the third 

4251 quartile *q3* of the data, with a line at the median (*med*). 

4252 The whiskers extend from *whislow* to *whishi*. 

4253 Flier points are markers past the end of the whiskers. 

4254 See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot for reference. 

4255 

4256 .. code-block:: none 

4257 

4258 whislow q1 med q3 whishi 

4259 |-----:-----| 

4260 o |--------| : |--------| o o 

4261 |-----:-----| 

4262 flier fliers 

4263 

4264 .. note:: 

4265 This is a low-level drawing function for when you already 

4266 have the statistical parameters. If you want a boxplot based 

4267 on a dataset, use `~.Axes.boxplot` instead. 

4268 

4269 Parameters 

4270 ---------- 

4271 bxpstats : list of dicts 

4272 A list of dictionaries containing stats for each boxplot. 

4273 Required keys are: 

4274 

4275 - ``med``: Median (float). 

4276 - ``q1``, ``q3``: First & third quartiles (float). 

4277 - ``whislo``, ``whishi``: Lower & upper whisker positions (float). 

4278 

4279 Optional keys are: 

4280 

4281 - ``mean``: Mean (float). Needed if ``showmeans=True``. 

4282 - ``fliers``: Data beyond the whiskers (array-like). 

4283 Needed if ``showfliers=True``. 

4284 - ``cilo``, ``cihi``: Lower & upper confidence intervals 

4285 about the median. Needed if ``shownotches=True``. 

4286 - ``label``: Name of the dataset (str). If available, 

4287 this will be used a tick label for the boxplot 

4288 

4289 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n] 

4290 The positions of the boxes. The ticks and limits 

4291 are automatically set to match the positions. 

4292 

4293 widths : float or array-like, default: None 

4294 The widths of the boxes. The default is 

4295 ``clip(0.15*(distance between extreme positions), 0.15, 0.5)``. 

4296 

4297 capwidths : float or array-like, default: None 

4298 Either a scalar or a vector and sets the width of each cap. 

4299 The default is ``0.5*(width of the box)``, see *widths*. 

4300 

4301 vert : bool, optional 

4302 .. deprecated:: 3.11 

4303 Use *orientation* instead. 

4304 

4305 This is a pending deprecation for 3.10, with full deprecation 

4306 in 3.11 and removal in 3.13. 

4307 If this is given during the deprecation period, it overrides 

4308 the *orientation* parameter. 

4309 

4310 If True, plots the boxes vertically. 

4311 If False, plots the boxes horizontally. 

4312 

4313 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

4314 If 'horizontal', plots the boxes horizontally. 

4315 Otherwise, plots the boxes vertically. 

4316 

4317 .. versionadded:: 3.10 

4318 

4319 patch_artist : bool, default: False 

4320 If `False` produces boxes with the `.Line2D` artist. 

4321 If `True` produces boxes with the `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` artist. 

4322 

4323 shownotches, showmeans, showcaps, showbox, showfliers : bool 

4324 Whether to draw the CI notches, the mean value (both default to 

4325 False), the caps, the box, and the fliers (all three default to 

4326 True). 

4327 

4328 boxprops, whiskerprops, capprops, flierprops, medianprops, meanprops :\ 

4329 dict, optional 

4330 Artist properties for the boxes, whiskers, caps, fliers, medians, and 

4331 means. 

4332 

4333 meanline : bool, default: False 

4334 If `True` (and *showmeans* is `True`), will try to render the mean 

4335 as a line spanning the full width of the box according to 

4336 *meanprops*. Not recommended if *shownotches* is also True. 

4337 Otherwise, means will be shown as points. 

4338 

4339 manage_ticks : bool, default: True 

4340 If True, the tick locations and labels will be adjusted to match the 

4341 boxplot positions. 

4342 

4343 label : str or list of str, optional 

4344 Legend labels. Use a single string when all boxes have the same style and 

4345 you only want a single legend entry for them. Use a list of strings to 

4346 label all boxes individually. To be distinguishable, the boxes should be 

4347 styled individually, which is currently only possible by modifying the 

4348 returned artists, see e.g. :doc:`/gallery/statistics/boxplot_demo`. 

4349 

4350 In the case of a single string, the legend entry will technically be 

4351 associated with the first box only. By default, the legend will show the 

4352 median line (``result["medians"]``); if *patch_artist* is True, the legend 

4353 will show the box `.Patch` artists (``result["boxes"]``) instead. 

4354 

4355 .. versionadded:: 3.9 

4356 

4357 zorder : float, default: ``Line2D.zorder = 2`` 

4358 The zorder of the resulting boxplot. 

4359 

4360 Returns 

4361 ------- 

4362 dict 

4363 A dictionary mapping each component of the boxplot to a list 

4364 of the `.Line2D` instances created. That dictionary has the 

4365 following keys (assuming vertical boxplots): 

4366 

4367 - ``boxes``: main bodies of the boxplot showing the quartiles, and 

4368 the median's confidence intervals if enabled. 

4369 - ``medians``: horizontal lines at the median of each box.
