6421 ``C[i, j]``. The dimensions of *X* and *Y* should be 

6422 one greater than those of *C*; if they are the same as *C*, 

6423 then a deprecation warning is raised, and the last row 

6424 and column of *C* are dropped. 

6425 - 'nearest': Each grid point will have a color centered on it, 

6426 extending halfway between the adjacent grid centers. The 

6427 dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*. 

6428 - 'gouraud': Each quad will be Gouraud shaded: The color of the 

6429 corners (i', j') are given by ``C[i', j']``. The color values of 

6430 the area in between is interpolated from the corner values. 

6431 The dimensions of *X* and *Y* must be the same as *C*. When 

6432 Gouraud shading is used, *edgecolors* is ignored. 

6433 - 'auto': Choose 'flat' if dimensions of *X* and *Y* are one 

6434 larger than *C*. Choose 'nearest' if dimensions are the same. 

6435 

6436 See :doc:`/gallery/images_contours_and_fields/pcolormesh_grids` 

6437 for more description. 

6438 

6439 snap : bool, default: False 

6440 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries. 

6441 

6442 rasterized : bool, optional 

6443 Rasterize the pcolormesh when drawing vector graphics. This can 

6444 speed up rendering and produce smaller files for large data sets. 

6445 See also :doc:`/gallery/misc/rasterization_demo`. 

6446 

6447 Returns 

6448 ------- 

6449 `matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` 

6450 

6451 Other Parameters 

6452 ---------------- 

6453 data : indexable object, optional 

6454 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

6455 

6456 **kwargs 

6457 Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed 

6458 along to the `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` constructor: 

6459 

6460 %(QuadMesh:kwdoc)s 

6461 

6462 See Also 

6463 -------- 

6464 pcolor : An alternative implementation with slightly different 

6465 features. For a detailed discussion on the differences see 

6466 :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh() 

6467 <differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`. 

6468 imshow : If *X* and *Y* are each equidistant, `~.Axes.imshow` can be a 

6469 faster alternative. 

6470 

6471 Notes 

6472 ----- 

6473 **Masked arrays** 

6474 

6475 *C* may be a masked array. If ``C[i, j]`` is masked, the corresponding 

6476 quadrilateral will be transparent. Masking of *X* and *Y* is not 

6477 supported. Use `~.Axes.pcolor` if you need this functionality. 

6478 

6479 .. _axes-pcolormesh-grid-orientation: 

6480 

6481 **Grid orientation** 

6482 

6483 The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array 

6484 *C* with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as 

6485 *X* and the row number as *Y*. 

6486 

6487 .. _differences-pcolor-pcolormesh: 

6488 

6489 **Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()** 

6490 

6491 Both methods are used to create a pseudocolor plot of a 2D array 

6492 using quadrilaterals. 

6493 

6494 The main difference lies in the created object and internal data 

6495 handling: 

6496 While `~.Axes.pcolor` returns a `.PolyQuadMesh`, `~.Axes.pcolormesh` 

6497 returns a `.QuadMesh`. The latter is more specialized for the given 

6498 purpose and thus is faster. It should almost always be preferred. 

6499 

6500 There is also a slight difference in the handling of masked arrays. 

6501 Both `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh` support masked arrays 

6502 for *C*. However, only `~.Axes.pcolor` supports masked arrays for *X* 

6503 and *Y*. The reason lies in the internal handling of the masked values. 

6504 `~.Axes.pcolor` leaves out the respective polygons from the 

6505 PolyQuadMesh. `~.Axes.pcolormesh` sets the facecolor of the masked 

6506 elements to transparent. You can see the difference when using 

6507 edgecolors. While all edges are drawn irrespective of masking in a 

6508 QuadMesh, the edge between two adjacent masked quadrilaterals in 

6509 `~.Axes.pcolor` is not drawn as the corresponding polygons do not 

6510 exist in the PolyQuadMesh. Because PolyQuadMesh draws each individual 

6511 polygon, it also supports applying hatches and linestyles to the collection. 

6512 

6513 Another difference is the support of Gouraud shading in 

6514 `~.Axes.pcolormesh`, which is not available with `~.Axes.pcolor`. 

6515 

6516 """ 

6517 if shading is None: 

6518 shading = mpl.rcParams['pcolor.shading'] 

6519 shading = shading.lower() 

6520 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolors', 'none') 

6521 

6522 X, Y, C, shading = self._pcolorargs('pcolormesh', *args, 

6523 shading=shading, kwargs=kwargs) 

6524 coords = np.stack([X, Y], axis=-1) 

6525 

6526 kwargs.setdefault('snap', mpl.rcParams['pcolormesh.snap']) 

6527 

6528 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh( 

6529 coords, antialiased=antialiased, shading=shading, 

6530 array=C, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, colorizer=colorizer, alpha=alpha, **kwargs) 

6531 collection._check_exclusionary_keywords(colorizer, vmin=vmin, vmax=vmax) 

6532 collection._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax) 

6533 

6534 coords = coords.reshape(-1, 2) # flatten the grid structure; keep x, y 

6535 

6536 # Transform from native to data coordinates? 

6537 t = collection._transform 

6538 if (not isinstance(t, mtransforms.Transform) and 

6539 hasattr(t, '_as_mpl_transform')): 

6540 t = t._as_mpl_transform(self.axes) 

6541 

6542 if t and any(t.contains_branch_seperately(self.transData)): 

6543 trans_to_data = t - self.transData 

6544 coords = trans_to_data.transform(coords) 

6545 

6546 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False) 

6547 

6548 minx, miny = np.min(coords, axis=0) 

6549 maxx, maxy = np.max(coords, axis=0) 

6550 collection.sticky_edges.x[:] = [minx, maxx] 

6551 collection.sticky_edges.y[:] = [miny, maxy] 

6552 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy) 

6553 self.update_datalim(corners) 

6554 self._request_autoscale_view() 

6555 return collection 

6556 

6557 @_preprocess_data() 

6558 @_docstring.interpd 

6559 def pcolorfast(self, *args, alpha=None, norm=None, cmap=None, vmin=None, 

6560 vmax=None, colorizer=None, **kwargs): 

6561 """ 

6562 Create a pseudocolor plot with a non-regular rectangular grid. 

6563 

6564 Call signature:: 

6565 

6566 ax.pcolorfast([X, Y], C, /, **kwargs) 

6567 

6568 The arguments *X*, *Y*, *C* are positional-only. 

6569 

6570 This method is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor` and `~.Axes.pcolormesh`. 

6571 It's designed to provide the fastest pcolor-type plotting with the 

6572 Agg backend. To achieve this, it uses different algorithms internally 

6573 depending on the complexity of the input grid (regular rectangular, 

6574 non-regular rectangular or arbitrary quadrilateral). 

6575 

6576 .. warning:: 

6577 

6578 This method is experimental. Compared to `~.Axes.pcolor` or 

6579 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` it has some limitations: 

6580 

6581 - It supports only flat shading (no outlines) 

6582 - It lacks support for log scaling of the axes. 

6583 - It does not have a pyplot wrapper. 

6584 

6585 Parameters 

6586 ---------- 

6587 C : array-like 

6588 The image data. Supported array shapes are: 

6589 

6590 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. Color-mapping is controlled 

6591 by *cmap*, *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*. 

6592 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int). 

6593 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int), 

6594 i.e. including transparency. 

6595 

6596 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of 

6597 the image. 

6598 

6599 This parameter can only be passed positionally. 

6600 

6601 X, Y : tuple or array-like, default: ``(0, N)``, ``(0, M)`` 

6602 *X* and *Y* are used to specify the coordinates of the 

6603 quadrilaterals. There are different ways to do this: 

6604 

6605 - Use tuples ``X=(xmin, xmax)`` and ``Y=(ymin, ymax)`` to define 

6606 a *uniform rectangular grid*. 

6607 

6608 The tuples define the outer edges of the grid. All individual 

6609 quadrilaterals will be of the same size. This is the fastest 

6610 version. 

6611 

6612 - Use 1D arrays *X*, *Y* to specify a *non-uniform rectangular 

6613 grid*. 

6614 

6615 In this case *X* and *Y* have to be monotonic 1D arrays of length 

6616 *N+1* and *M+1*, specifying the x and y boundaries of the cells. 

6617 

6618 The speed is intermediate. Note: The grid is checked, and if 

6619 found to be uniform the fast version is used. 

6620 

6621 - Use 2D arrays *X*, *Y* if you need an *arbitrary quadrilateral 

6622 grid* (i.e. if the quadrilaterals are not rectangular). 

6623 

6624 In this case *X* and *Y* are 2D arrays with shape (M + 1, N + 1), 

6625 specifying the x and y coordinates of the corners of the colored 

6626 quadrilaterals. 

6627 

6628 This is the most general, but the slowest to render. It may 

6629 produce faster and more compact output using ps, pdf, and 

6630 svg backends, however. 

6631 

6632 These arguments can only be passed positionally. 

6633 

6634 %(cmap_doc)s 

6635 

6636 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6637 

6638 %(norm_doc)s 

6639 

6640 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6641 

6642 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s 

6643 

6644 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6645 

6646 %(colorizer_doc)s 

6647 

6648 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6649 

6650 alpha : float, default: None 

6651 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque). 

6652 

6653 snap : bool, default: False 

6654 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries. 

6655 

6656 Returns 

6657 ------- 

6658 `.AxesImage` or `.PcolorImage` or `.QuadMesh` 

6659 The return type depends on the type of grid: 

6660 

6661 - `.AxesImage` for a regular rectangular grid. 

6662 - `.PcolorImage` for a non-regular rectangular grid. 

6663 - `.QuadMesh` for a non-rectangular grid. 

6664 

6665 Other Parameters 

6666 ---------------- 

6667 data : indexable object, optional 

6668 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

6669 

6670 **kwargs 

6671 Supported additional parameters depend on the type of grid. 

6672 See return types of *image* for further description. 

6673 """ 

6674 

6675 C = args[-1] 

6676 nr, nc = np.shape(C)[:2] 

6677 if len(args) == 1: 

6678 style = "image" 

6679 x = [0, nc] 

6680 y = [0, nr] 

6681 elif len(args) == 3: 

6682 x, y = args[:2] 

6683 x = np.asarray(x) 

6684 y = np.asarray(y) 

6685 if x.ndim == 1 and y.ndim == 1: 

6686 if x.size == 2 and y.size == 2: 

6687 style = "image" 

6688 else: 

6689 if x.size != nc + 1: 

6690 raise ValueError( 

6691 f"Length of X ({x.size}) must be one larger than the " 

6692 f"number of columns in C ({nc})") 

6693 if y.size != nr + 1: 

6694 raise ValueError( 

6695 f"Length of Y ({y.size}) must be one larger than the " 

6696 f"number of rows in C ({nr})" 

6697 ) 

6698 dx = np.diff(x) 

6699 dy = np.diff(y) 

6700 if (np.ptp(dx) < 0.01 * abs(dx.mean()) and 

6701 np.ptp(dy) < 0.01 * abs(dy.mean())): 

6702 style = "image" 

6703 else: 

6704 style = "pcolorimage" 

6705 elif x.ndim == 2 and y.ndim == 2: 

6706 style = "quadmesh" 

6707 else: 

6708 raise TypeError( 

6709 f"When 3 positional parameters are passed to pcolorfast, the first " 

6710 f"two (X and Y) must be both 1D or both 2D; the given X was " 

6711 f"{x.ndim}D and the given Y was {y.ndim}D") 

6712 else: 

6713 raise _api.nargs_error('pcolorfast', '1 or 3', len(args)) 

6714 

6715 mcolorizer.ColorizingArtist._check_exclusionary_keywords(colorizer, vmin=vmin, 

6716 vmax=vmax) 

6717 if style == "quadmesh": 

6718 # data point in each cell is value at lower left corner 

6719 coords = np.stack([x, y], axis=-1) 

6720 if np.ndim(C) not in {2, 3}: 

6721 raise ValueError("C must be 2D or 3D") 

6722 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh( 

6723 coords, array=C, 

6724 alpha=alpha, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, colorizer=colorizer, 

6725 antialiased=False, edgecolors="none") 

6726 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False) 

6727 xl, xr, yb, yt = x.min(), x.max(), y.min(), y.max() 

6728 ret = collection 

6729 

6730 else: # It's one of the two image styles. 

6731 extent = xl, xr, yb, yt = x[0], x[-1], y[0], y[-1] 

6732 if style == "image": 

6733 im = mimage.AxesImage( 

6734 self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, colorizer=colorizer, 

6735 data=C, alpha=alpha, extent=extent, 

6736 interpolation='nearest', origin='lower', 

6737 **kwargs) 

6738 elif style == "pcolorimage": 

6739 im = mimage.PcolorImage( 

6740 self, x, y, C, 

6741 cmap=cmap, norm=norm, colorizer=colorizer, alpha=alpha, 

6742 extent=extent, **kwargs) 

6743 self.add_image(im) 

6744 ret = im 

6745 

6746 if np.ndim(C) == 2: # C.ndim == 3 is RGB(A) so doesn't need scaling. 

6747 ret._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax) 

6748 

6749 if ret.get_clip_path() is None: 

6750 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to Axes patch 

6751 ret.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

6752 

6753 ret.sticky_edges.x[:] = [xl, xr] 

6754 ret.sticky_edges.y[:] = [yb, yt] 

6755 self.update_datalim(np.array([[xl, yb], [xr, yt]])) 

6756 self._request_autoscale_view(tight=True) 

6757 return ret 

6758 

6759 @_preprocess_data() 

6760 @_docstring.interpd 

6761 def contour(self, *args, **kwargs): 

6762 """ 

6763 Plot contour lines. 

6764 

6765 Call signature:: 

6766 

6767 contour([X, Y,] Z, /, [levels], **kwargs) 

6768 

6769 The arguments *X*, *Y*, *Z* are positional-only. 

6770 %(contour_doc)s 

6771 """ 

6772 kwargs['filled'] = False 

6773 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs) 

6774 self._request_autoscale_view() 

6775 return contours 

6776 

6777 @_preprocess_data() 

6778 @_docstring.interpd 

6779 def contourf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

6780 """ 

6781 Plot filled contours. 

6782 

6783 Call signature:: 

6784 

6785 contourf([X, Y,] Z, /, [levels], **kwargs) 

6786 

6787 The arguments *X*, *Y*, *Z* are positional-only. 

6788 %(contour_doc)s 

6789 """ 

6790 kwargs['filled'] = True 

6791 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs) 

6792 self._request_autoscale_view() 

6793 return contours 

6794 

6795 def clabel(self, CS, levels=None, **kwargs): 

6796 """ 

6797 Label a contour plot. 

6798 

6799 Adds labels to line contours in given `.ContourSet`. 

6800 

6801 Parameters 

6802 ---------- 

6803 CS : `.ContourSet` instance 

6804 Line contours to label. 

6805 

6806 levels : array-like, optional 

6807 A list of level values, that should be labeled. The list must be 

6808 a subset of ``CS.levels``. If not given, all levels are labeled. 

6809 

6810 **kwargs 

6811 All other parameters are documented in `~.ContourLabeler.clabel`. 

6812 """ 

6813 return CS.clabel(levels, **kwargs) 

6814 

6815 #### Data analysis 

6816 

6817 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "range") 

6818 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", 'weights'], label_namer="x") 

6819 def hist(self, x, bins=None, range=None, density=False, weights=None, 

6820 cumulative=False, bottom=None, histtype='bar', align='mid', 

6821 orientation='vertical', rwidth=None, log=False, 

6822 color=None, label=None, stacked=False, **kwargs): 

6823 """ 

6824 Compute and plot a histogram. 

6825 

6826 This method uses `numpy.histogram` to bin the data in *x* and count the 

6827 number of values in each bin, then draws the distribution either as a 

6828 `.BarContainer` or `.Polygon`. The *bins*, *range*, *density*, and 

6829 *weights* parameters are forwarded to `numpy.histogram`. 

6830 

6831 If the data has already been binned and counted, use `~.bar` or 

6832 `~.stairs` to plot the distribution:: 

6833 

6834 counts, bins = np.histogram(x) 

6835 plt.stairs(counts, bins) 

6836 

6837 Alternatively, plot pre-computed bins and counts using ``hist()`` by 

6838 treating each bin as a single point with a weight equal to its count:: 

6839 

6840 plt.hist(bins[:-1], bins, weights=counts) 

6841 

6842 The data input *x* can be a singular array, a list of datasets of 

6843 potentially different lengths ([*x0*, *x1*, ...]), or a 2D ndarray in 

6844 which each column is a dataset. Note that the ndarray form is 

6845 transposed relative to the list form. If the input is an array, then 

6846 the return value is a tuple (*n*, *bins*, *patches*); if the input is a 

6847 sequence of arrays, then the return value is a tuple 

6848 ([*n0*, *n1*, ...], *bins*, [*patches0*, *patches1*, ...]). 

6849 

6850 Masked arrays are not supported. 

6851 

6852 Parameters 

6853 ---------- 

6854 x : (n,) array or sequence of (n,) arrays 

6855 Input values, this takes either a single array or a sequence of 

6856 arrays which are not required to be of the same length. 

6857 

6858 bins : int or sequence or str, default: :rc:`hist.bins` 

6859 If *bins* is an integer, it defines the number of equal-width bins 

6860 in the range. 

6861 

6862 If *bins* is a sequence, it defines the bin edges, including the 

6863 left edge of the first bin and the right edge of the last bin; 

6864 in this case, bins may be unequally spaced. All but the last 

6865 (righthand-most) bin is half-open. In other words, if *bins* is:: 

6866 

6867 [1, 2, 3, 4] 

6868 

6869 then the first bin is ``[1, 2)`` (including 1, but excluding 2) and 

6870 the second ``[2, 3)``. The last bin, however, is ``[3, 4]``, which 

6871 *includes* 4. 

6872 

6873 If *bins* is a string, it is one of the binning strategies 

6874 supported by `numpy.histogram_bin_edges`: 'auto', 'fd', 'doane', 

6875 'scott', 'stone', 'rice', 'sturges', or 'sqrt'. 

6876 

6877 range : tuple or None, default: None 

6878 The lower and upper range of the bins. Lower and upper outliers 

6879 are ignored. If not provided, *range* is ``(x.min(), x.max())``. 

6880 Range has no effect if *bins* is a sequence. 

6881 

6882 If *bins* is a sequence or *range* is specified, autoscaling 

6883 is based on the specified bin range instead of the 

6884 range of x. 

6885 

6886 density : bool, default: False 

6887 If ``True``, draw and return a probability density: each bin 

6888 will display the bin's raw count divided by the total number of 

6889 counts *and the bin width* 

6890 (``density = counts / (sum(counts) * np.diff(bins))``), 

6891 so that the area under the histogram integrates to 1 

6892 (``np.sum(density * np.diff(bins)) == 1``). 

6893 

6894 If *stacked* is also ``True``, the sum of the histograms is 

6895 normalized to 1. 

6896 

6897 weights : (n,) array-like or None, default: None 

6898 An array of weights, of the same shape as *x*. Each value in 

6899 *x* only contributes its associated weight towards the bin count 

6900 (instead of 1). If *density* is ``True``, the weights are 

6901 normalized, so that the integral of the density over the range 

6902 remains 1. 

6903 

6904 cumulative : bool or -1, default: False 

6905 If ``True``, then a histogram is computed where each bin gives the 

6906 counts in that bin plus all bins for smaller values. The last bin 

6907 gives the total number of datapoints. 

6908 

6909 If *density* is also ``True`` then the histogram is normalized such 

6910 that the last bin equals 1. 

6911 

6912 If *cumulative* is a number less than 0 (e.g., -1), the direction 

6913 of accumulation is reversed. In this case, if *density* is also 

6914 ``True``, then the histogram is normalized such that the first bin 

6915 equals 1. 

6916 

6917 bottom : array-like or float, default: 0 

6918 Location of the bottom of each bin, i.e. bins are drawn from 

6919 ``bottom`` to ``bottom + hist(x, bins)`` If a scalar, the bottom 

6920 of each bin is shifted by the same amount. If an array, each bin 

6921 is shifted independently and the length of bottom must match the 

6922 number of bins. If None, defaults to 0. 

6923 

6924 histtype : {'bar', 'barstacked', 'step', 'stepfilled'}, default: 'bar' 

6925 The type of histogram to draw. 

6926 

6927 - 'bar' is a traditional bar-type histogram. If multiple data 

6928 are given the bars are arranged side by side. 

6929 - 'barstacked' is a bar-type histogram where multiple 

6930 data are stacked on top of each other. 

6931 - 'step' generates a lineplot that is by default unfilled. 

6932 - 'stepfilled' generates a lineplot that is by default filled. 

6933 

6934 align : {'left', 'mid', 'right'}, default: 'mid' 

6935 The horizontal alignment of the histogram bars. 

6936 

6937 - 'left': bars are centered on the left bin edges. 

6938 - 'mid': bars are centered between the bin edges. 

6939 - 'right': bars are centered on the right bin edges. 

6940 

6941 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

6942 If 'horizontal', `~.Axes.barh` will be used for bar-type histograms 

6943 and the *bottom* kwarg will be the left edges. 

6944 

6945 rwidth : float or None, default: None 

6946 The relative width of the bars as a fraction of the bin width. If 

6947 ``None``, automatically compute the width. 

6948 

6949 Ignored if *histtype* is 'step' or 'stepfilled'. 

6950 

6951 log : bool, default: False 

6952 If ``True``, the histogram axis will be set to a log scale. 

6953 

6954 color : :mpltype:`color` or list of :mpltype:`color` or None, default: None 

6955 Color or sequence of colors, one per dataset. Default (``None``) 

6956 uses the standard line color sequence. 

6957 

6958 label : str or list of str, optional 

6959 String, or sequence of strings to match multiple datasets. Bar 

6960 charts yield multiple patches per dataset, but only the first gets 

6961 the label, so that `~.Axes.legend` will work as expected. 

6962 

6963 stacked : bool, default: False 

6964 If ``True``, multiple data are stacked on top of each other If 

6965 ``False`` multiple data are arranged side by side if histtype is 

6966 'bar' or on top of each other if histtype is 'step' 

6967 

6968 Returns 

6969 ------- 

6970 n : array or list of arrays 

6971 The values of the histogram bins. See *density* and *weights* for a 

6972 description of the possible semantics. If input *x* is an array, 

6973 then this is an array of length *nbins*. If input is a sequence of 

6974 arrays ``[data1, data2, ...]``, then this is a list of arrays with 

6975 the values of the histograms for each of the arrays in the same 

6976 order. The dtype of the array *n* (or of its element arrays) will 

6977 always be float even if no weighting or normalization is used. 

6978 

6979 bins : array 

6980 The edges of the bins. Length nbins + 1 (nbins left edges and right 

6981 edge of last bin). Always a single array even when multiple data 

6982 sets are passed in. 

6983 

6984 patches : `.BarContainer` or list of a single `.Polygon` or list of \ 

6985such objects 

6986 Container of individual artists used to create the histogram 

6987 or list of such containers if there are multiple input datasets. 

6988 

6989 Other Parameters 

6990 ---------------- 

6991 data : indexable object, optional 

6992 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

6993 

6994 **kwargs 

6995 `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties. The following properties 

6996 additionally accept a sequence of values corresponding to the 

6997 datasets in *x*: 

6998 *edgecolor*, *facecolor*, *linewidth*, *linestyle*, *hatch*. 

6999 

7000 .. versionadded:: 3.10 

7001 Allowing sequences of values in above listed Patch properties. 

7002 

7003 See Also 

7004 -------- 

7005 hist2d : 2D histogram with rectangular bins 

7006 hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins 

7007 stairs : Plot a pre-computed histogram 

7008 bar : Plot a pre-computed histogram 

7009 

7010 Notes 

7011 ----- 

7012 For large numbers of bins (>1000), plotting can be significantly 

7013 accelerated by using `~.Axes.stairs` to plot a pre-computed histogram 

7014 (``plt.stairs(*np.histogram(data))``), or by setting *histtype* to 

7015 'step' or 'stepfilled' rather than 'bar' or 'barstacked'. 

7016 """ 

7017 # Avoid shadowing the builtin. 

7018 bin_range = range 

7019 from builtins import range 

7020 

7021 if np.isscalar(x): 

7022 x = [x] 

7023 

7024 if bins is None: 

7025 bins = mpl.rcParams['hist.bins'] 

7026 

7027 # Validate string inputs here to avoid cluttering subsequent code. 

7028 _api.check_in_list(['bar', 'barstacked', 'step', 'stepfilled'], 

7029 histtype=histtype) 

7030 _api.check_in_list(['left', 'mid', 'right'], align=align) 

7031 _api.check_in_list(['horizontal', 'vertical'], orientation=orientation) 

7032 

7033 if histtype == 'barstacked' and not stacked: 

7034 stacked = True 

7035 

7036 # Massage 'x' for processing. 

7037 x = cbook._reshape_2D(x, 'x') 

7038 nx = len(x) # number of datasets 

7039 

7040 # Process unit information. _process_unit_info sets the unit and 

7041 # converts the first dataset; then we convert each following dataset 

7042 # one at a time. 

7043 if orientation == "vertical": 

7044 convert_units = self.convert_xunits 

7045 x = [*self._process_unit_info([("x", x[0])], kwargs), 

7046 *map(convert_units, x[1:])] 

7047 else: # horizontal 

7048 convert_units = self.convert_yunits 

7049 x = [*self._process_unit_info([("y", x[0])], kwargs), 

7050 *map(convert_units, x[1:])] 

7051 

7052 if bin_range is not None: 

7053 bin_range = convert_units(bin_range) 

7054 

7055 if not cbook.is_scalar_or_string(bins): 

7056 bins = convert_units(bins) 

7057 

7058 # We need to do to 'weights' what was done to 'x' 

7059 if weights is not None: 

7060 w = cbook._reshape_2D(weights, 'weights') 

7061 else: 

7062 w = [None] * nx 

7063 

7064 if len(w) != nx: 

7065 raise ValueError('weights should have the same shape as x') 

7066 

7067 input_empty = True 

7068 for xi, wi in zip(x, w): 

7069 len_xi = len(xi) 

7070 if wi is not None and len(wi) != len_xi: 

7071 raise ValueError('weights should have the same shape as x') 

7072 if len_xi: 

7073 input_empty = False 

7074 

7075 if color is None: 

7076 colors = [self._get_lines.get_next_color() for i in range(nx)] 

7077 else: 

7078 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(color) 

7079 if len(colors) != nx: 

7080 raise ValueError(f"The 'color' keyword argument must have one " 

7081 f"color per dataset, but {nx} datasets and " 

7082 f"{len(colors)} colors were provided") 

7083 

7084 hist_kwargs = dict() 

7085 

7086 # if the bin_range is not given, compute without nan numpy 

7087 # does not do this for us when guessing the range (but will 

7088 # happily ignore nans when computing the histogram). 

7089 if bin_range is None: 

7090 xmin = np.inf 

7091 xmax = -np.inf 

7092 for xi in x: 

7093 if len(xi): 

7094 # python's min/max ignore nan, 

7095 # np.minnan returns nan for all nan input 

7096 xmin = min(xmin, np.nanmin(xi)) 

7097 xmax = max(xmax, np.nanmax(xi)) 

7098 if xmin <= xmax: # Only happens if we have seen a finite value. 

7099 bin_range = (xmin, xmax) 

7100 

7101 # If bins are not specified either explicitly or via range, 

7102 # we need to figure out the range required for all datasets, 

7103 # and supply that to np.histogram. 

7104 if not input_empty and len(x) > 1: 

7105 if weights is not None: 

7106 _w = np.concatenate(w) 

7107 else: 

7108 _w = None 

7109 bins = np.histogram_bin_edges( 

7110 np.concatenate(x), bins, bin_range, _w) 

7111 else: 

7112 hist_kwargs['range'] = bin_range 

7113 

7114 density = bool(density) 

7115 if density and not stacked: 

7116 hist_kwargs['density'] = density 

7117 

7118 # List to store all the top coordinates of the histograms 

7119 tops = [] # Will have shape (n_datasets, n_bins). 

7120 # Loop through datasets 

7121 for i in range(nx): 

7122 # this will automatically overwrite bins, 

7123 # so that each histogram uses the same bins 

7124 m, bins = np.histogram(x[i], bins, weights=w[i], **hist_kwargs) 

7125 tops.append(m) 

7126 tops = np.array(tops, float) # causes problems later if it's an int 

7127 bins = np.array(bins, float) # causes problems if float16 

7128 if stacked: 

7129 tops = tops.cumsum(axis=0) 

7130 # If a stacked density plot, normalize so the area of all the 

7131 # stacked histograms together is 1 

7132 if density: 

7133 tops = (tops / np.diff(bins)) / tops[-1].sum() 

7134 if cumulative: 

7135 slc = slice(None) 

7136 if isinstance(cumulative, Number) and cumulative < 0: 

7137 slc = slice(None, None, -1) 

7138 if density: 

7139 tops = (tops * np.diff(bins))[:, slc].cumsum(axis=1)[:, slc] 

7140 else: 

7141 tops = tops[:, slc].cumsum(axis=1)[:, slc] 

7142 

7143 patches = [] 

7144 

7145 if histtype.startswith('bar'): 

7146 

7147 totwidth = np.diff(bins) 

7148 

7149 if rwidth is not None: 

7150 dr = np.clip(rwidth, 0, 1) 

7151 elif (len(tops) > 1 and 

7152 ((not stacked) or mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode'])): 

7153 dr = 0.8 

7154 else: 

7155 dr = 1.0 

7156 

7157 if histtype == 'bar' and not stacked: 

7158 width = dr * totwidth / nx 

7159 dw = width 

7160 boffset = -0.5 * dr * totwidth * (1 - 1 / nx) 

7161 elif histtype == 'barstacked' or stacked: 

7162 width = dr * totwidth 

7163 boffset, dw = 0.0, 0.0 

7164 

7165 if align == 'mid': 

7166 boffset += 0.5 * totwidth 

7167 elif align == 'right': 

7168 boffset += totwidth 

7169 

7170 if orientation == 'horizontal': 

7171 _barfunc = self.barh 

7172 bottom_kwarg = 'left' 

7173 else: # orientation == 'vertical' 

7174 _barfunc = self.bar 

7175 bottom_kwarg = 'bottom' 

7176 

7177 for top, color in zip(tops, colors): 

7178 if bottom is None: 

7179 bottom = np.zeros(len(top)) 

7180 if stacked: 

7181 height = top - bottom 

7182 else: 

7183 height = top 

7184 bars = _barfunc(bins[:-1]+boffset, height, width, 

7185 align='center', log=log, 

7186 color=color, **{bottom_kwarg: bottom}) 

7187 patches.append(bars) 

7188 if stacked: 

7189 bottom = top 

7190 boffset += dw 

7191 # Remove stickies from all bars but the lowest ones, as otherwise 

7192 # margin expansion would be unable to cross the stickies in the 

7193 # middle of the bars. 

7194 for bars in patches[1:]: 

7195 for patch in bars: 

7196 patch.sticky_edges.x[:] = patch.sticky_edges.y[:] = [] 

7197 

7198 elif histtype.startswith('step'): 

7199 # these define the perimeter of the polygon 

7200 x = np.zeros(4 * len(bins) - 3) 

7201 y = np.zeros(4 * len(bins) - 3) 

7202 

7203 x[0:2*len(bins)-1:2], x[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = bins, bins[:-1] 

7204 x[2*len(bins)-1:] = x[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

7205 

7206 if bottom is None: 

7207 bottom = 0 

7208 

7209 y[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = y[2:2*len(bins):2] = bottom 

7210 y[2*len(bins)-1:] = y[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

7211 

7212 if log: 

7213 if orientation == 'horizontal': 

7214 self.set_xscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

7215 else: # orientation == 'vertical' 

7216 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

7217 

7218 if align == 'left': 

7219 x -= 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0]) 

7220 elif align == 'right': 

7221 x += 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0]) 

7222 

7223 # If fill kwarg is set, it will be passed to the patch collection, 

7224 # overriding this 

7225 fill = (histtype == 'stepfilled') 

7226 

7227 xvals, yvals = [], [] 

7228 for top in tops: 

7229 if stacked: 

7230 # top of the previous polygon becomes the bottom 

7231 y[2*len(bins)-1:] = y[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

7232 # set the top of this polygon 

7233 y[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = y[2:2*len(bins):2] = top + bottom 

7234 

7235 # The starting point of the polygon has not yet been 

7236 # updated. So far only the endpoint was adjusted. This 

7237 # assignment closes the polygon. The redundant endpoint is 

7238 # later discarded (for step and stepfilled). 

7239 y[0] = y[-1] 

7240 

7241 if orientation == 'horizontal': 

7242 xvals.append(y.copy()) 

7243 yvals.append(x.copy()) 

7244 else: 

7245 xvals.append(x.copy()) 

7246 yvals.append(y.copy()) 

7247 

7248 # stepfill is closed, step is not 

7249 split = -1 if fill else 2 * len(bins) 

7250 # add patches in reverse order so that when stacking, 

7251 # items lower in the stack are plotted on top of 

7252 # items higher in the stack 

7253 for x, y, color in reversed(list(zip(xvals, yvals, colors))): 

7254 patches.append(self.fill( 

7255 x[:split], y[:split], 

7256 closed=True if fill else None, 

7257 facecolor=color, 

7258 edgecolor=None if fill else color, 

7259 fill=fill if fill else None, 

7260 zorder=None if fill else mlines.Line2D.zorder)) 

7261 for patch_list in patches: 

7262 for patch in patch_list: 

7263 if orientation == 'vertical': 

7264 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(0) 

7265 elif orientation == 'horizontal': 

7266 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(0) 

7267 

7268 # we return patches, so put it back in the expected order 

7269 patches.reverse() 

7270 

7271 # If None, make all labels None (via zip_longest below); otherwise, 

7272 # cast each element to str, but keep a single str as it. 

7273 labels = [] if label is None else np.atleast_1d(np.asarray(label, str)) 

7274 

7275 if histtype == "step": 

7276 edgecolors = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get('edgecolor', 

7277 colors))) 

7278 else: 

7279 edgecolors = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get("edgecolor", None))) 

7280 

7281 facecolors = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get('facecolor', colors))) 

7282 hatches = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get('hatch', None))) 

7283 linewidths = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get('linewidth', None))) 

7284 linestyles = itertools.cycle(np.atleast_1d(kwargs.get('linestyle', None))) 

7285 

7286 for patch, lbl in itertools.zip_longest(patches, labels): 

7287 if not patch: 

7288 continue 

7289 p = patch[0] 

7290 kwargs.update({ 

7291 'hatch': next(hatches), 

7292 'linewidth': next(linewidths), 

7293 'linestyle': next(linestyles), 

7294 'edgecolor': next(edgecolors), 

7295 'facecolor': next(facecolors), 

7296 }) 

7297 p._internal_update(kwargs) 

7298 if lbl is not None: 

7299 p.set_label(lbl) 

7300 for p in patch[1:]: 

7301 p._internal_update(kwargs) 

7302 p.set_label('_nolegend_') 

7303 

7304 if nx == 1: 

7305 return tops[0], bins, patches[0] 

7306 else: 

7307 patch_type = ("BarContainer" if histtype.startswith("bar") 

7308 else "list[Polygon]") 

7309 return tops, bins, cbook.silent_list(patch_type, patches) 

7310 

7311 @_preprocess_data() 

7312 def stairs(self, values, edges=None, *, 

7313 orientation='vertical', baseline=0, fill=False, **kwargs): 

7314 """ 

7315 Draw a stepwise constant function as a line or a filled plot. 

7316 

7317 *edges* define the x-axis positions of the steps. *values* the function values 

7318 between these steps. Depending on *fill*, the function is drawn either as a 

7319 continuous line with vertical segments at the edges, or as a filled area. 

7320 

7321 Parameters 

7322 ---------- 

7323 values : array-like 

7324 The step heights. 

7325 

7326 edges : array-like 

7327 The step positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``, 

7328 between which the curve takes on vals values. 

7329 

7330 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

7331 The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are along 

7332 the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis. 

7333 

7334 baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0 

7335 The bottom value of the bounding edges or when 

7336 ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is 

7337 True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed 

7338 path is drawn. 

7339 

7340 If None, then drawn as an unclosed Path. 

7341 

7342 fill : bool, default: False 

7343 Whether the area under the step curve should be filled. 

7344 

7345 Passing both ``fill=True` and ``baseline=None`` will likely result in 

7346 undesired filling: the first and last points will be connected 

7347 with a straight line and the fill will be between this line and the stairs. 

7348 

7349 

7350 Returns 

7351 ------- 

7352 StepPatch : `~matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` 

7353 

7354 Other Parameters 

7355 ---------------- 

7356 data : indexable object, optional 

7357 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7358 

7359 **kwargs 

7360 `~matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` properties 

7361 

7362 """ 

7363 

7364 if 'color' in kwargs: 

7365 _color = kwargs.pop('color') 

7366 else: 

7367 _color = self._get_lines.get_next_color() 

7368 if fill: 

7369 kwargs.setdefault('linewidth', 0) 

7370 kwargs.setdefault('facecolor', _color) 

7371 else: 

7372 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolor', _color) 

7373 

7374 if edges is None: 

7375 edges = np.arange(len(values) + 1) 

7376 

7377 edges, values, baseline = self._process_unit_info( 

7378 [("x", edges), ("y", values), ("y", baseline)], kwargs) 

7379 

7380 patch = mpatches.StepPatch(values, 

7381 edges, 

7382 baseline=baseline, 

7383 orientation=orientation, 

7384 fill=fill, 

7385 **kwargs) 

7386 self.add_patch(patch) 

7387 if baseline is None and fill: 

7388 _api.warn_external( 

7389 f"Both {baseline=} and {fill=} have been passed. " 

7390 "baseline=None is only intended for unfilled stair plots. " 

7391 "Because baseline is None, the Path used to draw the stairs will " 

7392 "not be closed, thus because fill is True the polygon will be closed " 

7393 "by drawing an (unstroked) edge from the first to last point. It is " 

7394 "very likely that the resulting fill patterns is not the desired " 

7395 "result." 

7396 ) 

7397 

7398 if baseline is not None: 

7399 if orientation == 'vertical': 

7400 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(np.min(baseline)) 

7401 self.update_datalim([(edges[0], np.min(baseline))]) 

7402 else: 

7403 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(np.min(baseline)) 

7404 self.update_datalim([(np.min(baseline), edges[0])]) 

7405 self._request_autoscale_view() 

7406 return patch 

7407 

7408 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "range") 

7409 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "weights"]) 

7410 @_docstring.interpd 

7411 def hist2d(self, x, y, bins=10, range=None, density=False, weights=None, 

7412 cmin=None, cmax=None, **kwargs): 

7413 """ 

7414 Make a 2D histogram plot. 

7415 

7416 Parameters 

7417 ---------- 

7418 x, y : array-like, shape (n, ) 

7419 Input values 

7420 

7421 bins : None or int or [int, int] or array-like or [array, array] 

7422 

7423 The bin specification: 

7424 

7425 - If int, the number of bins for the two dimensions 

7426 (``nx = ny = bins``). 

7427 - If ``[int, int]``, the number of bins in each dimension 

7428 (``nx, ny = bins``). 

7429 - If array-like, the bin edges for the two dimensions 

7430 (``x_edges = y_edges = bins``). 

7431 - If ``[array, array]``, the bin edges in each dimension 

7432 (``x_edges, y_edges = bins``). 

7433 

7434 The default value is 10. 

7435 

7436 range : array-like shape(2, 2), optional 

7437 The leftmost and rightmost edges of the bins along each dimension 

7438 (if not specified explicitly in the bins parameters): ``[[xmin, 

7439 xmax], [ymin, ymax]]``. All values outside of this range will be 

7440 considered outliers and not tallied in the histogram. 

7441 

7442 density : bool, default: False 

7443 Normalize histogram. See the documentation for the *density* 

7444 parameter of `~.Axes.hist` for more details. 

7445 

7446 weights : array-like, shape (n, ), optional 

7447 An array of values w_i weighing each sample (x_i, y_i). 

7448 

7449 cmin, cmax : float, default: None 

7450 All bins that has count less than *cmin* or more than *cmax* will not be 

7451 displayed (set to NaN before passing to `~.Axes.pcolormesh`) and these count 

7452 values in the return value count histogram will also be set to nan upon 

7453 return. 

7454 

7455 Returns 

7456 ------- 

7457 h : 2D array 

7458 The bi-dimensional histogram of samples x and y. Values in x are 

7459 histogrammed along the first dimension and values in y are 

7460 histogrammed along the second dimension. 

7461 xedges : 1D array 

7462 The bin edges along the x-axis. 

7463 yedges : 1D array 

7464 The bin edges along the y-axis. 

7465 image : `~.matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` 

7466 

7467 Other Parameters 

7468 ---------------- 

7469 %(cmap_doc)s 

7470 

7471 %(norm_doc)s 

7472 

7473 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s 

7474 

7475 %(colorizer_doc)s 

7476 

7477 alpha : ``0 <= scalar <= 1`` or ``None``, optional 

7478 The alpha blending value. 

7479 

7480 data : indexable object, optional 

7481 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7482 

7483 **kwargs 

7484 Additional parameters are passed along to the 

7485 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` method and `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` 

7486 constructor. 

7487 

7488 See Also 

7489 -------- 

7490 hist : 1D histogram plotting 

7491 hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins 

7492 

7493 Notes 

7494 ----- 

7495 - Currently ``hist2d`` calculates its own axis limits, and any limits 

7496 previously set are ignored. 

7497 - Rendering the histogram with a logarithmic color scale is 

7498 accomplished by passing a `.colors.LogNorm` instance to the *norm* 

7499 keyword argument. Likewise, power-law normalization (similar 

7500 in effect to gamma correction) can be accomplished with 

7501 `.colors.PowerNorm`. 

7502 """ 

7503 

7504 h, xedges, yedges = np.histogram2d(x, y, bins=bins, range=range, 

7505 density=density, weights=weights) 

7506 

7507 if cmin is not None: 

7508 h[h < cmin] = None 

7509 if cmax is not None: 

7510 h[h > cmax] = None 

7511 

7512 pc = self.pcolormesh(xedges, yedges, h.T, **kwargs) 

7513 self.set_xlim(xedges[0], xedges[-1]) 

7514 self.set_ylim(yedges[0], yedges[-1]) 

7515 

7516 return h, xedges, yedges, pc 

7517 

7518 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "weights"], label_namer="x") 

7519 @_docstring.interpd 

7520 def ecdf(self, x, weights=None, *, complementary=False, 

7521 orientation="vertical", compress=False, **kwargs): 

7522 """ 

7523 Compute and plot the empirical cumulative distribution function of *x*. 

7524 

7525 .. versionadded:: 3.8 

7526 

7527 Parameters 

7528 ---------- 

7529 x : 1d array-like 

7530 The input data. Infinite entries are kept (and move the relevant 

7531 end of the ecdf from 0/1), but NaNs and masked values are errors. 

7532 

7533 weights : 1d array-like or None, default: None 

7534 The weights of the entries; must have the same shape as *x*. 

7535 Weights corresponding to NaN data points are dropped, and then the 

7536 remaining weights are normalized to sum to 1. If unset, all 

7537 entries have the same weight. 

7538 

7539 complementary : bool, default: False 

7540 Whether to plot a cumulative distribution function, which increases 

7541 from 0 to 1 (the default), or a complementary cumulative 

7542 distribution function, which decreases from 1 to 0. 

7543 

7544 orientation : {"vertical", "horizontal"}, default: "vertical" 

7545 Whether the entries are plotted along the x-axis ("vertical", the 

7546 default) or the y-axis ("horizontal"). This parameter takes the 

7547 same values as in `~.Axes.hist`. 

7548 

7549 compress : bool, default: False 

7550 Whether multiple entries with the same values are grouped together 

7551 (with a summed weight) before plotting. This is mainly useful if 

7552 *x* contains many identical data points, to decrease the rendering 

7553 complexity of the plot. If *x* contains no duplicate points, this 

7554 has no effect and just uses some time and memory. 

7555 

7556 Other Parameters 

7557 ---------------- 

7558 data : indexable object, optional 

7559 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7560 

7561 **kwargs 

7562 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7563 

7564 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7565 

7566 Returns 

7567 ------- 

7568 `.Line2D` 

7569 

7570 Notes 

7571 ----- 

7572 The ecdf plot can be thought of as a cumulative histogram with one bin 

7573 per data entry; i.e. it reports on the entire dataset without any 

7574 arbitrary binning. 

7575 

7576 If *x* contains NaNs or masked entries, either remove them first from 

7577 the array (if they should not taken into account), or replace them by 

7578 -inf or +inf (if they should be sorted at the beginning or the end of 

7579 the array). 

7580 """ 

7581 _api.check_in_list(["horizontal", "vertical"], orientation=orientation) 

7582 if "drawstyle" in kwargs or "ds" in kwargs: 

7583 raise TypeError("Cannot pass 'drawstyle' or 'ds' to ecdf()") 

7584 if np.ma.getmask(x).any(): 

7585 raise ValueError("ecdf() does not support masked entries") 

7586 x = np.asarray(x) 

7587 if np.isnan(x).any(): 

7588 raise ValueError("ecdf() does not support NaNs") 

7589 argsort = np.argsort(x) 

7590 x = x[argsort] 

7591 if weights is None: 

7592 # Ensure that we end at exactly 1, avoiding floating point errors. 

7593 cum_weights = (1 + np.arange(len(x))) / len(x) 

7594 else: 

7595 weights = np.take(weights, argsort) # Reorder weights like we reordered x. 

7596 cum_weights = np.cumsum(weights / np.sum(weights)) 

7597 if compress: 

7598 # Get indices of unique x values. 

7599 compress_idxs = [0, *(x[:-1] != x[1:]).nonzero()[0] + 1] 

7600 x = x[compress_idxs] 

7601 cum_weights = cum_weights[compress_idxs] 

7602 if orientation == "vertical": 

7603 if not complementary: 

7604 line, = self.plot([x[0], *x], [0, *cum_weights], 

7605 drawstyle="steps-post", **kwargs) 

7606 else: 

7607 line, = self.plot([*x, x[-1]], [1, *1 - cum_weights], 

7608 drawstyle="steps-pre", **kwargs) 

7609 line.sticky_edges.y[:] = [0, 1] 

7610 else: # orientation == "horizontal": 

7611 if not complementary: 

7612 line, = self.plot([0, *cum_weights], [x[0], *x], 

7613 drawstyle="steps-pre", **kwargs) 

7614 else: 

7615 line, = self.plot([1, *1 - cum_weights], [*x, x[-1]], 

7616 drawstyle="steps-post", **kwargs) 

7617 line.sticky_edges.x[:] = [0, 1] 

7618 return line 

7619 

7620 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "NFFT") 

7621 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7622 @_docstring.interpd 

7623 def psd(self, x, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

7624 window=None, noverlap=None, pad_to=None, 

7625 sides=None, scale_by_freq=None, return_line=None, **kwargs): 

7626 r""" 

7627 Plot the power spectral density. 

7628 

7629 The power spectral density :math:`P_{xx}` by Welch's average 

7630 periodogram method. The vector *x* is divided into *NFFT* length 

7631 segments. Each segment is detrended by function *detrend* and 

7632 windowed by function *window*. *noverlap* gives the length of 

7633 the overlap between segments. The :math:`|\mathrm{fft}(i)|^2` 

7634 of each segment :math:`i` are averaged to compute :math:`P_{xx}`, 

7635 with a scaling to correct for power loss due to windowing. 

7636 

7637 If len(*x*) < *NFFT*, it will be zero padded to *NFFT*. 

7638 

7639 Parameters 

7640 ---------- 

7641 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7642 Array or sequence containing the data 

7643 

7644 %(Spectral)s 

7645 

7646 %(PSD)s 

7647 

7648 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

7649 The number of points of overlap between segments. 

7650 

7651 Fc : int, default: 0 

7652 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7653 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7654 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7655 

7656 return_line : bool, default: False 

7657 Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values. 

7658 

7659 Returns 

7660 ------- 

7661 Pxx : 1-D array 

7662 The values for the power spectrum :math:`P_{xx}` before scaling 

7663 (real valued). 

7664 

7665 freqs : 1-D array 

7666 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxx*. 

7667 

7668 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7669 The line created by this function. 

7670 Only returned if *return_line* is True. 

7671 

7672 Other Parameters 

7673 ---------------- 

7674 data : indexable object, optional 

7675 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7676 

7677 **kwargs 

7678 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7679 

7680 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7681 

7682 See Also 

7683 -------- 

7684 specgram 

7685 Differs in the default overlap; in not returning the mean of the 

7686 segment periodograms; in returning the times of the segments; and 

7687 in plotting a colormap instead of a line. 

7688 magnitude_spectrum 

7689 Plots the magnitude spectrum. 

7690 csd 

7691 Plots the spectral density between two signals. 

7692 

7693 Notes 

7694 ----- 

7695 For plotting, the power is plotted as 

7696 :math:`10\log_{10}(P_{xx})` for decibels, though *Pxx* itself 

7697 is returned. 

7698 

7699 References 

7700 ---------- 

7701 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

7702 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

7703 """ 

7704 if Fc is None: 

7705 Fc = 0 

7706 

7707 pxx, freqs = mlab.psd(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

7708 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

7709 sides=sides, scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq) 

7710 freqs += Fc 

7711 

7712 if scale_by_freq in (None, True): 

7713 psd_units = 'dB/Hz' 

7714 else: 

7715 psd_units = 'dB' 

7716 

7717 line = self.plot(freqs, 10 * np.log10(pxx), **kwargs) 

7718 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7719 self.set_ylabel('Power Spectral Density (%s)' % psd_units) 

7720 self.grid(True) 

7721 

7722 vmin, vmax = self.get_ybound() 

7723 step = max(10 * int(np.log10(vmax - vmin)), 1) 

7724 ticks = np.arange(math.floor(vmin), math.ceil(vmax) + 1, step) 

7725 self.set_yticks(ticks) 

7726 

7727 if return_line is None or not return_line: 

7728 return pxx, freqs 

7729 else: 

7730 return pxx, freqs, line 

7731 

7732 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "NFFT") 

7733 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

7734 @_docstring.interpd 

7735 def csd(self, x, y, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

7736 window=None, noverlap=None, pad_to=None, 

7737 sides=None, scale_by_freq=None, return_line=None, **kwargs): 

7738 r""" 

7739 Plot the cross-spectral density. 

7740 

7741 The cross spectral density :math:`P_{xy}` by Welch's average 

7742 periodogram method. The vectors *x* and *y* are divided into 

7743 *NFFT* length segments. Each segment is detrended by function 

7744 *detrend* and windowed by function *window*. *noverlap* gives 

7745 the length of the overlap between segments. The product of 

7746 the direct FFTs of *x* and *y* are averaged over each segment 

7747 to compute :math:`P_{xy}`, with a scaling to correct for power 

7748 loss due to windowing. 

7749 

7750 If len(*x*) < *NFFT* or len(*y*) < *NFFT*, they will be zero 

7751 padded to *NFFT*. 

7752 

7753 Parameters 

7754 ---------- 

7755 x, y : 1-D arrays or sequences 

7756 Arrays or sequences containing the data. 

7757 

7758 %(Spectral)s 

7759 

7760 %(PSD)s 

7761 

7762 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

7763 The number of points of overlap between segments. 

7764 

7765 Fc : int, default: 0 

7766 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7767 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7768 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7769 

7770 return_line : bool, default: False 

7771 Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values. 

7772 

7773 Returns 

7774 ------- 

7775 Pxy : 1-D array 

7776 The values for the cross spectrum :math:`P_{xy}` before scaling 

7777 (complex valued). 

7778 

7779 freqs : 1-D array 

7780 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxy*. 

7781 

7782 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7783 The line created by this function. 

7784 Only returned if *return_line* is True. 

7785 

7786 Other Parameters 

7787 ---------------- 

7788 data : indexable object, optional 

7789 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7790 

7791 **kwargs 

7792 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7793 

7794 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7795 

7796 See Also 

7797 -------- 

7798 psd : is equivalent to setting ``y = x``. 

7799 

7800 Notes 

7801 ----- 

7802 For plotting, the power is plotted as 

7803 :math:`10 \log_{10}(P_{xy})` for decibels, though :math:`P_{xy}` itself 

7804 is returned. 

7805 

7806 References 

7807 ---------- 

7808 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

7809 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

7810 """ 

7811 if Fc is None: 

7812 Fc = 0 

7813 

7814 pxy, freqs = mlab.csd(x=x, y=y, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

7815 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

7816 sides=sides, scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq) 

7817 # pxy is complex 

7818 freqs += Fc 

7819 

7820 line = self.plot(freqs, 10 * np.log10(np.abs(pxy)), **kwargs) 

7821 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7822 self.set_ylabel('Cross Spectrum Magnitude (dB)') 

7823 self.grid(True) 

7824 

7825 vmin, vmax = self.get_ybound() 

7826 step = max(10 * int(np.log10(vmax - vmin)), 1) 

7827 ticks = np.arange(math.floor(vmin), math.ceil(vmax) + 1, step) 

7828 self.set_yticks(ticks) 

7829 

7830 if return_line is None or not return_line: 

7831 return pxy, freqs 

7832 else: 

7833 return pxy, freqs, line 

7834 

7835 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "Fs") 

7836 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7837 @_docstring.interpd 

7838 def magnitude_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None, 

7839 pad_to=None, sides=None, scale=None, 

7840 **kwargs): 

7841 """ 

7842 Plot the magnitude spectrum. 

7843 

7844 Compute the magnitude spectrum of *x*. Data is padded to a 

7845 length of *pad_to* and the windowing function *window* is applied to 

7846 the signal. 

7847 

7848 Parameters 

7849 ---------- 

7850 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7851 Array or sequence containing the data. 

7852 

7853 %(Spectral)s 

7854 

7855 %(Single_Spectrum)s 

7856 

7857 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'} 

7858 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling. 

7859 'dB' returns the values in dB scale, i.e., the dB amplitude 

7860 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'linear'. 

7861 

7862 Fc : int, default: 0 

7863 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7864 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7865 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7866 

7867 Returns 

7868 ------- 

7869 spectrum : 1-D array 

7870 The values for the magnitude spectrum before scaling (real valued). 

7871 

7872 freqs : 1-D array 

7873 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*. 

7874 

7875 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7876 The line created by this function. 

7877 

7878 Other Parameters 

7879 ---------------- 

7880 data : indexable object, optional 

7881 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7882 

7883 **kwargs 

7884 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7885 

7886 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7887 

7888 See Also 

7889 -------- 

7890 psd 

7891 Plots the power spectral density. 

7892 angle_spectrum 

7893 Plots the angles of the corresponding frequencies. 

7894 phase_spectrum 

7895 Plots the phase (unwrapped angle) of the corresponding frequencies. 

7896 specgram 

7897 Can plot the magnitude spectrum of segments within the signal in a 

7898 colormap. 

7899 """ 

7900 if Fc is None: 

7901 Fc = 0 

7902 

7903 spec, freqs = mlab.magnitude_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window, 

7904 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides) 

7905 freqs += Fc 

7906 

7907 yunits = _api.check_getitem( 

7908 {None: 'energy', 'default': 'energy', 'linear': 'energy', 

7909 'dB': 'dB'}, 

7910 scale=scale) 

7911 if yunits == 'energy': 

7912 Z = spec 

7913 else: # yunits == 'dB' 

7914 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec) 

7915 

7916 line, = self.plot(freqs, Z, **kwargs) 

7917 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7918 self.set_ylabel('Magnitude (%s)' % yunits) 

7919 

7920 return spec, freqs, line 

7921 

7922 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "Fs") 

7923 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7924 @_docstring.interpd 

7925 def angle_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None, 

7926 pad_to=None, sides=None, **kwargs): 

7927 """ 

7928 Plot the angle spectrum. 

7929 

7930 Compute the angle spectrum (wrapped phase spectrum) of *x*. 

7931 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function 

7932 *window* is applied to the signal. 

7933 

7934 Parameters 

7935 ---------- 

7936 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7937 Array or sequence containing the data. 

7938 

7939 %(Spectral)s 

7940 

7941 %(Single_Spectrum)s 

7942 

7943 Fc : int, default: 0 

7944 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7945 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7946 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7947 

7948 Returns 

7949 ------- 

7950 spectrum : 1-D array 

7951 The values for the angle spectrum in radians (real valued). 

7952 

7953 freqs : 1-D array 

7954 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*. 

7955 

7956 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7957 The line created by this function. 

7958 

7959 Other Parameters 

7960 ---------------- 

7961 data : indexable object, optional 

7962 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7963 

7964 **kwargs 

7965 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7966 

7967 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7968 

7969 See Also 

7970 -------- 

7971 magnitude_spectrum 

7972 Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies. 

7973 phase_spectrum 

7974 Plots the unwrapped version of this function. 

7975 specgram 

7976 Can plot the angle spectrum of segments within the signal in a 

7977 colormap. 

7978 """ 

7979 if Fc is None: 

7980 Fc = 0 

7981 

7982 spec, freqs = mlab.angle_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window, 

7983 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides) 

7984 freqs += Fc 

7985 

7986 lines = self.plot(freqs, spec, **kwargs) 

7987 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7988 self.set_ylabel('Angle (radians)') 

7989 

7990 return spec, freqs, lines[0] 

7991 

7992 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "Fs") 

7993 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7994 @_docstring.interpd 

7995 def phase_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None, 

7996 pad_to=None, sides=None, **kwargs): 

7997 """ 

7998 Plot the phase spectrum. 

7999 

8000 Compute the phase spectrum (unwrapped angle spectrum) of *x*. 

8001 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function 

8002 *window* is applied to the signal. 

8003 

8004 Parameters 

8005 ---------- 

8006 x : 1-D array or sequence 

8007 Array or sequence containing the data 

8008 

8009 %(Spectral)s 

8010 

8011 %(Single_Spectrum)s 

8012 

8013 Fc : int, default: 0 

8014 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

8015 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

8016 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

8017 

8018 Returns 

8019 ------- 

8020 spectrum : 1-D array 

8021 The values for the phase spectrum in radians (real valued). 

8022 

8023 freqs : 1-D array 

8024 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*. 

8025 

8026 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

8027 The line created by this function. 

8028 

8029 Other Parameters 

8030 ---------------- 

8031 data : indexable object, optional 

8032 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

8033 

8034 **kwargs 

8035 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

8036 

8037 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

8038 

8039 See Also 

8040 -------- 

8041 magnitude_spectrum 

8042 Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies. 

8043 angle_spectrum 

8044 Plots the wrapped version of this function. 

8045 specgram 

8046 Can plot the phase spectrum of segments within the signal in a 

8047 colormap. 

8048 """ 

8049 if Fc is None: 

8050 Fc = 0 

8051 

8052 spec, freqs = mlab.phase_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window, 

8053 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides) 

8054 freqs += Fc 

8055 

8056 lines = self.plot(freqs, spec, **kwargs) 

8057 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

8058 self.set_ylabel('Phase (radians)') 

8059 

8060 return spec, freqs, lines[0] 

8061 

8062 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "NFFT") 

8063 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"]) 

8064 @_docstring.interpd 

8065 def cohere(self, x, y, NFFT=256, Fs=2, Fc=0, detrend=mlab.detrend_none, 

8066 window=mlab.window_hanning, noverlap=0, pad_to=None, 

8067 sides='default', scale_by_freq=None, **kwargs): 

8068 r""" 

8069 Plot the coherence between *x* and *y*. 

8070 

8071 Coherence is the normalized cross spectral density: 

8072 

8073 .. math:: 

8074 

8075 C_{xy} = \frac{|P_{xy}|^2}{P_{xx}P_{yy}} 

8076 

8077 Parameters 

8078 ---------- 

8079 %(Spectral)s 

8080 

8081 %(PSD)s 

8082 

8083 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

8084 The number of points of overlap between blocks. 

8085 

8086 Fc : int, default: 0 

8087 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

8088 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

8089 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

8090 

8091 Returns 

8092 ------- 

8093 Cxy : 1-D array 

8094 The coherence vector. 

8095 

8096 freqs : 1-D array 

8097 The frequencies for the elements in *Cxy*. 

8098 

8099 Other Parameters 

8100 ---------------- 

8101 data : indexable object, optional 

8102 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

8103 

8104 **kwargs 

8105 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

8106 

8107 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

8108 

8109 References 

8110 ---------- 

8111 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

8112 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

8113 """ 

8114 cxy, freqs = mlab.cohere(x=x, y=y, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

8115 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, 

8116 scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq, sides=sides, 

8117 pad_to=pad_to) 

8118 freqs += Fc 

8119 

8120 self.plot(freqs, cxy, **kwargs) 

8121 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

8122 self.set_ylabel('Coherence') 

8123 self.grid(True) 

8124 

8125 return cxy, freqs 

8126 

8127 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "NFFT") 

8128 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

8129 @_docstring.interpd 

8130 def specgram(self, x, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

8131 window=None, noverlap=None, 

8132 cmap=None, xextent=None, pad_to=None, sides=None, 

8133 scale_by_freq=None, mode=None, scale=None, 

8134 vmin=None, vmax=None, **kwargs): 

8135 """ 

8136 Plot a spectrogram. 

8137 

8138 Compute and plot a spectrogram of data in *x*. Data are split into 

8139 *NFFT* length segments and the spectrum of each section is 

8140 computed. The windowing function *window* is applied to each 

8141 segment, and the amount of overlap of each segment is 

8142 specified with *noverlap*. The spectrogram is plotted as a colormap 

8143 (using imshow). 

8144 

8145 Parameters 

8146 ---------- 

8147 x : 1-D array or sequence 

8148 Array or sequence containing the data. 

8149 

8150 %(Spectral)s 

8151 

8152 %(PSD)s 

8153 

8154 mode : {'default', 'psd', 'magnitude', 'angle', 'phase'} 

8155 What sort of spectrum to use. Default is 'psd', which takes the 

8156 power spectral density. 'magnitude' returns the magnitude 

8157 spectrum. 'angle' returns the phase spectrum without unwrapping. 

8158 'phase' returns the phase spectrum with unwrapping. 

8159 

8160 noverlap : int, default: 128 

8161 The number of points of overlap between blocks. 

8162 

8163 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'} 

8164 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling. 

8165 'dB' returns the values in dB scale. When *mode* is 'psd', 

8166 this is dB power (10 * log10). Otherwise, this is dB amplitude 

8167 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'dB' if *mode* is 'psd' or 

8168 'magnitude' and 'linear' otherwise. This must be 'linear' 

8169 if *mode* is 'angle' or 'phase'. 

8170 

8171 Fc : int, default: 0 

8172 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

8173 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

8174 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

8175 

8176 cmap : `.Colormap`, default: :rc:`image.cmap` 

8177 

8178 xextent : *None* or (xmin, xmax) 

8179 The image extent along the x-axis. The default sets *xmin* to the 

8180 left border of the first bin (*spectrum* column) and *xmax* to the 

8181 right border of the last bin. Note that for *noverlap>0* the width 

8182 of the bins is smaller than those of the segments. 

8183 

8184 data : indexable object, optional 

8185 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

8186 

8187 vmin, vmax : float, optional 

8188 vmin and vmax define the data range that the colormap covers. 

8189 By default, the colormap covers the complete value range of the 

8190 data. 

8191 

8192 **kwargs 

8193 Additional keyword arguments are passed on to `~.axes.Axes.imshow` 

8194 which makes the specgram image. The origin keyword argument 

8195 is not supported. 

8196 

8197 Returns 

8198 ------- 

8199 spectrum : 2D array 

8200 Columns are the periodograms of successive segments. 

8201 

8202 freqs : 1-D array 

8203 The frequencies corresponding to the rows in *spectrum*. 

8204 

8205 t : 1-D array 

8206 The times corresponding to midpoints of segments (i.e., the columns 

8207 in *spectrum*). 

8208 

8209 im : `.AxesImage` 

8210 The image created by imshow containing the spectrogram. 

8211 

8212 See Also 

8213 -------- 

8214 psd 

8215 Differs in the default overlap; in returning the mean of the 

8216 segment periodograms; in not returning times; and in generating a 

8217 line plot instead of colormap. 

8218 magnitude_spectrum 

8219 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

8220 is 'magnitude'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

8221 angle_spectrum 

8222 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

8223 is 'angle'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

8224 phase_spectrum 

8225 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

8226 is 'phase'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

8227 

8228 Notes 

8229 ----- 

8230 The parameters *detrend* and *scale_by_freq* do only apply when *mode* 

8231 is set to 'psd'. 

8232 """ 

8233 if NFFT is None: 

8234 NFFT = 256 # same default as in mlab.specgram() 

8235 if Fc is None: 

8236 Fc = 0 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper() 

8237 if noverlap is None: 

8238 noverlap = 128 # same default as in mlab.specgram() 

8239 if Fs is None: 

8240 Fs = 2 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper() 

8241 

8242 if mode == 'complex': 

8243 raise ValueError('Cannot plot a complex specgram') 

8244 

8245 if scale is None or scale == 'default': 

8246 if mode in ['angle', 'phase']: 

8247 scale = 'linear' 

8248 else: 

8249 scale = 'dB' 

8250 elif mode in ['angle', 'phase'] and scale == 'dB': 

8251 raise ValueError('Cannot use dB scale with angle or phase mode') 

8252 

8253 spec, freqs, t = mlab.specgram(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, 

8254 detrend=detrend, window=window, 

8255 noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

8256 sides=sides, 

8257 scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq, 

8258 mode=mode) 

8259 

8260 if scale == 'linear': 

8261 Z = spec 

8262 elif scale == 'dB': 

8263 if mode is None or mode == 'default' or mode == 'psd': 

8264 Z = 10. * np.log10(spec) 

8265 else: 

8266 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec) 

8267 else: 

8268 raise ValueError(f'Unknown scale {scale!r}') 

8269 

8270 Z = np.flipud(Z) 

8271 

8272 if xextent is None: 

8273 # padding is needed for first and last segment: 

8274 pad_xextent = (NFFT-noverlap) / Fs / 2 

8275 xextent = np.min(t) - pad_xextent, np.max(t) + pad_xextent 

8276 xmin, xmax = xextent 

8277 freqs += Fc 

8278 extent = xmin, xmax, freqs[0], freqs[-1] 

8279 

8280 if 'origin' in kwargs: 

8281 raise _api.kwarg_error("specgram", "origin") 

8282 

8283 im = self.imshow(Z, cmap, extent=extent, vmin=vmin, vmax=vmax, 

8284 origin='upper', **kwargs) 

8285 self.axis('auto') 

8286 

8287 return spec, freqs, t, im 

8288 

8289 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "precision") 

8290 @_docstring.interpd 

8291 def spy(self, Z, precision=0, marker=None, markersize=None, 

8292 aspect='equal', origin="upper", **kwargs): 

8293 """ 

8294 Plot the sparsity pattern of a 2D array. 

8295 

8296 This visualizes the non-zero values of the array. 

8297 

8298 Two plotting styles are available: image and marker. Both 

8299 are available for full arrays, but only the marker style 

8300 works for `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances. 

8301 

8302 **Image style** 

8303 

8304 If *marker* and *markersize* are *None*, `~.Axes.imshow` is used. Any 

8305 extra remaining keyword arguments are passed to this method. 

8306 

8307 **Marker style** 

8308 

8309 If *Z* is a `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` or *marker* or *markersize* are 

8310 *None*, a `.Line2D` object will be returned with the value of marker 

8311 determining the marker type, and any remaining keyword arguments 

8312 passed to `~.Axes.plot`. 

8313 

8314 Parameters 

8315 ---------- 

8316 Z : (M, N) array-like 

8317 The array to be plotted. 

8318 

8319 precision : float or 'present', default: 0 

8320 If *precision* is 0, any non-zero value will be plotted. Otherwise, 

8321 values of :math:`|Z| > precision` will be plotted. 

8322 

8323 For `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances, you can also 

8324 pass 'present'. In this case any value present in the array 

8325 will be plotted, even if it is identically zero. 

8326 

8327 aspect : {'equal', 'auto', None} or float, default: 'equal' 

8328 The aspect ratio of the Axes. This parameter is particularly 

8329 relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are 

8330 square. 

8331 

8332 This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling 

8333 `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details. 

8334 

8335 - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square. 

8336 - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so 

8337 that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in 

8338 non-square pixels. 

8339 - *None*: Use :rc:`image.aspect`. 

8340 

8341 origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin` 

8342 Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower left 

8343 corner of the Axes. The convention 'upper' is typically used for 

8344 matrices and images. 

8345 

8346 Returns 

8347 ------- 

8348 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` or `.Line2D` 

8349 The return type depends on the plotting style (see above). 

8350 

8351 Other Parameters 

8352 ---------------- 

8353 **kwargs 

8354 The supported additional parameters depend on the plotting style. 

8355 

8356 For the image style, you can pass the following additional 

8357 parameters of `~.Axes.imshow`: 

8358 

8359 - *cmap* 

8360 - *alpha* 

8361 - *url* 

8362 - any `.Artist` properties (passed on to the `.AxesImage`) 

8363 

8364 For the marker style, you can pass any `.Line2D` property except 

8365 for *linestyle*: 

8366 

8367 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

8368 """ 

8369 if marker is None and markersize is None and hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'): 

8370 marker = 's' 

8371 _api.check_in_list(["upper", "lower"], origin=origin) 

8372 if marker is None and markersize is None: 

8373 Z = np.asarray(Z) 

8374 mask = np.abs(Z) > precision 

8375 

8376 if 'cmap' not in kwargs: 

8377 kwargs['cmap'] = mcolors.ListedColormap(['w', 'k'], 

8378 name='binary') 

8379 if 'interpolation' in kwargs: 

8380 raise _api.kwarg_error("spy", "interpolation") 

8381 if 'norm' not in kwargs: 

8382 kwargs['norm'] = mcolors.NoNorm() 

8383 ret = self.imshow(mask, interpolation='nearest', 

8384 aspect=aspect, origin=origin, 

8385 **kwargs) 

8386 else: 

8387 if hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'): 

8388 c = Z.tocoo() 

8389 if precision == 'present': 

8390 y = c.row 

8391 x = c.col 

8392 else: 

8393 nonzero = np.abs(c.data) > precision 

8394 y = c.row[nonzero] 

8395 x = c.col[nonzero] 

8396 else: 

8397 Z = np.asarray(Z) 

8398 nonzero = np.abs(Z) > precision 

8399 y, x = np.nonzero(nonzero) 

8400 if marker is None: 

8401 marker = 's' 

8402 if markersize is None: 

8403 markersize = 10 

8404 if 'linestyle' in kwargs: 

8405 raise _api.kwarg_error("spy", "linestyle") 

8406 ret = mlines.Line2D( 

8407 x, y, linestyle='None', marker=marker, markersize=markersize, 

8408 **kwargs) 

8409 self.add_line(ret) 

8410 nr, nc = Z.shape 

8411 self.set_xlim(-0.5, nc - 0.5) 

8412 if origin == "upper": 

8413 self.set_ylim(nr - 0.5, -0.5) 

8414 else: 

8415 self.set_ylim(-0.5, nr - 0.5) 

8416 self.set_aspect(aspect) 

8417 self.title.set_y(1.05) 

8418 if origin == "upper": 

8419 self.xaxis.tick_top() 

8420 else: # lower 

8421 self.xaxis.tick_bottom() 

8422 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both') 

8423 self.xaxis.set_major_locator( 

8424 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8425 self.yaxis.set_major_locator( 

8426 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8427 return ret 

8428 

8429 def matshow(self, Z, **kwargs): 

8430 """ 

8431 Plot the values of a 2D matrix or array as color-coded image. 

8432 

8433 The matrix will be shown the way it would be printed, with the first 

8434 row at the top. Row and column numbering is zero-based. 

8435 

8436 Parameters 

8437 ---------- 

8438 Z : (M, N) array-like 

8439 The matrix to be displayed. 

8440 

8441 Returns 

8442 ------- 

8443 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` 

8444 

8445 Other Parameters 

8446 ---------------- 

8447 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow` arguments 

8448 

8449 See Also 

8450 -------- 

8451 imshow : More general function to plot data on a 2D regular raster. 

8452 

8453 Notes 

8454 ----- 

8455 This is just a convenience function wrapping `.imshow` to set useful 

8456 defaults for displaying a matrix. In particular: 

8457 

8458 - Set ``origin='upper'``. 

8459 - Set ``interpolation='nearest'``. 

8460 - Set ``aspect='equal'``. 

8461 - Ticks are placed to the left and above. 

8462 - Ticks are formatted to show integer indices. 

8463 

8464 """ 

8465 Z = np.asanyarray(Z) 

8466 kw = {'origin': 'upper', 

8467 'interpolation': 'nearest', 

8468 'aspect': 'equal', # (already the imshow default) 

8469 **kwargs} 

8470 im = self.imshow(Z, **kw) 

8471 self.title.set_y(1.05) 

8472 self.xaxis.tick_top() 

8473 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both') 

8474 self.xaxis.set_major_locator( 

8475 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8476 self.yaxis.set_major_locator( 

8477 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8478 return im 

8479 

8480 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "vert") 

8481 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["dataset"]) 

8482 def violinplot(self, dataset, positions=None, vert=None, 

8483 orientation='vertical', widths=0.5, showmeans=False, 

8484 showextrema=True, showmedians=False, quantiles=None, 

8485 points=100, bw_method=None, side='both',): 

8486 """ 

8487 Make a violin plot. 

8488 

8489 Make a violin plot for each column of *dataset* or each vector in 

8490 sequence *dataset*. Each filled area extends to represent the 

8491 entire data range, with optional lines at the mean, the median, 

8492 the minimum, the maximum, and user-specified quantiles. 

8493 

8494 Parameters 

8495 ---------- 

8496 dataset : Array or a sequence of vectors. 

8497 The input data. 

8498 

8499 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n] 

8500 The positions of the violins; i.e. coordinates on the x-axis for 

8501 vertical violins (or y-axis for horizontal violins). 

8502 

8503 vert : bool, optional 

8504 .. deprecated:: 3.10 

8505 Use *orientation* instead. 

8506 

8507 If this is given during the deprecation period, it overrides 

8508 the *orientation* parameter. 

8509 

8510 If True, plots the violins vertically. 

8511 If False, plots the violins horizontally. 

8512 

8513 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

8514 If 'horizontal', plots the violins horizontally. 

8515 Otherwise, plots the violins vertically. 

8516 

8517 .. versionadded:: 3.10 

8518 

8519 widths : float or array-like, default: 0.5 

8520 The maximum width of each violin in units of the *positions* axis. 

8521 The default is 0.5, which is half the available space when using default 

8522 *positions*. 

8523 

8524 showmeans : bool, default: False 

8525 Whether to show the mean with a line. 

8526 

8527 showextrema : bool, default: True 

8528 Whether to show extrema with a line. 

8529 

8530 showmedians : bool, default: False 

8531 Whether to show the median with a line. 

8532 

8533 quantiles : array-like, default: None 

8534 If not None, set a list of floats in interval [0, 1] for each violin, 

8535 which stands for the quantiles that will be rendered for that 

8536 violin. 

8537 

8538 points : int, default: 100 

8539 The number of points to evaluate each of the gaussian kernel density 

8540 estimations at. 

8541 

8542 bw_method : {'scott', 'silverman'} or float or callable, default: 'scott' 

8543 The method used to calculate the estimator bandwidth. If a 

8544 float, this will be used directly as `kde.factor`. If a 

8545 callable, it should take a `matplotlib.mlab.GaussianKDE` instance as 

8546 its only parameter and return a float. 

8547 

8548 side : {'both', 'low', 'high'}, default: 'both' 

8549 'both' plots standard violins. 'low'/'high' only 

8550 plots the side below/above the positions value. 

8551 

8552 data : indexable object, optional 

8553 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

8554 

8555 Returns 

8556 ------- 

8557 dict 

8558 A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a 

8559 list of the corresponding collection instances created. The 

8560 dictionary has the following keys: 

8561 

8562 - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection` 

8563 instances containing the filled area of each violin. 

8564 

8565 - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8566 the mean values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8567 

8568 - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8569 the bottom of each violin's distribution. 

8570 

8571 - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8572 the top of each violin's distribution. 

8573 

8574 - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8575 the centers of each violin's distribution. 

8576 

8577 - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that 

8578 marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8579 

8580 - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created 

8581 to identify the quantile values of each of the violin's 

8582 distribution. 

8583 

8584 See Also 

8585 -------- 

8586 .Axes.violin : Draw a violin from pre-computed statistics. 

8587 boxplot : Draw a box and whisker plot. 

8588 """ 

8589 

8590 def _kde_method(X, coords): 

8591 # Unpack in case of e.g. Pandas or xarray object 

8592 X = cbook._unpack_to_numpy(X) 

8593 # fallback gracefully if the vector contains only one value 

8594 if np.all(X[0] == X): 

8595 return (X[0] == coords).astype(float) 

8596 kde = mlab.GaussianKDE(X, bw_method) 

8597 return kde.evaluate(coords) 

8598 

8599 vpstats = cbook.violin_stats(dataset, _kde_method, points=points, 

8600 quantiles=quantiles) 

8601 return self.violin(vpstats, positions=positions, vert=vert, 

8602 orientation=orientation, widths=widths, 

8603 showmeans=showmeans, showextrema=showextrema, 

8604 showmedians=showmedians, side=side) 

8605 

8606 @_api.make_keyword_only("3.9", "vert") 

8607 def violin(self, vpstats, positions=None, vert=None, 

8608 orientation='vertical', widths=0.5, showmeans=False, 

8609 showextrema=True, showmedians=False, side='both'): 

8610 """ 

8611 Draw a violin plot from pre-computed statistics. 

8612 

8613 Draw a violin plot for each column of *vpstats*. Each filled area 

8614 extends to represent the entire data range, with optional lines at the 

8615 mean, the median, the minimum, the maximum, and the quantiles values. 

8616 

8617 Parameters 

8618 ---------- 

8619 vpstats : list of dicts 

8620 A list of dictionaries containing stats for each violin plot. 

8621 Required keys are: 

8622
